HP stock rose a small fraction to 15.59 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has an above-average IBD Composite Rating of 60, but there are more attractive stocks near buy zones. Read the article, "Stocks Near Buy Zone: Which Names May Set Sail On Columbus Day?"At the analyst day, Wall Street expects an update on HP's printing business strategy, including a timeline for a recovery in supplies sales and the recently announced acquisition of Samsung's printing business.Analysts also want to get more data points about a possible recovery in PC sales."Given HP's subdued outlook for October-quarter PC performance, we think there could be upside to (HP's Personal Systems Group) results based on recent developments including Intel's (INTC) positive pre-announcement and data points from PC suppliers," Daryanani said.Also on the agenda are updates on HP's growth prospects in new businesses, including 3D printers and A3 copiers.On Friday, Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha reiterated his outperform rating on HP stock, with a price target of 19.RELATED:Intel Stock Earns Price-Target Hikes On Apple, PC DevelopmentsHP Hopes To Disrupt Copier Market With Samsung Printer Purchase

Chipmaker Intel (INTC) is expected to show improved sales and earnings when it reports third-quarter results after the market close Tuesday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Intel to earn 73 cents a share excluding items, up 14% year over year, on sales of $15.58 billion, up nearly 8%.For the December quarter, Wall Street is modeling for Intel to earn 77 cents a share minus items, up 4%, on sales of $15.86 billion, up 6%.IBD'S TAKE: Intel stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, meaning it has outperformed 89% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. That's good, but there are even better stocks to consider. The IBD 50 list of superior stocks includes seven stocks from the semiconductor industry.Intel stock fell a fraction to 37.29 on the stock market today. Intel shares last month touched a 36.03 buy point out of a flat base, so it remains within buy range.The last time Intel reported quarterly results back on July 20, it was a mixed bag, with Q2 EPS better than views and sales slightly below targets.Intel preannounced better-than-expected results for Q3 on Sept. 16 when it raised its revenue guidance for the September quarter. The chip giant largely credited "replenishment of PC supply chain inventory," but also said it's "seeing some signs of improving PC demand."With Intel's Q3 earnings report, analysts will be looking for signs that the improvement in PC demand is sustainable and for strength in the company's data center group.Wall Street also will be looking for information on the impact of Intel's baseband chip win in some models of Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 7 series, RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a research report Monday.RELATED:Intel Inside iPhone 7; Chipmaker Wins Apple BusinessHP Gains On Lenovo In PCs; Apple Mac Sales Tumble

A survey of 3D printer resellers indicated a challenging market in the third quarter that was "extremely discouraging" for market leaders' Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD), according to a Piper Jaffray survey.Piper Jaffray analyst Troy Jensen collected feedback from 68 3D printer makers and service bureau operators, skewed toward Stratasys and 3D Systems."The results were extremely discouraging for both Stratasys and 3D Systems," Jensen wrote in a research report. Both companies are likely to miss revenue estimates when they report Q3 earnings next month, he wrote. EPS is less at risk due to cost cutting by both companies, he said.IBD'S TAKE: Both 3D Systems and Stratasys are far off their highs from 2014, and have weak performance ratings, based on a variety of IBD metrics. IBD's Stock Spotlight currently lists 16 stocks with top fundamentals that could be getting ready to break out.Stratasys and 3D Systems are expected to report Q3 earnings in mid-November.The consensus estimate on 3D Systems is revenue growth of 5.6% to $160.2 million, and earnings per share minus items of 9 cents, up from a 1 cent in the year-earlier quarter. The company's earnings turned positive in Q2, rising 300% after five quarters of no growth or declines.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Stratasys revenue to climb 4% to $174.5 million, with EPS of 5 cents vs. a penny. It would be its first year-over-year profit gain in eight quarters.Stratasys and 3D Systems stock have both fallen for the last three days. 3D Systems stock closed Thursday at 14.82, down 5%. Stratasys fell 3.5% to 21.23.Among the reasons for the weak performance of the 3D printer market in Q3 is sustained weakness overall and the entry of HP Inc. (HPQ) into the market.HP made its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market five months ago, with plans to begin shipping product later this year. Jensen and other industry analysts say some buyers have postponed purchases while they wait for HP to ship product."We believe the biggest headwind continues to be increased competition, and believe the entry of HP and (privately held) Carbon 3D, as well as newer entrants, have caused customers to pause spending on traditional brands and assess these new offerings," Jensen wrote.RELATED:3D Printer Maker 3D Systems Eyes 'Inflection Point"General Electric Or HP Takeover Of 3D Systems Seen UnlikelyShake-Up At 3D Systems As Two Executives Depart 3D Printer CompanyGE Buys European 3D Printing Firms, Lifting 3D Systems, Stratasys

Three dimensional printers – devices that manufacture computer-designed items from powdered plastics, ceramics, metal, sugar and other raw materials – are once again drawing investor attention. The technologies stirred an investor and media frenzy in the three years through 2014. At that time, 3D printers were just taking hold in consumer markets and developing critical mass in some commercial and…

The overall 0.6% bounceback in retail sales last month comes with a caveat: Total spending looked healthy, but much of the gain came in categories that may not drive growth going forward.A core measure of goods spending that strips out restaurants, cars and gas, as well as building materials, rose just 0.1% in September. That was well below the 0.4% gain expected by economists and came after a 0.1% decline in this broad "control group" category of retail spending.Sales at electronics and appliance stores like Best Buy (BBY) remained a sore spot. Despite the midmonth launch of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7, seasonally adjusted sales fell 0.9% from August and 3.8% from a year ago. Best Buy shares fell 1.3% on the stock market today but are still near 52-week highs. Apple is near 2016 highs amid strong initial iPhone 7 demand and rival Samsung's overheating problems with its Note 7, which finally prompted the company to end sales and production of the smartphone.Slumping demand for PCs and printers led Hewlett-Packard (HP) on Thursday to announce a gradual reduction of 3,000 to 4,000 jobs. Electronics retailers also are being squeezed by the likes of Amazon (AMZN). Nonstore retailers saw September sales rise 0.3% from August after a 0.1% dip the prior month. Though online sales momentum has cooled a bit in the past few months, nonstore retailers still are posting double-digit year-over-year gains — 10.6% in September.Department store sales slid 0.7% from August and 6.4% from a year ago. Some of the slide reflects store closures. Still, analysts at Sterne Agee downgraded shares of Macy's (M) to neutral from buy on Friday, noting a slowdown in same-store sales growth. JPMorgan cut price targets and Q3 estimates on Macy's, JCPenney (JCP), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS).Macy's, Kohl's shares fell about 3% Friday while Dillard's skidded 4.6%. Kohl's and Nordstom fell fractionally.Everything to do with the housing market shined in September. Sales at building materials and garden equipment stores like Home Depot (HD) surged 1.4% from August, more than reversing a 0.8% decline the prior month. Meanwhile, furniture store sales rose 1.0% from August and 2.7% from a year ago.Home Depot shares rose 0.1%.One of the surprises in the retail report was the strong gain in spending at food service and drinking places, up 0.8% from August, when sales rose 0.7%. Sales have moderated on a year-over-year basis to 6.1% from the 8%-plus pace that prevailed for most of 2015. Still, the gains over the past two months are a pleasant surprise given that McDonald's (MCD), Wendy's (WEN), Jack in the Box (JACK) and others have cited pressure from the growing cost gap between eating in and eating out.McDonald's stock fell 1.1%, while Wendy's and Jack in the Box rose fractionally.IBD'S TAKE: The Retail-Restaurants industry group is ranked in the lower tier by IBD, No. 113 out of 197 based on share performance. Investors will generally have more success buying leaders in top-tier groups, when the market trend is favorable. Sill, Papa Johns and Dunkin' Brands, are close to buy points and worth watching. Go to IBD Stock Checkup to find out why they're the two top stocks in the group.September restaurant sales data out Thursday from TDn2K covering 25,000 locations shed further light on industry trends. Overall, same-store sales fell 1.1% from a year ago in September, while customer traffic slumped 3.5%. The sector is on pace for its worst performance since 2009.Still, overall sales are performing better than same-store sales because of continued industry expansion, and the quick-service industry is doing a whole lot better than the rest, growing same-store sales 2.2% from a year ago in the third quarter, Nation's Restaurant News reported.On Friday, Bank of America analysts upgraded Domino's Pizza (DPZ) to buy from underperform, noting that the research firm expects 10.4% U.S. same-store sales growth in the third quarter. Domino's reports on Tuesday before the open. Domino's rose 0.5%.Auto sales jumped 1.1% in September, as U.S. vehicle sales rose to a 17.76 million annual rate from 17 million the prior month. Sales of higher-margin pickups and SUVs outperformed at Ford (F), General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), helping offset their unit sales declines vs. a year ago."The decline in gasoline prices relative to a year ago is likely to continue to support SUV sales," wrote Jefferies economists Ward McCarthy and Thomas Simons. "Nonetheless, overall vehicle sales are at a level that may be close to a ceiling."Ford shares closed unchanged. GM rallied 1.1% and Fiat Chrysler shares 2.3%.Gas station sales helped pump up the overall retail sales gain, rising 2.4% from August. McCarthy and Simons noted that the big rise was based on seasonal adjustments: Gas prices fell in 0.8% in September, but they usually fall 2.8% during the month after the peak summer driving season.RELATED:Off The Charts: Fast Food Inflation Vs. Eating InU.S. Auto Sales Sluggish, But Top Views On Strong Truck Demand

AT&T (T) announced a partnership with Amazon Web Services, the leading cloud computing service provider, a day after expanding its ties with IBM (IBM).AT&T says it will connect customers to AWS, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), using its high-speed private network services. Called NetBond, AT&T's private network services provide security and other tools to tap cloud infrastructure.AWS is the biggest provider of infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), where customers rent computing resources via the web. Besides IBM, AT&T's other Netbond partners include Box (BOX), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Salesforce.com (CRM), Microsoft's (MSFT) Azure and HP (HPQ).IBD'S TAKE: Amazon's stock has jumped nearly 25% in 2016. The c-commerce leader has more than one growth engine. Its cloud computing arm, AWS, is one. Then there's Amazon Prime, the customer loyalty program. Learn more about Amazon's technical chart at IBD's Leaderboard of top growth stocks.Salesforce forged its own cloud alliance with AWS in May. AT&T and Amazon said their partnership includes services involving web-connected industrial and consumer devices, also called the Internet of Things. Salesforce.com's deal with AWS also includes IoT apps.AT&T on Wednesday said its "FlexWare" network management tools will be run on IBM's cloud platform. IBM acquired cloud services provider SoftLayer for $2 billion in 2013. AT&T forged a marketing partnership with IBM and SoftLayer in 2014.Shares of AT&T closed 0.1% lower at 39.11 and Amazon dipped 0.3% to 841.66 in the stock market today.RELATED:How Amazon, Microsoft, Google Crushed Verizon, AT&T In The CloudAmazon Stock Hits Another High As Amazon Prime Users Keep 'Ramping'

One chapter in Nvidia's (NVDA) rivalry with Intel (INTC) is nearing an end: Royalty payments from Intel that have boosted Nvidia earnings since 2011 could sunset next year — just as more competition unfolds between them in data centers, self-driving cars and augmented reality.Both Intel and Nvidia, whose stock has jumped 103% in 2016 after slipping a fraction on Friday, stick out as chipmakers hunting for the next killer app. Mobile phone sales are slowing globally, much as the PC market did earlier. Intel and Nvidia aim for leadership in semiconductors used in cars, artificial intelligence and visual processing.The moves into new markets are panning out, but Nvidia still gets 60% of revenue from PC graphics and gaming.Intel, which in Q2 derived 54% of its revenue from its PC unit, recently acquired startups in the AI and visual computing fields. Observers wonder what Nvidia might buy, with nearly $5 billion in cash on its balance sheet.But where Intel has had four chief executives since Nvidia was founded in 1993, Nvidia has had one CEO: Jen-Hsun Huang, one of Nvidia's three co-founders. The CEO gets kudos for reinventing Nvidia and for his ability to recruit top engineers to the chipmaker."Jen-Hsun has made several gutsy calls in the past decade," Mark Hung, an analyst at tech research firm Gartner, told IBD. "Some of them worked out very well, a couple not so much. When he sees an opportunity, he's been able to marshal the company's full resources behind it. In data center and automotive, they're charging ahead."IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia's big year hasn't just been good for a chip company or for a tech company, but for any company. How good? The IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks over the past 52 weeks, with an emphasis on the most recent six months, is always a great place to find winners. Nvidia currently ranks No. 5 on that hard-to-make list.Huang is slated to deliver a preshow keynote address at CES 2017 in January and is expected to trumpet emerging gaming and AI technology, as well as AR headsets and self-driving cars. Its chips already help power the instrument and navigation displays in Tesla Motors (TSLA) e-cars and others.Nvidia continues to improve upon the high-end graphics processing that made it the leader in gaming, along with Advance Micro Devices (AMD). An Nvidia edge is that its powerful graphics processors, thanks to their "parallel-processing" circuitry, can be extended to artificial intelligence software.AI chips are well-suited for facial or object recognition, a plus for robotics and security applications, as well as spoken-language apps. Much R&D is focused on "deep learning," an AI tool that enables computers to be trained and to perform actual reasoning. Self-driving cars map their surroundings and detect hazards, for example.In self-driving, Nvidia has "the right product at the right time," said Malcolm Penn, founder and CEO of U.K.-based Future Horizons, a semiconductor research firm. "Autonomous driving is all about vision and parallel processing," and Nvidia products are "perfect for this; Intel ... is not."Intel's chips still dominate in low-end PC graphics. And its chips are built into most computer servers packed into data centers. Nvidia's chips are gaining in data center gear as well, with technology well-suited for apps such as credit-card fraud-detection systems, says David Kanter, an analyst at Real World Technologies and the Linley Group.Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and others are racing to develop AI-based apps that can be delivered to consumers via the internet cloud. There's another race underway to equip data centers with AI hardware and software.Intel's August acquisition of startup Nervana Systems heated up its rivalry with Nvidia. Nervana's technology processes "deep learning" algorithms. For its part, Intel last month acquired startup Movidius, whose visual processors are used in drones, virtual reality devices and autonomous machines."Intel has only recently started to focus on machine learning and doesn't offer the same level of performance as Nvidia's latest products," Kanter said. "The Nervana acquisition is an attempt by Intel to get expertise in machine learning and defend its territory in the data center."For its fiscal Q2 ended July 31, Santa Clara, Calif.-based Nvidia's revenue jumped 24% from the year earlier, easily its best showing in at least four years. EPS ex items jumped 56% to 53 cents, its best showing in two years.But for its fiscal 2018 ending Jan. 31, 2018, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are modeling only 3% full-year EPS growth. That's where the patent cross-licensing deal signed by Intel and Nvidia in 2011 comes in. Intel agreed to pay Nvidia $1.5 billion over six years, or roughly $264 million annually, to settle a patent dispute.In an email, Intel spokesman William Moss declined to comment on whether Intel plans to renew the agreement. Analysts say Nvidia has indicated there won't be a renewal.Nvidia can make up the Intel loss, says William Stein, a SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst. "Nvidia's margins will be pressured in the near term for the nearly 90%-margin Intel-licensing revenue rolling off in 2017," said Stein in a research report. "We believe this will be more than offset in the long term by growth in the high-margin data center end-market, plus new products in automotive, lifting margins above the corporate average. Increasing ASPs (average selling prices) in gaming will also help."Some observers speculate that Nvidia could win back some PC business at Apple, where AMD's chips have recently been built into Mac desktops and laptops.Nvidia and AMD talked merger back in 2005. A deal would have created a bigger rival to Intel. Huang wanted to be CEO of the combined chip company, analysts say, and the deal fell apart.M&A has not been a big part of Nvidia's DNA, though it bought U.K.-based Icera for around $370 million in 2011. Nvidia had problems melding Icera's modem technology with its GPUs and wrote down the Icera business in 2015, says Will Strauss, president of market research firm Forward Concepts. While Nvidia has won some design wins in tablets, it's not a volume player in smartphones.With nearly $5 billion in cash on its balance sheet, Nvidia could be primed for acquisitions, Nomura analyst Romit Shah speculated in a September research report.With a market cap over $13.5 billion, Xilinx (XLNX) could be out of Nvidia's reach, but it's a potentially potent combo. "Nvidia and Xilinx … now that would change the world as we know it," said Penn via email. Intel plucked down $16.7 billion in 2015 to buy top Xilinx rival Altera, which like Xilinx has a sizable data center business.Shah speculates that Nvidia might be interested in IBM's (IBM) Power family of processors. IBM and Nvidia have been partners in AI projects.Nvidia garners just over 10% of revenue from its data center business and, for now, only about 8% from automotive. Besides Tesla, Nvidia works with such automakers as Audi, BMW, Honda (HMC), Mercedes-Benz and Volvo, providing technology for infotainment, navigation, digital instrument clusters and advanced driver-assistance systems.Self-driving cars are one big battleground for Intel and Nvidia. Intel has teamed with autonomous-driving tech company Mobileye (MBLY) and Germany's BMW with the goal of bringing a self-driving car to market by 2021.Nvidia's highest-profile customer and partner might be Tesla Motors (TSLA). (Nvidia, by coincidence, has a line of AI and deep-learning platforms brand-named Tesla, but its Tegra line is what is used inside Tesla and other cars.) In August, Nvidia nabbed another biggie, announcing a partnership with China internet giant Baidu (BIDU) to make an autonomous car platform.Self-driving cars would be a big leap forward technologically for the chipmaker, says Kanter, but he says it's far too early to call Nvidia a winner of the race."It's not clear to me how well Nvidia's expertise will translate outside of gaming and PCs," Kanter said. "Automotive products are totally different from consumer electronics and the car manufacturers play a much more active role in system integration than a PC (maker) like HP (HPQ) or Dell."There are many other companies that are more specialized in automotive."RELATED:Nvidia Debuts AI Supercomputer Chip For Self-Driving CarsNvidia Could Provide Graphics Chips For Apple Mac ComputersIntel Among Chipmakers Getting Vote Of Confidence

HP Inc. (HPQ) on Monday announced a $1.05 billion deal to buy the printer business of Samsung Electronics, in a move to shake up the stodgy office copier market.HP said it hopes the acquisition will accelerate its goal of disrupting and reinventing the $55 billion copier industry. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company wants to get customers to switch to more reliable multifunction printer technology and away from outdated, complicated copiers. HP said traditional copiers have dozens of replaceable parts and require frequent servicing to keep functioning.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 46 and ranks No. 3 out of 16 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware and Peripherals industry group. To find out which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Samsung's portfolio of A3 multifunction printers deliver the performance of copiers with the reliability and ease-of-use of printers and with as few as seven replaceable parts, HP said in a press release.HP expects to complete the all-cash acquisition within 12 months pending regulatory review and customary closing conditions.After the deal closes, Samsung has agreed to make a $100 million to $300 million equity investment in HP through open market purchases."The acquisition of Samsung's printer business allows us to deliver print innovation and create entirely new business opportunities with far better efficiency, security, and economics for customers" HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement.Samsung's printer business also brings an intellectual property portfolio of more than 6,500 printing patents.HP said the deal will strengthen its position in laser printing, a category where it has a partnership with Canon (CAJ).RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani says HP will be able to lessen its reliance on Canon technology through the Samsung printer business acquisition."There is a strategic element to this deal as HP currently licenses its laser print technology from Canon," he said in a research report. "Samsung's laser technology could reduce its reliance on Canon. In this scenario, HP could see potential synergies increase beyond straightforward consolidation."Daryanani said HP could reduce its cost-of-goods profile as a result of the asset purchase. He estimates Canon represents about 10% to 15% of HP's cost of goods.HP stock was up 3% to 14.49 on the stock market today. Canon's U.S. shares fell 1.4% to 28.63.The Samsung printer unit generates about $1 billion to $1.6 billion in annual revenue and could add 5 to 15 cents to HP's annual earnings per share, Daryanani said. He rates HP stock as sector perform, with a price target of 14.RELATED:HP Printing Woes Hit Stock, But Not For Long

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE)  is near an agreement to sell its software business to U.K.-based Micro Focus International PLC, according to people with knowledge of the matter.The terms being discussed value the assets at more than $8 billion, said the sources, who asked not to be identified because the information is private. A deal could be announced as soon as Wednesday afternoon, one person said.Micro Focus, based in Newbury, England, can use the assets to bolster its software products that help companies on a variety of fronts, including business applications, security and with data centers.HP Enterprise has been considering a sale of some of its software assets, people familiar with the matter said in July, in an effort to slim down its operations. The possible divestitures included a portfolio of acquisitions made over roughly the past decade, including Autonomy, Mercury Interactive and Vertica Systems.Kate Holderness, spokeswoman for HP Enterprise, declined to comment. Representatives of Micro Focus didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.Chief Executive Meg Whitman -- who split HP Enterprise from sister company HP Inc. in November -- is looking for more ways to pare down her company. Her aim is to make the enterprise unit nimbler to woo customers with more options from cloud providers such as Amazon.com (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT).Sky News previously reported that Micro Focus is planning to buy HPE's software business.

An acquisition of 3D Systems (DDD) is unlikely in the wake of General Electric's (GE) plans to buy two European makers of metal printing products, though Belgium-based Materialize (MTLS) could be acquired, speculates Pacific Crest Securities.Shares of 3D Systems and rival Stratasys (SSYS) closed down 1.9% and 3.5%, respectively, in afternoon trading on the stock market today. But they rose 5.6% and 3.8%, respectively, Tuesday after GE announced that it would buy acquire Sweden's Arcam and Germany's SLM Solutions Group for $1.4 billion, respectively. The two companies are leading suppliers of metal additive 3D manufacturing machines. Most 3D printer companies make parts from plastic and other materials.Weston Twigg, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, says GE's acquisitions could pressure 3D Systems, but he doesn't expect a buyer such as HP Inc. (HPQ) to surface. HP is just entering the 3D printer field."We don't expect any near-term bid for 3D Systems, despite GE's announcement," Twigg said in a research report late Tuesday. "3D Systems has an overly broad product portfolio, in our view, and larger entrants like HP and GE are looking at ways to leverage in-house expertise to improve upon current 3D printing technology rather than entering the market through a large acquisition."IBD'S TAKE: GE aims to be a leader in the industrial internet, but its core businesses include aviation, where 3D manufacturing could play a role. GE stock hit an eight-year high in early 2016, but shares have slipped of late. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.GE expects to generate $1 billion in revenue from 3D printing activities by 2020. GE's push into 3D printing is a negative for 3D Systems, which makes metal printers, and relatively neutral for Stratasys and Proto Labs (PRLB), says Pacific Crest's Twigg. He says GE might eventually try to buy Materialise."If GE creates a more aggressive competitive dynamic, 3D Systems will need to decide whether it should continue to invest R&D to continue to develop its platform, or whether to exit metals altogether," added Twigg. "There's an outside chance that Materialise could become a GE acquisition."RELATED:GE Buys European Printing Firms, Lifting 3D Systems, Stratasys

Chinese competition dogs the likes of Apple (AAPL), HP (HPQ), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Intel (INTC) and many other U.S. companies -- but not so much the makers of fiber-optic components, especially at the high-end of the market.That's a good thing for optical component makers such as Acacia Communications (ACIA), Lumentum Holdings (LITE), Finisar (FNSR), Oclaro (OCLR), and NeoPhotonics (NPTN), which aim to ride a so-called "supercycle" that some analysts expect could last more than two to three years.Lumentum stock notched an all-time high on Thursday, while Finisar, Oclaro and NeoPhotonics all touched more than five-year highs. Acacia made its IPO in May and hit its record high on Sept. 7. The companies have helped drive IBD's 14-company Telecom-Fiber Optics industry group to No. 1 out of 197 groups tracked. The group reached a 15-year high on Sept. 7.Optics demand has surged as telecom companies like Verizon Communications (VZ) upgrade networks and internet firms such as Google and Facebook (FB) build new data centers packed with computer servers.U.S. optical parts makers and suppliers of system-level fiber-optics products, such as Ciena (CIEN), are far ahead of Chinese rivals in churning out faster communications products.IBD'S TAKE: The best stocks are often part of the best industry groups, which is why IBD ranks 197 industry groups by performance and goes deep on the weekly Industry Snapshot feature, including this one on the current No. 1 group, Telecom-Fiber Optics.U.S. companies are shipping optical transceivers and network switches that whisk data at 100 gigabits per second and are working on 400G products. At the low end of the market where Chinese suppliers operate, price competition is fierce for older, slower 10G and 40G products."With the exception of InnoLight, which is the only Chinese company capable of doing 100G, Chinese component suppliers are mainly focused on low-cost, low-speed datacom optics today, at 10 and 40 gigabit," Dmitry Netis, an analyst at William Blair & Co., told IBD. "Long-distance optics have not been an area of strength or particular know-how for Chinese component suppliers yet."Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google invested in InnoLight in 2014. Other Chinese component suppliers include Accelink, Eoptolink, Wuhan Weiyun Technology, and Huihong Technologies. While Apple has Chinese smartphone rival Xiaomi to contend with and HP battles Lenovo in laptops, there's no rising star in China's optical components industry. Huawei, which has emerged as a global supplier of telecom networking equipment, makes some optical components internally at subsidiary Hisense, but it's a big customer of U.S. optical suppliers.Troy Jensen, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, says it's more economical for U.S. companies to invest in the R&D needed to develop leading-edge 100G and 400G parts than it would be for Huawei, which would sell components mainly to itself. A company like Finisar sells components to Cisco, Ciena, Alcatel and many customers, he says."China is typically a product generation behind the pure-play optical guys," Jensen told IBD.U.S. companies usually manage to garner high profit margins for three or four years before comparable Chinese products hit the market, says Alex Henderson, an analyst at Needham & Co.China, though, has made it a priority to create a world-class semiconductor industry to reduce its reliance on foreign suppliers. China now produces about 20% of the chips it consumes in phones, appliances, TVs and other manufactured products locally, Citigroup said in a research report this month. An initiative called "Made in China 2025" aims to increase local chip production to as much as 70% by 2025.Already Huawei, dating back to 2013, acquired Belgium-based Caliopa to gain know-how in high-end silicon photonics.But while China's semiconductor industry has made great strides in wireless and other chip areas, the government hasn't prioritized fiber-optics technology as much.One reason could be that the semiconductor industry is much bigger than fiber optics and spans many more end-markets, says Henderson. He says some optical products use advanced materials that Chinese companies have not yet widely utilized.China's government may rethink its fiber-optics strategy, analysts say, in the wake of the U.S. Commerce Department briefly banning component sales to China smartphone maker ZTE earlier this year. The U.S. said ZTE broke export sanctions against Iran.The U.S. has since lifted its restrictions on component sales to ZTE, which is a customer of Acacia and other parts makers, but China might set it sights on ensuring a local supply of high-end optical devices in the future, says Needham's Henderson.For now, though, U.S. companies are positioned to take advantage of the current supercycle in the fiber-optics industry, analysts say, with China among their markets.The U.S. optics makers that do the most business in China are NeoPhotonics, Lumentum, Oclaro and Finisar, says Piper's Jensen. NeoPhotonics' customers include Huawei.Chinese telecom companies, just like U.S. carriers such as Verizon, are upgrading networks in metropolitan areas to 100G technology, Jensen says. Metro networks as well as data centers need more bandwidth to handle internet video, mobile broadband and business-driven data traffic.Chinese internet leaders Alibaba Holdings (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU) lag U.S. counterparts in upgrading data centers to 100G technology, but they are expected to pick up the pace over the next couple of years, says Vladimir Kozlov, CEO of LightCounting Market Research.He tells IBD that many Chinese component suppliers have focused on the residential and business broadband market, but companies like Eoptolink are making strides in 100G technology for telecom. The country, indeed, already has begun to focus optics, he says."There are more domestic suppliers," Kozlov said. "China's government has encouraged development of optics."

With about 98% of S&P 500 firms reporting results in a shortened week of Labor Day trading, the earnings calendar is a bit thin. Not to worry, though, because two solid names are near buy points ahead of their quarterly reports. HD Supply (HDS), a distributor of industrial and construction supplies, reports earnings Wednesday before the open. It's a candidate…

Chipmaker Intel (INTC) earned at least eight price-target increases for its stock after raising its current-quarter revenue guidance on improving PC sales on Friday.Also Friday, teardowns of Apple's (AAPL) new iPhone 7 handset revealed that Intel has scored the communications chip set in some models, replacing Qualcomm (QCOM).Intel stock, however, fell 1.4% to 37.16 at the close on the stock market today. Intel stock rose 3% and reached a more than 15-year high of 38.05 on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Intel stock is at longtime highs but ranks just No. 7 on IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group (which doesn't include fabless chipmakers). See which are the top-rated chip stocks, and why, at IBD Stock Checkup.Investment bank Jefferies raised its price target on Intel stock to 49 from 44 and kept its buy rating.Mizuho raised its price target on Intel to 42 from 38 and reiterated its buy rating.Needham upped its price target on Intel to 43 from 38 and kept its buy rating.Nomura raised its PT on Intel to 42 from 38 and maintained its buy rating.Pacific Crest Securities increased its PT on Intel to 42 from 38 and reiterated its overweight rating.Cowen maintained its market perform rating on Intel, but upped its price target to 38 from 36.UBS upped its price target on Intel to 43 from 40 and reiterated its buy rating.Baird raised its PT on Intel to 42 from 40 and kept its outperform rating.Early Friday, Intel said it expects third-quarter revenue of $15.3 billion to $15.9 billion vs. its prior range of $14.4 billion to $15.4 billion. The chip giant largely credited "replenishment of PC supply chain inventory" but also is "seeing some signs of improving PC demand."The midpoint of its Q3 sales guidance would be a 7.8% yearly gain, its best since Q3 2014.Intel's commentary on an improving PC business bodes well for PC makers HP Inc. (HPQ) and Apple, RBC Capital Markets said in a report Friday. Apple is expected to update its Mac computer lineup in October.UBS analyst Stephen Chin said PCs remain a driver for Intel's stock since the segment accounts for 53% of sales."One outstanding question is whether this was a one-time benefit (for Intel's Q3) or the result of better consumer interest in new products and replacement of older PCs," Chin said in a report.In addition to improving PC sales, Intel is likely to benefit from better performance in its data center chip business, Nomura analyst Romit Shah said in a report Friday."The Broadwell-E server refresh should drive stronger results in the second half of the year," Shah said. "A new server launch typically sees an (average selling price) uplift and strong unit demand."RELATED:Facebook Ad Fears 'Overblown'; Intel, Fiber-Optic Stocks Win Price Target HikesBroadcom, Cirrus Logic Get Lift From iPhone 7 Preorders

Not long after General Electric's (GE) announced its more-than-billion-dollar acquisition of European 3D printing companies Swedish Arcam and German SLM Solutions Group, it is plunking down some change in 3D printing startup Carbon.Carbon said Thursday that it had received a new funding round of $81 million from GE Ventures, BMW (BMWYY), Nikon and JSR, plus existing investors, for a funding total of $222 million.Carbon's claim to fame is the M1 machine, which, according to the company, can produce "3-dimensional isotropic parts with the mechanical properties and surface finish of a quality that matches injection-molded plastics."GV, formerly Google Ventures, led a $100 million funding round in the Redwood City, Calif.-based startup over a year ago. GV is the venture capital arm of Alphabet (GOOGL).Shares of General Electric fell 0.2% to 29.68 in the stock market today. GE is trading at its lowest levels since late June, below key moving averages.IBD'S TAKE: Shares of GE have been trading below their key 50-day moving average since August and recently undercut the 200-day line. For tips on deciphering charts, check out IBD University's "How To Read Stock Charts.""In today's digital world, additive manufacturing is changing how products are designed, made and serviced at GE," said GE Ventures' Senior Director of Advanced Manufacturing Steve Taub in a statement released by Carbon on Thursday."Carbon's CLIP technology can print exceptional quality parts for end-use production, opening the doors to incredible possibilities like low volume manufacturing, freedom of design, and mass customization."Despite GE's apparent hunger in the 3D realm, some analysts said recently that they don't expect GE or HP Inc. (HPQ) to make a play for 3D Systems (DDD) anytime soon.3D Systems up early, fell 1.3% as it works on a five-month consolidation. Stratasys (SSYS) retreated 1.45%.RELATED:3D Printer Maker 3D Systems Eyes 'Inflection Point' GE Buys European 3D Printing Firms, Lifting 3D Systems, StratasysGeneral Electric Or HP Takeover Of 3D Systems Seen Unlikely

Apple (AAPL) iPhone demand appears higher than conservative forecasts, giving Apple and the broader markets a lift. Wells Fargo (WFC) is still reeling from the major cross-selling fraud scandal. General Motors (GM) said its Chevy Bolt will have a higher battery range than the Tesla Motors (TSLA) Model 3, as Tesla and others gave autonomous vehicle updates. Two huge agribusiness mergers were announced.The major averages followed the Sept. 9 sell-off with several large and up-and-down days. Fed Gov. Lael Brainard's dovish comments Monday helped reassure investors that a September rate hike was highly unlikely. Meanwhile, Apple powered ahead on stronger-than-expected demand for its iPhone 7. Apple, which boasts the world's biggest market cap, is part of the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow industrials. The Nasdaq retook its 50-day line and rose 2.3% for the week. The S&P 500 and Dow, up 0.5% and 0.2%, respectively, remained below that key support level.Apple started selling its 10th-generation smartphone, the iPhone 7, on Friday along with its second-generation smartwatch, Apple Watch Series 2. AT&T (T), Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) said iPhone preorders were better than for last year's iPhone 6S, while Verizon (VZ) said they were in the normal range for an iPhone launch. Apple said it sold out its initial production run of iPhone 7 Plus and jet-black color iPhone 7 handsets. Samsung's recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones because of battery fires could help Apple gain smartphone market share, analysts said.Apple rose 11.4% to 114.92, its best weekly gain in years and blasting past a 110.33 buy point on Wednesday.August retail sales fell 0.3% and industrial production sank 0.4%, both worse than expected. But struggling apparel stores, groceries and restaurants reported higher sales. September's Philly Fed manufacturing index jumped far more than expected, while the New York Fed's Empire State index remaining negative. But the most important economic news may have come Monday, when Federal Gov. Lael Brainard signaled she would prefer to be cautious with rate hikes. That reinforced expectations that the central bank will take no action at this week's policy meeting.Wells Fargo shares continued to slide over the cross-selling fraud scandal, losing nearly 7% for the week. After paying a $195 million fine and firing 5,300 workers, Wells reportedly faces a federal criminal probe. The Senate Banking Committee is set to hold a hearing on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Deutsche Bank (DB) tumbled 9.4% Friday after the Justice Department said it wanted $14 billion to settle a probe into its mortgage securities from 2005-2007."Let's just raise rates," JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said during the week, following more bullish sentiment from Fed officials over a potential rate hike that would likely boost banks' finances. At the Barclays Global Financial Services conference, Bank of America (BAC) said Q3 investment banking had improved, while the quarter so far for Citigroup (C) appeared more mixed. Both touted their international prospects.Intel expects third-quarter revenue of $15.3 billion to $15.9 billion vs. its prior range of $14.4 billion to $15.4 billion. That's a 7.8% yearly gain at the midpoint, the best since Q3 2014. The chip giant largely credited "replenishment of PC supply chain inventory" but also is "seeing some signs of improving PC demand." Intel also raised gross margin targets. Intel shares rose 3% Friday, briefly hitting its highest levels since January 2001.Oil prices were on track to fall for the week as reports indicated that production is rising faster and demand increasing at a slower pace. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries released its monthly oil report Monday that production from nonmembers will increase by 200,000 barrels a day in 2017 vs. a prior outlook of a decline or 150,000 barrels per day in its August report. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said in its monthly report that global crude demand will only rise by 1.3 million barrels a day this year as Q3 demand slows at a faster pace than expected. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration reported a surprise 559,000 barrel drop in domestic crude stockpiles. But production rose by 0.4% to 8.493 million barrels per day. Also the IEA debuted its World Energy Investment report, which found that investment in the energy sector in 2015 fell 8% year-over-year to $1.8 trillion.General Motors' all-electric Chevrolet Bolt, due out this fall, will have an EPA-estimated 238 miles per charge, topping Tesla's promised range for its Model 3, which won't be out for another year. Tesla said its new Autopilot software upgrade would rely more on radars than cameras, an update that Musk says would've likely prevented a fatal crash; Mobileye (MBLY) said it split with Tesla over Autopilot safety issues. Ford (F) highlighted EV and self-driving development in its strategic plans. Uber rolled out a self-driving fleet in Pittsburgh made up of souped-up Ford Fusions.RELATED:Is GM's Chevy Bolt EV A Tesla Model 3 Party Pooper?Mobileye Rips Tesla Autopilot Safety As War Of Words IntensifiesFord Sees Self-Driving Cars Making Up 20% Of Sales By 2030Tesla Autopilot 8.0 Will Focus On Radar, Not CamerasTesla Wins Record Grid Battery Storage Deal After Methane DisasterIt was a busy week for mergers and acquisitions, with Bayer (BAYRY) reaching a deal to buy Monsanto (MON) while fertilizer makers Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Agrium (AGU) agreed to merge.After a series of raised bids, herbicide and seeds giant Monsanto finally accepted a $128-a-share takeover offer from Bayer. The $66 billion deal, including debt, also includes a $2 billion breakup fee in the event of antitrust objections. Monsanto shares fell more than 3% for the week to 103.45 amid speculation that regulators may block the deal.Fertilizer producers Potash and Agrium announced a merger in which Potash shareholders will receive 0.4 share and Agrium investors will receive 2.23 shares of the new company for each of their existing shares. The deal comes as farmers cut back amid weak crop prices. HP Inc. (HPQ) announced a $1.05 billion deal to buy the printer business of Samsung Electronics. Samsung has agreed to make a $100 million to $300 million equity investment in HP after the deal closes.Industrial gas giants Praxair (PX) and Germany's Linde broke off merger talks over the fate of Linde's Munich headquarters.RELATED:Bayer, Monsanto Agree On $66 Billion Deal; Investors DoubtfulOracle reported that fiscal Q1 earnings rose 4% to 55 cents while revenue climbed 2% to $8.6 billion, both below estimates. But Oracle's cloud business is booming: The business software giant said SaaS (software-as-a-service) and PaaS (platform-as-a-service) revenue rose 77% from the year-earlier quarter, to $798 million. Oracle guide Q3 EPS and sales views lower but sees cloud offerings up about 80%, above Wall Street targets. "The challenge for management is to deliver on its promises to get margins back up as cloud investments scale," said Jason Ader, a William Blair analyst.Oracle stock fell 4.8% on Friday, closing below its 200-day line for the first time in six months.Twitter began live streaming of the first of 10 Thursday night NFL games. On Wednesday, the struggling social network launched an app that lets Apple TV, Amazon (AMZN) TV and Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox get Twitter's live streaming video, including the NFL games, and other content. And as soon as Monday, the sacrosanct 140-character limit to tweets will get fudged. Reportedly, Twitter will exclude certain ancillary items from the character count, including photos and GIFs. Twitter stock rose 5.5% rising above its 10-week and 40-week moving averages.RELATED:Twitter Brings Its Live Video, Other Content To Apple, Amazon TV

Analysts don't see any near-term brightening of the picture for 3D Systems (DDD), after the 3D printer maker's Q&A at a trade show Monday.The 3D printer industry emerged with a flourish from 2009 to 2013, only to crash in the next couple of years when it turned out that industry hype — the printers make products out of plastics, metals and other materials — has gotten ahead of reality in both the industrial and consumer segments.Longer term, though, prospects remain bullish, so much so that HP Inc. (HPQ) and General Electric (GE) have recently entered the market, just another hurdle for 3D Systems and its longtime top rival, Stratasys (SSYS).IBD'S TAKE: For all its challenges, 3D Systems sports a good IBD Relative Strength Rating of 90, meaning it's performed in the top 10% of all stocks over the past year. And it gets good "green" ratings on three key metrics, along with bad "red" ratings on another three key metrics, as shown in IBD Stock Checkup.But those companies entered the market for a reason. 3D Systems' new CEO, Vyomesh Joshi, who joined this year after helping guide HP's printer business to the top — and other top executives, a number of whom also came from HP — said the company "is at an inflection point as the 3D printing industry transitions over the next three years from prototyping to production," Needham analyst James Ricchiuti related in a research note Tuesday.But Ricchiuti maintained a hold rating on 3D Systems stock, writing that executives "conceded that more work needs to be done in terms of meeting all of the major customer requirements (speed, durability, repeatability and total cost of ownership)."The company did not update its financial guidance in the session, held at the start of the International Manufacturing Technology Show in Chicago.In terms of financial guidance, CFO John McMullen, one of the former HP execs at 3D Systems, "suggested ... there is an opportunity for revenue and EPS growth in 2017," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg reported in a research note late Monday. But Twigg said "we think this should be a minimum goal post," and "we expect more aggressive goals to be rolled out through 2017 as operational improvements are accomplished."Pac Crest maintained its sector weight rating on 3D Systems, which has seen its year-over-year revenue fall in each of the past four quarters.3D Systems on Monday announced a collaboration with computer-aided design company PTC (PTC), with 3D Systems' technology integrated into PTC's CAD platform. Analysts quoted CEO Joshi as saying that collaborations, not acquisitions, will be the company's style, and as conceding that the company has done a poor job of integrating its acquisitions.3D Systems stock fell 2.1% in the stock market today, to 15.16, but it's still up nearly 75% for the year. PTC stock fell 1.1%, to 43.11.RELATED:3D Systems Takeover By GE Or HP Seen Unlikely3D Systems, Stratasys Building Bases

HP Inc. (HPQ) stock rebounded from early losses Thursday, a day after the PC and printer maker reported better-than-expected fiscal Q3 results but offered weak earnings guidance for the current quarter.HP shares closed down 0.2% to 14.37 on the stock market today, but they rebounded strongly from a morning sell-off to 13.55.Maxim Group downgraded HP stock to hold from buy and cut its price target to 15 from 17.Palo Alto, Calif.-based HP earned 48 cents a share excluding items, up 37% year over year, on sales of $11.89 billion, down 4%, in the quarter ended July 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 44 cents EPS and $11.46 billion in sales.For the current quarter, HP guided to non-GAAP earnings per share of 34 to 37 cents, when Wall Street was targeting 41 cents. The shortfall was attributed to changes in HP's printer and ink business. HP is reducing its printing supplies inventory and aggressively pricing printers to expand its installed base.IBD'S TAKE: Earnings time can be volatile for stocks. Investors looking to reduce risks at these times might want to consider investing in options, and can get help with options as part of IBD's weekly Earnings Preview feature."We believe management's decision to draw down printer supplies and increase product placement is the right decision for the long term," Wells Fargo analyst Maynard Um said in a research report. "However, the near-term impact is now being felt in fiscal Q4 as these actions are pressuring margins without any offsetting gains the company had in previous quarters."Benefits from its actions are not expected until the back half of fiscal 2017, which starts Nov. 1, Um said. He rates HP stock as market perform, with a valuation range of 13 to 14."These actions should create a nice set up for HP in the future — low supplies inventory and high installed base of printers that should be in need of supplies replacement," he said. "HP is sowing the right seeds, but we think it will take some time to bear fruit."HP's key challenge is to stabilize its high-margin printer supplies business, FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi said in a report. But the printer business is in secular decline and HP's printer hardware installed base is shrinking.Seyrafi reiterated his rating on HP stock of sector perform, with a price target of 13.RELATED:HP Stock Tumbles In Late Trading On Weak Earnings Outlook

HP Inc. (HPQ) late Wednesday beat Wall Street's targets for fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings, but its stock dropped in after-hours trading on weak guidance.HP stock was down 4.5% after hours, following the earnings news release. During the regular session Wednesday, HP dipped 1.2% to 14.40.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based PC and printer maker earned 48 cents a share excluding items, up 37% year over year, on sales of $11.89 billion, down 4%, in the quarter ended July 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 44 cents EPS and $11.46 billion in sales.For the current quarter, HP's fiscal Q4, the company guided to non-GAAP earnings per share of 34 to 37 cents. It did not give a revenue outlook. Wall Street had been modeling HP to earn 41 cents a share ex items on sales of $11.8 billion."While the July-quarter print is good (upside to sales and EPS), the much softer October quarter is driving the stock lower," RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a research note. It is "unclear what's leading to the downtick in EPS for October quarter but the concern would be it's printing driven, given PC results were actually positive."Personal computers accounted for 63% of HP's revenue in Q3, with printing making up the remaining 37%.But HP's printing business brought in 73% of profits in Q3, compared with 27% for the PC business."Although the markets remain challenged, we have the innovation and executional rigor needed to continue to take profitable share and invest in the right opportunities to drive long-term success for the company," HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement.Excluding foreign-exchange impact, HP's revenue was down 1% in constant currency in fiscal Q3.IBD'S TAKE: Earnings time can be volatile for stocks. Investors looking to reduce risks at these times might want to consider investing in options, and can get help with options as part of IBD's weekly Earnings Preview feature.It was HP's third quarterly report since it split from Hewlett-Packard. The rest of the original company became Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).HP is the global market share leader in computer printers and is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in personal computers. But printers and PCs are in secular decline as the rise of mobile devices has reduced the need for both categories.HP is broadening its reach into corporate copying-and-printing systems as well as 3D printers. In PCs, it is innovating with premium machines for gamers and power users, including the Omen gaming desktop and Spectre laptop.RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PC Shipments; Apple Slips

Workday (WDAY), HP Inc. (HPQ) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) gave weak guidance, while Heico (HEI) and PVH (PVH)  reported mixed quarterly results late Wednesday.Estimates: Q2 loss of 2 cents a share vs. 2 cent profit a year earlier. Revenue up 32% to $372.68 million.Results: Adjusted per-share loss of 4 cents on revenue of $377.3 million.Outlook: Q3 revenue of $398 million-$400 million vs. consensus for $401 million.Stock: Shares jumped 7% after hours on the stock market today. The shares are finding support at the 50-day moving average.Workday is a maker of cloud-based software for human relations, payroll and other business functions.RELATED:Workday Downgraded On Concerns Over Q2 Billings Ahead Of EarningsWorkday Push Into Financial Tools On Radar As Earnings On TapEstimates: Fiscal Q3 EPS of 48 cents on $11.46 billion revenue. No comps are available for HP Inc. due to its split with enterprise cloud-enabled services company Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) in November.Results: Adjusted EPS from continuing operations of 48 cents on revenue of $11.9 billion.Outlook: Q4 EPS from continuing operations of 34-37 cents vs. consensus for 41 cents.Stock: HP dropped 4.5% late.In addition to printers and PCs, HP sells scanners, servers and storage devices.IBD'S TAKE: Facebook and Google parent Alphabet are among 5 top techs that reported strong earnings.Estimates: Q2 EPS of 59 cents, up 16%. Revenue up 19% to $356.34 million. Results: EPS of 62 cents on sales of $356.1 million.Outlook: Full-year net income seen up 13%-15%, up from prior view of 12%-14%.Stock:  Heico shares closed up 1.2% at 74.24, below a record high of 74.66 set Tuesday, and rallied another 1.2% after hours.Heico is a maker of jet engine and aircraft parts and systems for the aerospace and defense markets.Estimates: Flat Q2 earnings at 58 cents a share. Sales up 3.5% to $1.167 billion.Results: EPS of 58 cents on revenue of $1.16 billion.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 75-80 cents on revenue of $1.235 billion-$1.285 billion. Analysts see EPS of 81 cents and revenue of $1.285 billion.Stock: Williams-Sonoma fell 0.3% late. The stock has been in a downtrend, unable to close above its 200-day moving average for the past year.Williams-Sonoma operates home furnishings stores under its namesake brand, as well as Pottery Barn and other labels.Estimates: Q2 EPS down 6% to $1.29, as revenue rises 3.8% to $1.94 billion.Results: EPS of $1.47 on revenue of $1.93 billion.Outlook: Q3 EPS of $2.35-$2.40 vs. consensus for $2.39. Full-year EPS seen at $6.55-$6.60, vs. consensus for $6.54, with revenue seen up 2%.Stock: PVH rose 1.1% late.PVH makes apparel, including Tommy Hilfiger, Calvin Klein and Heritage brands.

Stocks opened lower, but clawed their way back to even in Thursday morning trade after the market sought to stabilize after a day of heavy selling.The three major indexes were all fractionally higher in late morning action, but all essentially flat. Volume was tracking slightly lower than at the same time Thursday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges in the stock market today.Dollar Tree (DLTR) was trimmed nearly 7% after missing on earnings and sales. It reported 73 cents a share compared to 25 cents a year earlier, but that was a penny short of the Wall Street consensus estimate. Revenue came in at $5 billion, 66% better than a year ago, but shy of estimates of $5.1 billion. Same-store sales rose 2.7%.IBD'S TAKE: Dollar Tree and Dollar General are tumbling. But fellow specialty discount Ollie's Bargain Outlet is looking better ahead of its earnings next week. Check out this IBD Stock Analysis of Ollie's Bargain Outlet.Dollar General (DG) fell 13%. It reported EPS of $1.08, 14 cents better than a year ago, but also a penny short of estimates. Sales came in at $5.39 billion, 6% better than a year earlier but missing estimates of $5.5 billion.Five Below (FIVE) dropped as much as 6% in the opening minutes, but roared its way back to just a 1% drop.HP (HPQ), gapped down early but recovered to a 1% loss as well. It beat on earnings and sales, but offered guidance below the Street.Signet Jewelers (SIG) fell 14% after reporting weak sales and amid concern about the quality of its stones. But Tiffany (TIF) gapped up and was trading 7% higher after it beat estimates.RELATED:Signet Slashes Outlook, Cites Energy Slump; Tiffany SparklesDollar General, Dollar Tree Miss; Medtronic EPS Tops; Burlington Beats

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Earnings reports from Workday (WDAY), HP Inc. (HPQ), Heico (HEI) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) are slated for after the market close, existing-home sales from the National Association of Realtors are due out, and Facebook (FB) and Lockheed Martin (LMT) could flash important stock…

With worldwide sales of personal computers and printers in decline, HP Inc. (HPQ) faces a tough road ahead.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company has seen sales fall on a year-over-year basis for seven straight quarters. Earnings growth has been hard to find as well.HP will get its next test on Wednesday, when it is scheduled to report fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close. It will be the company's third quarterly report since it split from Hewlett-Packard. The rest of the original company became Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).IBD'S TAKE: HP Inc. ranks No. 4 out of 15 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware and Peripherals group. But HP has a low IBD Composite Rating of 41. The top-ranked company in the group, Logitech International, has a Composite Rating of 91. For more details on Logitech, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to earn 44 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $11.44 billion, for the quarter ended July 31.For the current quarter, Wall Street is looking for HP to earn 41 cents a share excluding items on sales of $11.8 billion.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani on Monday reiterated his sector perform rating on HP, but raised his price target to 14 from 12. HP stock fell a fraction, to 14.37, on the stock market today."Heading into the July-quarter print, we think HPQ will report in-line to slightly positive results based on improved PC demand vs. the April quarter and a de-risked outlook for printing," Daryanani said.Market research firm IDC last month said HP's calendar second-quarter PC shipments rose 5.1% year over year, while the total market saw a 4.5% decline. HP is the world's No. 2 PC vendor in unit shipments behind Lenovo.Investor focus will be on HP's printer business, where the company gets about 80% of its profit, UBS analyst Steven Milunovich said in a research report last week.Rivals Xerox (XRX), Lexmark (LXK) and Canon (CAJ) have reported weak results but moderating rates of decline in hardware and supplies, he said.RELATED:HP Gains On Lenovo In PC Shipments; Apple SlipsApple Planning First Major MacBook Pro Upgrade In Over 4 Years

Stocks drifted lower amid rate hike concerns. Apple (AAPL) unveiled the new iPhone 7 and Apple Watch 2, but the modest upgrades failed to wow. Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and other grocery stores are reeling from lower food prices while airlines rallied on capacity plans from Delta Air Lines (DAL) and others. and fiber-optic results remained hot. A slew of M&A activity took place.Apple introduced its 10th-generation smartphone, the iPhone 7, and second-generation smartwatch, Apple Watch Series 2, at a media event on Wednesday. Both products are incremental upgrades to current-generation models. The iPhone 7 is waterproof to a degree, has advanced cameras and sports better battery life than the iPhone 6S series handsets. The Apple Watch 2 is "swim proof," has more health and fitness features, and includes built-in GPS and a brighter display. Apple also introduced a lineup of wireless earbuds and headphones. Nintendo (NTDOY) shares skyrocketed on news that it will bring games to the iPhone, iPad and Apple Watch.Apple shares fell 4.3% for the week as of Friday's close. The stock, which had been nearing a buy point, is testing its 50-day line again.RELATED:What Investors Loved, Hated About Apple iPhone 7 EventApple iPhone 7 Preorders Begin With Jet Black Model ShortagesApple Debuts Fitness-Centric Apple Watch Series 2 With 'Pokemon Go'The Nasdaq hit record highs early in the shortened week, but are down modestly for the week amid Fed rate hike concerns and after news of a North Korea nuclear test. The Dow and S&P 500 fell below their 50-day moving averages, but that's largely due to the support line catching up to the market's sideways action. Energy, fiber-optic, airline and biotech groups rallied, while grocery and retail groups struggled.Sprouts Farmers Market, SuperValu (SVU) and Kroger (KR) all cut full-year guidance as lower food prices slam grocery stores. Lower meat costs and broader price-trimming efforts by Wal-Mart are among the reasons for the food deflation. Food-stamp cuts also are hurting some grocers. Sprouts stock crashed 13,7% by week's end. SuperValu lost 17.3% and Kroger fell 3.1%. Retail groups sold off generally.RELATED:Fast Food Prices Have Never Risen So Fast Vs. Eating In CostsShares of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got a bump this week after activist investor Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital disclosed a 9.9% stake in Chipotle. Pershing Square, in an SEC filing, said the Mexican-food fast-casual chain had a "strong brand" and "visionary leadership," and that its stock is "undervalued and is an attractive investment." The hedge fund also said it planned to "engage in discussions" with Chipotle over its business and direction. The disclosure comes as Chipotle tries to revive sales and customer loyalty after a foodborne-illness scare. Chipotle shares rose more than 4% for the week by Friday's close.IBD'S TAKE: The grocery price wars are adding to pressure on restaurants, which face soaring labor costs. But pizza stocks have been standouts. Papa's Johns is near a buy point as it expands to Mexico.Oil prices rallied as the Energy Information Administration said U.S. crude stockpiles fell by 14.5 million barrels, the largest weekly draw since 1999, but came as refineries on the Gulf were closed during Hurricane Hermine. Analysts expected a 200,000-barrel increase. The EIA is also using different methodology for calculating the data.EOG (EOG) announced Tuesday that it would purchase privately held Yates Petroleum for $2.5 billion to expand its presence in the Permian Basin in West Texas. Apache (APA) raised its 2016 capex budget by $200 million to $2 billion to explore its Alpine High discovery that's estimated to hold billions of barrels of oil.Enbridge (ENB) agreed to buy rival pipeline operator Spectra Energy (SE) for $28 billion in stock.Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to pay $185 million in fines to regulators over claims bank employees had improperly created accounts in the names of customers in order to satisfy sales quotas and reap bonuses.Wells Fargo fired 5,300 employees after the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau alleged those workers opened more than 2 million accounts on behalf of existing customers without their knowledge. Prosecutors say those customers were charged fees for accounts they never ordered.Wells Fargo said it agreed to resolve the accusations without admitting or denying wrongdoing. It also set aside $5 million for customer remediation.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) confirmed that it would spin off its software business, merging it with London's Micro Focus. In May, HPE announced it would spin off its services unit to Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) Meanwhile, HPE also reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings, but revenue fell 6%, lagging views. HPE fell 4% for the week so far.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprises Keeps Slimming, But Where's The Beef?Finisar (FNSR) late Thursday posted fiscal Q1 earnings and gave Q2 guidance that handily beat Wall Street views. Meanwhile, smaller Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) hiked its Q3 outlook. Finisar stock leapt nearly 13% Friday and more than 17% for the week, hitting a 2-year high. Applied Opto, whose largest customer is Amazon (AMZN), climbed 16% so far this week, hitting a 10-month high. Telecom-Fiber Optics continues to rank as the No. 1 group. Analysts are using the term "supercycle" to refer to the big upgrade taking place to 100 gigabit-per-second, super-fast broadband networks, to accommodate video, the Internet of Things and more. Upgrading are telecom and cable broadband providers, but also the big cloud services and internet companies, as well as China. And this current cycle might last more than the usual two to three years, analysts say.RELATED:Finisar 'Stars Aligned' As Hot Fiber Optics Supercycle Keeps CyclingDelta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines (LUV) pared their flight-capacity growth forecasts, helping boost carrier stocks. Delta also said that it expects fuel costs to rise year-over-year in the fourth quarter, potentially boosting airfare and improving long-declining unit revenue as airlines pass those costs onto passengers. Cheap oil last year made it easy for airlines to expand and compete, helping drive down unit revenue in the process.Meanwhile, the breakout of Hawaiian Airlines parent Hawaiian Holdings (HA) was rerouted as shares fell nearly 4% on Friday, creating a 1% loss for the week. Skywest (SKYW) rose near the top of a consolidation for the week but was down Friday. Also, Panama's Copa Airlines (CPA) broke out, up nearly 8% for the week.RELATED:Delta, Southwest Capacity Plans Lift Airlines; Hawaiian Air Extends BreakoutGeneral Electric (GE) is buying Sweden's Arcam and Germany's SLM Solutions Group, suppliers of metal additive 3D manufacturing machines. But Pacific Crest says a GE or HP (HPQ) bid for 3D Systems (DDD) isn't likely. Volkswagen (VLKAY) is plunking down $256 million for a 16.6% stake in heavy-truck maker Navistar International (NAV). Diagnostics firm Cepheid (CPHD) is getting picked up by Danaher (DHR) in a $4 billion deal. Intel (INTC) is selling a 51% stake in security unit McAfee to TPG.RELATED:GE Buys European 3D Printing Firms, Lifting 3D Systems, StratasysVolkswagen To Buy Stake In Heavy-Truck Maker NavistarDanaher Buying Cepheid To Expand Diagnostics BusinessIntel To Sell 51% Of McAfee Security Unit To TPG

With its confirmation late Wednesday that it will spin off its software business, this following the pending sales of its services business to Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is ... what?The company that's left says it will be a more focused rival in today's enterprise "hybrid" cloud and on-premises computing world to Dell/EMC, IBM (IBM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), but investors and analysts aren't quite sure what to make of things as they have quickly evolved."The stock has performed well on an aggressive share repurchase program and the projected incoming cash and stock from the two deals, but we do not see this as sustainable without consistent results for the remaining Enterprise Group business units," Alex Kurtz, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research note late Wednesday. "Shares have outperformed on aggressive capital allocation plans, but there are no signs of demand stabilization."Pac Crest rates HPE stock sector weight, or neutral. Needham is maintaining its buy rating, but it's not particularly tied to actual business performance.IBD'S TAKE: Big companies can make big stock moves, while avoiding much of the volatility of smaller companies. Check out the IBD Big Cap 20 for the big companies that currently are performing the best."The company has become adept at pivoting, splitting and divesting as necessary to extract shareholder value out of a business that plus or minus a point is basically not growing," Needham analyst Richard Kugele wrote in a research report Thursday. "That said, we believe the value extracted from the spin-merger of the software business with Micro Focus adds at least $2 in value for shareholders to our previous $22 price target (now $24) and on that basis warrants a reiteration of our buy rating."UBS analyst Steven Milunovich also maintained a buy, but with a caveat. While he said in a research note that the recent deals benefit current shareholders, "the question when the dust settles is whether HPE will win as a more agile hybrid infrastructure vendor or have difficulty competing with larger Cisco and Dell with greater software and services assets."Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended Thursday trading down 3.2% to 21.38 on the stock market today. The stock hit a record high of 22.32 on Sept. 1.Late Wednesday, HPE confirmed earlier reports that it would spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International, as one of Silicon Valley's true pioneering companies continues to restructure and focus on the rise of cloud computing.HPE will receive $2.5 billion in cash and Micro Focus stock valued at $6.3 billion at the time of the announcement. U.K.-based Micro Focus is traded on the London exchange. HPE shareholders will own 50.1% of the new company, which is expected to generate about $4.5 billion in annual revenue, more than $3 billion from the HPE side.In May, HPE announced the sale of its services business to Computer Sciences, with HPE shareholders owning about half of a company valued near $8 billion. This deal is expected to close in Q1 2017 and the Micro Focus deal in the second half of 2017.In announcing the Micro Focus deal, HPE said "the move enables a stand-alone HPE to realize its vision of being the industry's leading provider of hybrid IT, built on the secure, next-generation, software-defined infrastructure that will run customers' data centers today, bridge them to multicloud environments tomorrow, and enable the emerging intelligent edge that will power campus, branch and IoT applications for decades to come."It was only in November that venerable Silicon Valley stalwart Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and HP Inc. (HPQ) to focus on PCs and printers.Also late Wednesday, HPE announced mixed results for its fiscal Q3 ended July 31. Earnings per share minus items of 49 cents topped Wall Street views for 44 cents, but revenue fell 6% year over year to $12.2 billion, where analysts had expected $12.6 billion. In constant currency, servers fell 2% and storage fell 5%, though the networking unit rose 10%.HPE CEO Meg Whitman is trying to create a company better able to compete with Dell Technologies, following its just-completed acquisition of EMC, as well Cisco and IBM, as large companies shift spending to cloud computing services.But Pac Crest's Kurtz said HPE still needs to show it can "buck industrywide secular headwinds facing on-premise hardware vendors and if HPE can establish share as a provider in new growth categories like hyper-converged appliances."RELATED:Cisco Systems Should Get Into The Chip BusinessHP Inc. Stock Rebounds From Weak Guidance

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) will spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International, continuing a restructuring of one of Silicon Valley's venerable companies amid the rise of cloud computing.HPE said it will receive $2.5 billion in cash and its shareholders will own 50.1% of the new company.HPE late Wednesday also said fiscal Q3 non-GAAP earnings rose 9% in the three months ended July 31 to 49 cents per share, topping estimates. Revenue fell 6% to $12.2 billion, missing views. Analysts had projected 44 cents and $12.6 billion.HPE stock was down more than 1% in after-hours trading Wednesday, following its earnings and spinoff release. Shares rose 1.1% in the regular session in the stock market today, at 22.09.Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies last November. It formed Hewlett Packard Enterprise to focus on services and products for businesses and other enterprises, and printer/PC maker HP Inc. (HPQ). HPE in May announced plans to spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC)HPE had reportedly been in talks with private equity firms over the software business before Micro Focus surfaced as the buyer.HPW will still sell networking, data storage and servers to corporate customers. Analysts say CEO Meg Whitman aims to better position the company vs. Dell Technologies, following its just-completed acquisition of EMC, as large companies shift spending to cloud computing services. Companies are spending less on their own data centers, pressuring IT suppliers like HPE and IBM."We are taking another important step in achieving the vision of creating a faster-growing, higher-margin, stronger cash flow company well positioned for our customers and for the future," said CEO Meg Whitman, in a statement.IBD'S TAKE: HPE stock hit an all-time high last week amid speculation over a company breakup. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.For the current quarter, HPE estimated non-GAAP EPS of 58 cents to 63 cents, in line with consensus estimates of 60 cents.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Price Target Hiked; Breakup Scenario?

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day.Apple (AAPL) and Sony (SNE) are each hosting a major announcement event; Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Guidewire (GWRE) are slated to report quarterly earnings; and the Beige Book and Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) are due.The frenzy begins at 10 a.m. PT in San Francisco. People are awaiting the iPhone 7, of course, which is rumored to come with several revamped features: No traditional headphone jack, a new "Space Black" color and a waterproof design, among other things. The anticipated changes are said to be incremental, with many expecting a more impressive overhaul next year when the iPhone turns 10. Apple Watch and Mac announcements are also foreseen on Wednesday.The iPad and iPhone maker has been said to be losing smartphone profit share to Samsung, although the unfortunate timing of the Galaxy Note 7's battery issues -- i.e. they're reportedly bursting into flames -- is a "lucky break" for Apple.In stock news, Apple's 50-day line and 200-day line are converging -- a sign that short-term performance is improving. But shares have only risen a little over 2% this calendar year, underperforming the S&P 500's year-to-date gains of about 6%. Still, Apple has a buy point of 110.33.Apple dipped 5 cents to close at 107.68 on the stock market today.RELATED:Apple iPhone 7 Leaks Point To Waterproofing, New Colors, Better CamerasApple Finally Shapes A Buy Point; Watch Broadcom, Activision Apple's Smartphone Profit Share Slipping Vs. SamsungApple Schedules Sept. 7 Event For iPhone 7 RevealA little later on Wednesday at 3 p.m. ET on the other coast, Sony is expected to roll out the PlayStation "Neo," the latest edition of its gaming console. Expect both a standard and higher-end version of the new PlayStation 4, according to the Wall Street Journal.Rival console maker and Xbox parent Microsoft (MSFT) announced in June the holiday 2017 arrival of Project Scorpio, calling it "the most powerful console ever built."Shares of Sony have been trading steadily above their 50-day line. Sony shares rose 2.7% to close at 33.52 Tuesday, close to a 5-year high of 33.70 set on Aug. 26.RELATED:Why Microsoft's Project Scorpio Is A 'Game Changer'  Microsoft Confirms 'Project Scorpio' After LinkedIn BuyIBD'S TAKE: Can't figure out what to buy, and when? IBD University has plenty of investing tools, including How To Find And Evaluate Stocks.The tech company, which split off from its hardware counterpart late last year, reports after the close on Wednesday.Wall Street is projecting earnings of 44 cents on revenue of $12.64 billion.Hewlett Packard Enterprise is said to be selling off its software division, just a few months after it announced that it was spinning off and merging its Enterprise Services business with Computer Sciences (CSC).HPE shares fell 1.6% to close at 21.86 Tuesday. HP Inc. (HPQ) shares rose 1% to 14.63.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Q3 Earnings Overshadowed By Deal TalkGuidewire also reports after the close that day, with analysts forecasting per-share profit of 32 cents, a 9% year-over-year dip, on 8% revenue growth to $136.1 million.Shares rose 0.8% to 63.52 at the close. The stock has found support at the 50-day line and has a buy point of 64.10.Ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting later this month -- aka Will The Fed Hike Rates In September? Maybe! But Probably Not! -- look for the sixth Beige Book of the calendar year (there are eight such reports on an annual basis). The report contains anecdotal data on employment, consumer spending, manufacturing and other economic conditions, collected from the 12 Federal Reserve Districts.Also look for the monthly JOLTS survey, which highlights job openings and turnover for the month of July.
