3D Systems (DDD) was handed a downgraded Tuesday while General Electric (GE) and Perrigo (PRGO) got their price targets cut and Walt Disney (DIS) received a price target raise.3D Systems is now a hold in Needham's book, down from buy. Earlier in the month, Citigroup deemed it "highly unlikely" that HP Inc. (HPQ) would acquire the 3D printing company, and downgraded 3D Systems to sell.Shares of 3D Systems closed down 1.85% on the stock market today.General Electric got a price-target haircut from Stifel, to 34 from 36 with a buy rating, a day after getting a PT bump from RBC to 35 from 33. GE, which is amid a transition to becoming a "digital industrial" company, came out ahead of Street forecasts when it reported Friday.GE shares edged up 0.7%.Nomura upped its price target on Disney to 115 from 110. The media conglomerate has two top-performing movies out in theaters, led by "The Jungle Book" in the No. 1 spot for the past two weeks, and "Zootopia" at the No. 4 spot after the weekend, according to Box Office Mojo.Disney shares added 0.3%.RBC slashed Perrigo's price target to 109 from 140 with a sector perform rating. Preliminary Q1 results missed as its CEO is leaving for Valeant.Perrigo shares finished 0.15% higher after sinking 18% Monday.Wunderlich boosted Palo Alto Networks (PANW) to buy from hold, less than a week after Morgan Stanley bumped up its price target on the stock to 185 from 171 with an overweight rating. The cybersecurity vendor is outperforming its peers among resellers and distributors, according to a recent Piper Jaffray survey.Palo Alto rose 0.2%.

3D printer stocks 3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS) skyrocketed Thursday after Bank of America/Merrill Lynch went from bear to bull on 3D.3D Systems jumped 10.1% to 18.12 on the stock market today, after hitting a nine-month high of 19.76 in the morning. Stratasys rose 5.9% to 29.35, breaking out of a base going back to late October.Bank of America gave 3D Systems a "double upgrade," raising it to a buy all the way from underperform. It hiked its price target from 11 to 26.Why the sudden switch from bear to bull? BofA sees new CEO Vyomesh Joshi fueling a turnaround. Joshi had worked for HP Inc. (HPQ), running HP's printing business. BofA sees Joshi improving profit margins by going after 3D's "bloated cost structure.""The past several years of our negative stance have been predicated on the company's poor M&A strategy, choice of assets that did not have complete exposure to 3D printing, increasing investments in low margin areas like consumer (now exiting part of low end consumer) and an aggressive investment and channel strategy that led to a bloated cost structure and revenue headwinds," BofA analysts wrote.BofA raised 3D EPS targets for 2016 by 2 cents to 30 cents, 2017 EPS revised up by 18 cents to 57 cents and 2018 EPS revised up to 71 cents from 43 cents.Smaller 3D printer makers ExOne (XONE) and Voxeljet (VJET) also rallied Thursday. ExOne jumped 7.6% to their best level since April 2015. Voxeljet climbed 8.6%.Related:3D Printers Gaining Traction With Nike, Boeing HP Inc.

Highly rated small cap Super Micro Computer (SMCI) lowered its third-quarter estimates after the close Thursday and then watched its stock crash Friday.Super Micro stock plunged 20% in the stock market today, to 26.79. The stock had made a breakout at 33.89 from a cup-with-handle base, but that breakout has now failed.Scheduled to announce Q3 earnings after the close April 28, Super Micro founder and CEO Charles Liang said late Thursday in a preannouncement that the quarter ended March 31 turned out "weaker than forecast due to weaker demand with some large customers and the channel than we anticipated. January and February were particularly soft, while March showed improved momentum. Storage and data center continued to grow."Except for the reference to March, there was "little detail on going-forward expectations," Needham analyst Richard Kugele said in a Thursday research note. "We see great risk to the company's goal of 20%-plus annual revenue growth and expect the stock will return to the penalty box, at least until further clarity is provided on the April 28 call."IBD's Take: Super Micro had been hot, but a breakout failed. How does the stock stack up? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupKugele, though, said he still likes the company in the long term and that it's outpacing the broader server/storage market. He reiterated his buy rating and 36 price target on Super Micro.Super Micro said Q3 revenue will come in at $530 million to $533 million instead of $530 million to $580 million. It now sees non-GAAP EPS of 33 cents to 35 cents vs. earlier guidance of 43 cents to 53 cents. Wall Street consensus had been 49 cents minus items, up 4% from the year-earlier quarter, and sales of $557 million, up 18%, Kugele said. Thomson Reuters on Friday cited consensus of six analysts on non-GAAP EPS of 46 cents and of seven analysts on revenue of $552 million.The preannouncement offered no guidance. Thomson Reuters put consensus on the current fiscal Q4 EPS minus items at 66 cents on revenue of $650 million vs. 57 cents on $574 million a year earlier.With an IBD Composite Rating of 98, Super Micro Computer had ranked as the best among all members of IBD's Computer-Hardware/Peripherals industry group. But its CR has now fallen all the way to 81. It's also one of the smallest, with a market cap of $1.35 billion. The largest, Canon (CAJ), with a $32.6 billion market cap, carries a 34 CR, followed by newly reorganized HP Inc. (HPQ), with a $21.8 billion market value and a 46 CR.Canon stock was down a fraction intradayFriday, while HP stock was up a fraction.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The stock charts of 3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS), the two largest U.S. providers of 3D printers, do not paint a picture of success. But despite the long declines, the 3D printing industry is stronger than it seems, say industry analysts who track the field. As a group, the Machinery-Material Handling and Automation group that houses the stocks has…

The entry of HP Inc. (HPQ) into the 3D printer market is seen as creating problems for 3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS), causing an analyst to issue a warning about the two market leaders.While 3D Systems and Stratasys are the two largest providers of 3D printers, HP (formerly Hewlett-Packard before its split) will gain market share over time, wrote UBS analyst Steven Milunovich in a research note. He reiterated a sell rating on Stratasys with a price target of 19. UBS also has a sell rating on 3D Systems and a price target of 9.Stratasys stock was up almost 3%, near 26, during afternoon trading in the stock market today. 3D Systems was near 15, down a fraction.The stocks of 3D Systems and Stratasys, having collapsed over the past two years due to numerous problems, are up sharply since recently hitting bottom. Despite the improvement and expectations of a turnaround, Milunovich believes that HP will be a disruptor. He says that HP expects to formally announce its first product in a few months, with availability by year end.“We expect HP to discuss betas with large industrial companies and provide impressive performance metrics,” Milunovich wrote. He also said, “(HP) indicates little interest in acquiring either Stratasys or 3D Systems, which surprises us."He believes that HP could gain broader technology, patents, channels and, with 3D Systems, metals capability, via an acquisition of one or the other.HP has also said that it plans to avoid the consumer market, where 3D Systems and Stratasys have flailed.3D printer revenue, including supplies, is expected to top $7 billion this year and approach $10 billion by 2017. Despite the struggles of 3D Systems and Stratasys, the 3D printing industry is stronger than it seems, say industry analysts who track the field. Among companies with big investments in 3D technology are Nike (NKE) and General Electric (GE). Nike has used 3D printers to develop several sport shoes, while General Electric uses them to produce advanced jet-engine fuel nozzles.

Personal computer and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) late Wednesday delivered in-line sales and earnings for its fiscal first quarter of 2016, but the midpoint of its EPS guidance for fiscal Q2 was below Wall Street's target.HP stock rose a fraction in after-hours trading following the earnings news release. During the regular session Wednesday, HP climbed nearly 5% to 10.82.HP earned 36 cents a share excluding items on sales of $12.2 billion in the quarter ended Jan. 31. On a year-over-year basis, EPS and sales each dropped 12%. On a constant currency basis, factoring out foreign exchange impact, sales slid 5%.For the current quarter, HP expects non-GAAP earnings per share of 35 to 40 cents, or 37.5 cents at the midpoint. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been modeling for HP to earn 39 cents a share ex items on sales of $11.94 billion in its fiscal second quarter. HP did not give a Q2 sales forecast.HP also reiterated its fiscal 2016 EPS guidance of $1.59 to $1.69 on a non-GAAP basis. Analysts have been targeting $1.60 EPS for the full year.PC and printer sales are mired in a prolonged slump. HP is the No. 2 maker of PCs worldwide with 19.9% market share by unit shipments in the fourth quarter, according to research firm IDC. Lenovo is No. 1 with 21.4% market share, IDC says.“We have a clear strategy that leverages our strengths, and we are focused on execution, taking cost out of the business and delivering innovations that will amaze our customers and partners,” HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement. “Although we have some tough quarters ahead, I am confident in the future.”

This week marked an important anniversary: The current bull market is now seven years old. That's many, many moons of watching stock indexes march higher and pocketing sizable returns on your hard-earned investments.Caution returned to the market in 2015, as the S&P 500 started to trade sideways. Stocks are taking a bit of a breather this year too. Perhaps you're in need of one too.So take a moment to catch up on ETF winners of the current bull market. As the table below shows, they span a host of asset classes, from financials and preferred stocks to retail and midcaps.The very top performer out of 1,646 nonleveraged ETFs is -- are you ready for this? -- Guggenheim S&P 500 Pure Value (RPV), an ETF that targets the cheapest third of the S&P 500 index.A bull market brings to mind higher beta positions, with a stronger growth skew. Yet in the past seven years, the market has rewarded value-oriented characteristics slightly more so than growth, said Guggenheim managing director William Belden. That's helped RPV outperform.Value ETFs are generally considered to perform well over longer periods of time. "Their greatest appeal is when the markets have gone both ways," Belden said.A closer look at RPV may be timely, as the market seems to have arrived at an inflection point for value stocks.RPV produced an average annual 30% return from March 10, 2009, to March 9, 2016. By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) gained an annualized 19% over the same period.SPY was also outpaced by Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP), with an annual average return of 22.4%.For investors seeking to make a style-focused bet on the markets, six Guggenheim ETFs offer style purity. They invest in only those stocks in the S&P 500, S&P MidCap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600 with the strongest value and growth characteristics.Traditional cap-weighted growth or value indexes generally have some overlap between growth and value stocks.Guggenheim's "Pure Style ETFs" avoid the muddle in the middle, as Belden likes to say. They also weight stocks by the strength of their growth or value characteristics.With $693.9 million in assets, RPV holds a mere 111 stocks from the S&P 500. They're selected based on metrics such as price-to-book, price-to-sales and price-to-earnings ratios.Top holdings now include electricity supplier NRG Energy (NRG), tech business HP Inc. (HPQ) and seeds processor Archer Daniels Midland (ADM).Morningstar analyst Alex Bryan cautions that this is a risky ETF investing strategy."The S&P 500 Pure Value Index was about 47% more volatile than the market-cap-weighted S&P 500 Value Index, which tracks the cheaper half of the S&P 500, during the past decade," he wrote in October 2015. "It has also tended to underperform during market downturns."Belden points out RPV has rewarded investors willing to take on a little higher volatility."It has a good risk-adjusted profile," he said. The expense ratio is 0.35%.Most investors tend to combine RPV with an S&P 500 ETF such as SPY to overweight value stocks. But RPV can also be combined with its sibling Guggenheim S&P 500 Pure Growth (RPG) for broad and well-diversified exposure to large-cap stocks.Growth investing and value investing are generally seen as being in favor in alternating periods. But the "Pure Growth" and "Pure Value" strategies have the potential to outperform at the same time, according to Guggenheim."The combination of both might be an attractive core position as opposed to one that's more tactically oriented," Belden said.It's worth noting that all six Guggenheim's "Pure Style" ETFs ranked in the 100 top-performing nonleveraged ETFs in this current bull market.Image at top provided by Shutterstock.

In the breakup of Hewlett-Packard, investors on Monday showed more love for the stodgy, slow-growth PC and printer business, rather than for the supposedly more attractive enterprise technology business.Shares of HP Inc. (HPQ), the personal computer and printer maker, were up more than 13% to near 14 in the stock market today. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock opened at 14.99 and was a fraction lower in afternoon trading.HP garnered several upbeat analyst reports post-split.Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 19. He called HP a "worthy annuity.""HP Inc. has a solid franchise and a multifaceted strategy to offset secular pressures in the printing and PC end markets," Garcha said in a report Monday. HP has "an extremely inexpensive valuation and significant cash return" potential.HP also is on track to improve the profitability of its printer unit by maximizing ink sales and expanding its commercial printer business, he said.S&P Capital IQ analyst Angelo Zino reiterated a strong buy rating on HP stock.Needham analyst Richard Kugele initiated coverage of HP with a buy rating and 14.50 price target.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani was more cautious on HP and its spinoff. He reiterated a sector perform rating on HP post-split and set a price target of 13.HP has "an attractive valuation and 4%+ dividend yield offset by secular challenges in printing and PC markets," Daryanani said in a report Monday.Meanwhile, he initiated coverage of Hewlett Packard Enterprise at sector perform, with a price target of 17.Credit Suisse's Garcha initiated coverage of HPE with a neutral rating and price target of 19."Secular challenges in the IT market (low growth rate and impact of the public cloud) create a headwind for the business," Garcha said in a report.HPE faces traditional competitors such as IBM (IBM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), plus public cloud computing firms such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.Mergers and acquisitions will be key for HPE, which has $11.5 billion of gross cash and $5.5 billion of net cash, Garcha said: "HPE has a strong balance sheet allowing for transformative M&A."Potential acquisitions include faster growth companies and current end-market positioning improvements, such as Arista Networks (ANET) and Nimble Storage (NMBL), and more legacy yet highly accretive acquisitions, such as NetApp (NTAP), Citrix Systems (CTXS) and CommVault Systems (CVLT).RELATED:HP Starts Life As A House Divided: Now The Hard PartHewlett-Packard spreading FUD over Dell-EMC merger.

Looking to push the legacy (i.e. old) giant tech stalwarts to use their cash piles to buy their way into faster growth, FBR analyst Daniel Ives issued a research report Thursday that praised Microsoft (MSFT) for its transition but kicked others — Cisco Systems, Oracle, IBM and Hewlett Packard — for their "treadmill approach" to expansion.And then he issued a wish-list of his top 10 tech tie-ups for 2016."It has been a choppy environment for tech players with a very bipolar IT spending backdrop," Ives said. "On the large-cap front, we have seen many changes from the HP split (into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to the largest tech merger ever in Dell/EMC (EMC)."Dell offered $67 billion in October to buy EMC."That said, it has been a tough road for many of these traditional tech stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), IBM (IBM), Cisco (CSCO) and HP, as investors have gotten used to seeing lackluster growth on a quarterly basis in light of the massive secular and company-specific challenges these mature tech vendors face," Ives said."The lone bright star in this cloudy large-cap enterprise tech space has been Microsoft, which is gaining momentum into 2016, as (CEO Satya) Nadella has made some tough decisions ('ripping the Band-Aid' off Nokia, cost cutting, free Windows 10 download strategy) to put (Microsoft) on the yellow brick road to the cloud."We believe the combination of the Dell/EMC deal, Amazon (AMZN) (Web Services') laser focus on the cloud and Nadella's 'golden child' success has put more heat in the kitchen for CEOs such as (IBM CEO Ginni) Rometty, (HPE CEO Meg) Whitman, (Oracle co-CEOs Safra Catz and Mark Hurd), and (Cisco CEO Chuck) Robbins to change from their 'treadmill approach' heading into 2016 and to focus on M&A and/or organic growth initiatives."FBR's top 10 merger-and-acquisition wish list for 2016, "in no particular order," Ives said, are:• (1) Cisco and NetApp (NTAP),• (2) Cisco and FireEye (FEYE),• (3) IBM and Splunk (SPLK),• (4) IBM and Qlik Technologies (QLIK),• (5) HPE and Box (BOX),• (6) HPE and Qlik,• (7) Oracle and Verint (VRNT),• (8) Oracle and NetSuite (N),• (9) Microsoft and Imperva (IMPV), and• (10) Microsoft and Qualys (QLYS)."... we believe EMC/Dell has disrupted the landscape and will force many of these mature tech stalwarts to finally be more aggressive in 2016 instead of fretting about valuations, as they need to focus on putting fuel back in their near-empty growth tanks," Ives said.

Employers in November announced plays to lay off 30,953 workers, the lowest since September 2014, even as 2015 cuts will likely hit a six-year high due to energy and factory job reductions.Announced layoff plans fell 39% from October, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Pink slips tend to fade near year-end, but plans were still down 13% vs. a year earlier.Still, the 12-month rolling total is high after spiking this summer amid a slew of job cuts, led by energy-related firms.Ailing tech titan Hewlett-Packard actually led the way with plans to cut 30,000 jobs. Hewlett-Packard has now split into two companies — printers-and-PC HP Inc. (HPQ) and corporate-focused Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE).But oil services firms Schlumberger (SLB), Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI) have slashed tens of thousands of jobs, with Schlumberger recently saying it would shed more positions. Halliburton is buying Baker Hughes.Caterpillar (CAT) in September said it will cut 5,000 jobs. The company has seen weak global demand for its mining equipment.Microsoft (MSFT), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Procter & Gamble (PG) have also announced significant workforce reductions this year.However, initial jobless claims edged higher last week but remain near long-time lows, where they've been for several months.The Labor Department issues its November employment report on Friday, with economists looking for a gain of 190,000, with unemployment holding at 5%.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter @IBD_ECarson and on Facebook.
After two strong up days following the Hewlett-Packard split-up, PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) fell Wednesday after getting a cautious report from UBS.

HP was down 2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 14. Its sister company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), was down 4%, also near 14. Hewlett-Packard split into HP and HPE on Sunday.
UBS analyst Steven Milunovich on Wednesday initiated coverage of HP with a neutral rating and HPE with a buy rating.
He set a 12-month price target of 15 on HP.

"Although we find the valuation and dividend yield somewhat attractive, we think the business fundamentals are likely to get worse before they get better," he said about HP. "We expect the printing margin to come under pressure and PC sales to decline albeit at a more modest rate."
In the longer term, he is optimistic about HP's prospects in encroaching on the copier market and becoming a leader in 3D printing.
HP gets about 80% of its profit from printing, mostly by selling ink, and the remaining 20% from personal computers.
On a revenue basis, printers and supplies account for 40% of sales, with PCs and workstations accounting for 60% of sales.
"Although HP Inc. is comprised of two secularly challenged businesses — printing and PCs — we do expect to see a benefit from increased focus over time," Milunovich said.
As for HPE, Milunovich sees the business improving in the near term, but has longer-term concerns. He set a price target of 18.50 on the stock.

"HPE has in its favor a combination of low valuation and positive momentum," he said. "We expect results to improve in storage, Enterprise Services, and software with stabilization in Technology Services and more modest growth in servers."
But HPE might be too hardware-centric and not sufficiently differentiated for long-term success, Milunovich said.
Barclays Favors HP Over HPE
Meanwhile, Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz favors HP over HPE. On Wednesday, he rated HP stock as equal weight with a price target of 14 and HPE as underweight with a target of 13.
Of the two stand-alone companies, HP is the more attractive, thanks to its better cash flow and yield prospects, he said.
HPE faces competition from cloud computing companies such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.
On Tuesday, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 17. He gave HPE a rating of market perform and a price target of 16.

HP is the dominant player in printing, with about a 40% share of A4 laser printer units and a 45% share of A4 inkjet printer units. It is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in the PC market, with about an 18% share.

"We believe that both are scale- and brand-driven businesses, and that consolidation is afoot in PCs, and appears inevitable in printing (both Lexmark (LXK) and Xerox (XRX) have recently announced that they are exploring strategic options)," Sacconaghi said. "In the near term, HP should benefit from distractions at its printing peers and No. 3 PC vendor Dell, which is in the process of attempting to swallow larger EMC (EMC)."

HPE faces a different set of challenges. He described it as "an on-premise vendor in an increasingly off-premise world." IT customers are shifting from servers and storage located on site to cloud computing resources accessed over the Internet.

"The IT spending landscape is undergoing massive changes, chief among them is the migration from on-premise infrastructure to off-premise solutions," Sacconaghi said. "Increasingly, CIOs are telling us that their priority for workloads is (software-as-a-service), (infrastructure-as-a-service), then — at last resort — on premise. This transition is affecting all traditional IT vendors, whose growth rates have stagnated."
Besides HPE, other vendors hurt by the shift include IBM (IBM), NetApp (NTAP), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and EMC excluding its VMware (VMW) unit, he said.

Old HP business more attractive than new HP spinoff.After two strong up days following the Hewlett-Packard split-up, PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) fell Wednesday after getting a cautious report from UBS.HP was down 2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 14. Its sister company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), was down 4%, also near 14. Hewlett-Packard split into HP and HPE on Sunday.UBS analyst Steven Milunovich on Wednesday initiated coverage of HP with a neutral rating and HPE with a buy rating.He set a 12-month price target of 15 on HP."Although we find the valuation and dividend yield somewhat attractive, we think the business fundamentals are likely to get worse before they get better," he said about HP. "We expect the printing margin to come under pressure and PC sales to decline albeit at a more modest rate."In the longer term, he is optimistic about HP's prospects in encroaching on the copier market and becoming a leader in 3D printing.HP gets about 80% of its profit from printing, mostly by selling ink, and the remaining 20% from personal computers.On a revenue basis, printers and supplies account for 40% of sales, with PCs and workstations accounting for 60% of sales."Although HP Inc. is comprised of two secularly challenged businesses — printing and PCs — we do expect to see a benefit from increased focus over time," Milunovich said.As for HPE, Milunovich sees the business improving in the near term, but has longer-term concerns. He set a price target of 18.50 on the stock."HPE has in its favor a combination of low valuation and positive momentum," he said. "We expect results to improve in storage, Enterprise Services, and software with stabilization in Technology Services and more modest growth in servers."But HPE might be too hardware-centric and not sufficiently differentiated for long-term success, Milunovich said.Barclays Favors HP Over HPEMeanwhile, Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz favors HP over HPE. On Wednesday, he rated HP stock as equal weight with a price target of 14 and HPE as underweight with a target of 13.Of the two stand-alone companies, HP is the more attractive, thanks to its better cash flow and yield prospects, he said.HPE faces competition from cloud computing companies such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.On Tuesday, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 17. He gave HPE a rating of market perform and a price target of 16.HP is the dominant player in printing, with about a 40% share of A4 laser printer units and a 45% share of A4 inkjet printer units. It is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in the PC market, with about an 18% share."We believe that both are scale- and brand-driven businesses, and that consolidation is afoot in PCs, and appears inevitable in printing (both Lexmark (LXK) and Xerox (XRX) have recently announced that they are exploring strategic options)," Sacconaghi said. "In the near term, HP should benefit from distractions at its printing peers and No. 3 PC vendor Dell, which is in the process of attempting to swallow larger EMC (EMC)."HPE faces a different set of challenges. He described it as "an on-premise vendor in an increasingly off-premise world." IT customers are shifting from servers and storage located on site to cloud computing resources accessed over the Internet."The IT spending landscape is undergoing massive changes, chief among them is the migration from on-premise infrastructure to off-premise solutions," Sacconaghi said. "Increasingly, CIOs are telling us that their priority for workloads is (software-as-a-service), (infrastructure-as-a-service), then — at last resort — on premise. This transition is affecting all traditional IT vendors, whose growth rates have stagnated."Besides HPE, other vendors hurt by the shift include IBM (IBM), NetApp (NTAP), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and EMC excluding its VMware (VMW) unit, he said.Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter https://twitter.com/ibd_pseitz.RELATED:Hewlett Packard Enterprise Starts Slow In 'Confusion'Old HP business more attractive than new HP spinoff.

HP (HPQ) and its spinoff, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), both got new analyst coverage Tuesday, while No. 1 U.S. drugmaker Pfizer (PFE) and top credit card firm Visa (V) had their price targets hiked.Bernstein initiated HP at outperform, while Mizuho lowered its price target on the IT giant's stock to 14 from 30 and maintained its neutral rating. On Monday, HP shares popped nearly 13% as investors embraced the company's spinoff of Hewlett Packard Enterprise.Meanwhile, Hewlett Packard Enterprise was initiated at neutral by Mizuho on Tuesday and given a 15 price target.HP shares closed up 3.3% on thestock market today. Hewlett Packard Enterprise fell 0.9% on its second day of trading.Visa's price target was raised to 91 from 82 by RBC Capital Markets, which maintained its outperform rating on the stock. On Monday, Visa fell short of quarterly EPS views and also said it is buying European counterpart Visa Europe for as much as $23.4 billion in a long-anticipated cash-and-stock deal.Shares of the credit card giant rose 3.6% Tuesday.Pfizer fell 0.3% even though its price target was raised to 46 from 41 at Argus, which has a buy rating on the stock. Pfizer shares rose 3.7% on Monday following a positive article in Barron's, which said the Big Pharma firm's strong pipeline of drugs should be a catalyst for a higher stock price.Fellow drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) lost 2.6% after RBC Capital Markets lowered its price target on the stock to 213 from 231. Valeant has seen a steep drop in its share price ever since short-selling outfit Citron Research charged the drugmaker with fraud involving multiple specialty pharmacies. Cardinal shares rose 0.26% Tuesday after adding 4.8% the previous session.Red Hat (RHT) climbed 0.9% to 80.85 after it was upgraded to buy at Deutsche Bank. The software maker is nearing the multiyear high of 81.49, set in June.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 0.1% after it was initiated at hold by Stifel.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Windows 7 PC users are refusing to switch to Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system even though it's being offered as a free upgrade.Microsoft released Windows 10 worldwide on July 29 as a free upgrade for one year to owners of Windows 7 and 8 PCs. (It skipped Windows 9 in its naming scheme.) While Windows 7 was well-received by users, people generally hated Windows 8 with its redesigned user interface optimized for touchscreens.Windows 10 has received mostly favorable reviews, but Windows 7 users have largely stayed put with their 6-year-old operating system, according to data from Net Applications. In November, 56.1% of PCs on the Internet were running Windows 7, Net Applications reported Tuesday. The figure has remained stubbornly high since the Windows 10 launch. It was 57.7% in August, 56.5% in September and 55.7% in October.Meanwhile, the percentage of Windows 8 PCs in use rose last month. Windows 8 accounted for 14% of PCs on the Internet in November, compared with 13.2% in October. In June, before the release of Windows 10, Windows 8 had 16% market share, Net Applications said.In the four months since its release, Windows 10 has grown to 9% market share as of November. In October, it had 7.9% share, Net Applications said.Windows 10 adoption also has been slowed by sluggish sales of new PCs, which come with the new operating system installed.Versions of Microsoft's Windows ran 91.4% of PCs on the Internet in November, Net Applications said. Apple's (AAPL) Mac OS was second with 7% share, followed by Linux with 1.6%.On Nov. 23, market research firm Gartner (IT) predicted a fast migration to Windows 10."In the consumer market, a free upgrade coupled with broad legacy device support and automatic over-the-air upgrades ensures that there will be tens of millions of users familiar with the operating system (OS) before the end of 2015," Gartner analyst Steve Kleynhans said in a statement. "For enterprises, we expect that implementation will be significantly more rapid than that seen with Windows 7 six years ago."RELATED:HP Inc. Q4 earnings exposes dark side of PC business.

Ahead of Thanksgiving Day, stocks inched higher Wednesday in quiet volume. The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq rose 0.1% each while the S&P 500 ticked up a fraction. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well below Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.Pfizer (PFE) was the best performer in the Dow, rising 3%. It recently announced plans to buy Allergan (AGN) for around $160 billion.In economic news, personal income rose 0.4% in October, in line with estimates. Spending came up a bit short, rising 0.1%. The Commerce Department also said durable goods orders jumped 3% in October, double expectations. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.5%, a tad better than expected.In earnings news, PC and printer manufacturer HP (HPQ) tumbled 14% after reporting sluggish earnings and issuing weak guidance.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), spun off from HP earlier this month, rose nearly 4% after reporting solid results late Tuesday.Inside the IBD 50, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) is getting support at its 10-week moving average after a recent breakout. Shares rose 2%. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) garnered more strength after a breakout over a 154.84 buy point. Shares rose nearly 2%.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil futures fell 78 cents, or 1.8%, to $42.09 a barrel.The stock market will be closed Thursday for Thanksgiving. It will be open for a half-session Friday, closing at 1 p.m. ET.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

While investors applauded Hewlett Packard Enterprise's first quarterly performance as an independent company -- beating Wall Street estimates and driving its stock up more than 13% Friday -- some analysts and owners are pushing CEO Meg Whitman to compete harder.That means more aggressively taking on cloud enterprise leaders Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT), and buying up software  rivals such as Workday (WDAY) or Salesforce.com (CRM), rather than directing cash to shareholders."I think we need to give Meg a chance to see if she can take advantage of the opportunities in servers with the cloud migration led by Amazon Web Services, Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Microsoft on the service and software side," said Daniel Morgan, vice president of Synovus Trust, which holds 251,971 shares of HPE, in a Friday interview with IBD."Further, the 54% year-over-year growth in the Q1 2016 quarter in networking allows HPE to build more momentum in this space" vs. rivals Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR), he said."And finally as we discussed before, the huge opportunity to expand the software unit with its 17%-plus operating margins (enables) a large acquisition in the cloud space. Right now software is just 8%-10% of total HPE revenues."Buying enterprise software rivals Salesforce or Workday specifically is "a chance to make that unit significant by bringing it up to 20%-25% of revenues," he said. "Post-split, Hewlett Packard Enterprise was supposed to be the growth portion of the Hewlett-Packard Co., (creating) a reinvigorated growth company."Nevertheless, happy with HPE's earnings performance issued after Thursday's market close, investors bid up its stock up 13.5% to close at 15.44 in the stock market today. That's less than 3% below its Dec. 1 high since splitting from its parent Nov. 1.For now, HPE stockholders interested in growth of any kind will need patience because the company is still shrinking, despite the slight Q1 beat.Hewlett Packard Enterprise reported earnings of 41 cents per share in the fiscal Q1 ended Jan. 31, on sales down 3% to $12.72 billion vs. pro forma figures from a year earlier. The results slightly beat the average view of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which called for EPS of 40 cents on sales of $12.68 billion. The non-GAAP 41 cents EPS is down from 47 cents a year earlier. (However, if HPE had been a standalone company at the time, Q1 2015 adjusted EPS would have been 44 cents, the company said in a March 1 note.)That's pretty much as planned, with HPE not projecting much growth until fiscal 2018. For Q2 ending in April, HPE expects EPS ex items of 39 cents to 43 cents.  Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Q2 EPS ex items of 42 cents on sales of $12.297 billion before Thursday's earnings release, but on Friday, the revenue consensus was revised up to $12.332 billion.For the entire fiscal 2016 ending Oct. 31,  analysts  polled by Thomson Reuters projected $1.87 EPS ex items for fiscal 2016 ending Oct. 31, on revenue revised up Friday to $50.805 billion. HPE earlier had modeled $50.81 billion in revenue in fiscal 2016, down 2.5% from a $52.12 billion pro forma in fiscal 2015.The slightly smaller half of the old Hewlett-Packard Co., now called HP Inc. (HPQ), kept the legacy PCs, printers and ticker. HP Inc. lifted 0.6% to 11.18 Friday. Hewlett Packard Enterprise kept the enterprise software, servers, networking and financial services businesses.To encourage patience among Hewlett Packard Enterprise shareholders, CFO Tim Stonesifer said HPE will “return at least 100% of our free cash flow outlook to shareholders” in fiscal 2016, after devoting $1.3 billion to share repurchases and dividends in Q1. In "addition," Stonesifer said, shareholders will receive a "majority" of proceeds from the sale of a 51% stake in its Chinese server and storage business to Tsinghua Holdings, valued at $2.3 billion at the time the deal was announced last May. The transaction was supposed to be done by February, but Whitman said regulatory delays have pushed back closing to May, after which the cash will flow to shareholders.To UBS analyst Steve Milunovich, who complained in the post-earnings-release conference call that HPE shares were priced too low, Whitman chuckled: “We appreciate that, which is why we’re backing up the truck” to buy back more shares, which helps boost the price.Whitman advised analysts that by investing internally and encouraging organic growth “you don’t end up with a Frankenstein of architecture" as the company would risk doing by  growing through acquisitions. She cited HPE for pursuing both paths.“Our innovation engine is firing on all cylinders, and you're going to see some amazing new introductions in the coming quarters in key areas of the portfolio, including servers, cloud, high-performance computing, IoT (Internet of Things), all-flash storage, Aruba and converged systems.” Aruba Networks is a networking leader in mobile enterprise that the old Hewlett-Packard agreed to buy last March for about $3 billion, strengthening the new HPE's rivalry with Cisco Systems and Juniper Networks.As for "taking advantage of the disruption in the marketplace," Whitman said, "we learned a lot about how to do this in the context of IBM's (IBM) sale of their server business to Lenovo. ... We have a big opportunity to go take (merging) Dell and EMC (EMC) business, much as we took a lot of the Lenovo business that would have gone to Lenovo.”She told CNBC on Friday that "in the last quarter, we had about 107 deals that we actually took from Dell/EMC."She also told analysts that HPE has become the "leading infrastructure provider for SAP (SAP) HANA (application server) with nearly twice the number of shipments over the next competitor.”In the cloud, she said, "following a major wave of product releases across our HPE Helion portfolio in the second half of 2015, we are seeing strong customer traction. In fact, since separation, Helion has gained over 200 customer wins, including some of the world's largest banks, service providers and industrials.”It just wasn't enough for Needham analyst Richard Kugele, who chided the company in a research note issued Friday, arguing that the $2.3 billion windfall from Tsinghua should be spent on organic or M&A growth, not shareholders' short-term benefit."We had hoped that post-split, HPE would be able to focus on getting its house in order and leverage its cash and balance sheet to buy/invest in solutions that solve their product gaps," Kugele said. "Instead, the company seems intent on continuing financial engineering by doubling its cash return to shareholders (including the pending Tsinghua cash). In our view, this creates no sustainable value for the company or its investors but merely provides a floor for the stock during a period of poor enterprise spending."With no material growth, revenue improvement or product strategy to build a buy thesis around, we reiterate our hold rating on the stock."Said Morgan, the Synovus Trust portfolio manager who wants to give Whitman time to execute: "I did hear HPE management touting its share repurchases and FCF (free cash-flow) generation capability on the call. And this is very reminiscent of when Mark Hurd was leading HPQ  (the former Hewlett-Packard Co.) and grew the share price through financial engineering and not new product growth."Hurd is now co-CEO of Oracle (ORCL), one of HPE's toughest software rivals, and another legacy giant growing slowly.

Worldwide shipments of personal computers fell 10.6% year over year in the fourth quarter to 71.9 million units. But Apple (AAPL) bucked the downturn, increasing shipments of its Mac computers by 2.8% to nearly 5.7 million units, research firm IDC reported late Tuesday.Rival research firm Gartner (IT) concurred on Apple's growth rate but estimated that overall PC sales dipped 8.3% in Q4 to 75.7 million units.The PC market continues to face such persistent challenges as longer PC life cycles and competition from smartphones and tablets, IDC said. Economic issues like falling commodity prices and weak international currencies also have hurt PC shipments, IDC added.China-based Lenovo remained the No. 1 PC vendor worldwide in Q4 with 21.4% market share, up from 20% a year earlier. HP Inc () was second with 19.9% share, followed by Dell (14.1%), Asus (7.9%) and Apple (7.9%).The PC market continued to show signs of consolidation in the fourth quarter. The top five vendors accounted for 71.3% of PC shipments, up from 67.1% a year earlier.In November, IDC predicted that two of the top 10 PC makers will exit the market within the next 24 months.

Avago Technologies has been one of the hottest stocks in tech this year, thanks in no small part to the chipmaker's ties with the world's top-valued company, Apple.Now Avago's (AVGO) ties to Apple (AAPL) will strengthen when the former takes over chip company Broadcom (BRCM). In a deal valued at $37 billion, the new entity will take the Broadcom name, and Avago Chief Executive Hock Tan will head the combined firm.The two complement each other as Apple contractors, supplying chips to different parts of Apple's iPhone and other smartphones — Avago makes radio frequency chips and filters, and Broadcom produces controller and Wi-Fi combination chips. Set-top boxes and cars also use Broadcom chips.Avago expects the Broadcom deal to close early in the first calendar quarter of 2016. Avago has already been working on integration plans to get a head start on day one."Avago has done a great job in integrating companies and cutting costs out of operations," analyst Thomas Diffely of D.A. Davidson told Investor's Business Daily.Diffely said in the shorter term, Avago will benefit from hundreds of millions of dollars in cost savings from the Broadcom merger as it integrates the two operations."Over time, Avago will have a more integrated chip solution for the mobile consumer in particular," Diffely said.HP OriginsAvago got its start in the 1960s as the semiconductor arm of Hewlett-Packard, now HP Inc. (HPQ). It later became part of Agilent Technologies (A) before private equity investors bought the business in 2005 and took it public in 2009.Shares have climbed steadily since that IPO, which was priced at 15. Avago's shares now stand at roughly 149, after surging 90% in 2014 and another 47% this year.Revenue also has been on a strong uphill run, more than quadrupling from $1.5 billion in 2009 to $6.9 billion in 2015. The 2015 number is up 60% from 2014.In addition to being used in Apple's new iPhone 6s and other smartphones, Avago's chips are found in data networking, telecom equipment and industrial uses. The firm's two biggest business segments, in wireless and networking, have grown through a string of acquisitions in recent years.Five Firms In Two YearsIn the last two years alone, Avago acquired five companies, including data-center chipmaker LSI for $6.6 billion; PLX Technology, which makes integrated circuits; and most recently, the networking company Emulex.As Broadcom merges with Avago, revenue in 2016 likely will grow another 8% to $7.39 billion, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. But Avago still will trail No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) and fellow chip company and Apple supplier Qualcomm (QCOM).Avago singled out one customer for contributing more than 20% of revenue in the fourth quarter: Foxconn, the Chinese electronics contract manufacturer that rolls out iPhones for Apple.Slowdown SeenBut Avago's first quarter, which ends in January, is expected to see a seasonal slowdown in iPhones, a drop-off made more noticeable in the aftermath of the iPhone 6s launch and ramp-up. Avago expects wireless sales in the current first quarter to decline in the low-teens-percent range from the fourth quarter.Still, analysts don't seem worried for Avago's future."Even if units are flat, Apple is still increasing content," Diffely said.Other handset makers trying to close the gap with Apple, such as Samsung and China's Huawei, will need advanced technology, he adds."Bottom line, the need for advanced chips for these phones continues to rise," Diffely said.Morgan Stanley analyst Craig Hettenbach expects a sharp acceleration in Avago's wireless business during the second half of 2016, aided by new capacity to handle new wafer sizes and higher dollar value content in premium filters due to rising LTE penetration and new wireless bands. (LTE is a high-speed wireless standard.)"Now that the quarter is out of the way and, importantly, numbers are intact, we see Avago handily outperforming into 2016," Hettenbach said in a note to clients following the fourth-quarter report.Enterprise Storage BoomMeanwhile, Avago's enterprise storage business has been performing "rather amazingly," Avago CEO Tan said in the fourth-quarter conference call in early December. Revenue in that October-ending quarter was up 9% from the third quarter, despite soft demand.Enterprise storage accounted for 35% of total revenue in the quarter. That was nearly as much generated by the firm's biggest division, wireless communications, which made up 37% of the total and was up 10% from the previous quarter.Avago expects its enterprise storage business to maintain its momentum in the first quarter, with revenue still growing slightly from the fourth quarter, Tan said on the call."We also believe we may be gaining share in this segment," he added.Hettenbach noted that product enhancements via acquisitions of LSI, PLX Technology and Emulex likely helped Avago's enterprise storage business.The company's much smaller wired infrastructure business showed 2% revenue growth from the third quarter and 7% year-over-year. The even smaller industrial segment saw a 10% decline from the third quarter and a 7% drop from the year-earlier period, with the Americas and Japan the weakest regions.Total revenue in the quarter rose 15% over the earlier year to $1.85 billion, while earnings climbed 26% to $2.51 a share. Gross margin moved up to 62% from 58%.Analysts estimate that 2016 earnings will rise 8% to $9.71 a share, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.

Initial jobless claims fell by 5,000 last week to 267,000, the Labor Department said Thursday. The four-week average rose by 1,750 to 272,500, a three-month high.But by either measure, unemployment filings have held below 300,000 for almost the entire year, hitting a long-term low in July. Sub-300,000 readings normally signal booming job gains, but not in this economic cycle.Net job growth has been mediocre. Yes, there have been layoffs. Hewlett-Packard, now split into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE), announced plans to cut 30,000 workers. Oil services firms Schlumberger (SLB), Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI) have announced tens of thousands of job cuts as demand plunges with the price of crude.But jobless claims and layoffs aren't the culprit. The problem is that actual gross hiring — hiring before any job cuts or exits — still hasn't returned to pre-recession levels, according to Labor's JOLTS report. Truth be told, gross hiring wasn't booming in the prior 2001-2007 expansion either, so failing to live up even to that pace isn't encouraging.Weak gross hiring likely is one reason why the labor force participation rate, including among prime-age workers, remains so low. Weak hiring — and firing — also suggest a less-dynamic economy. Some labor market churn is good, as workers move to more-productive jobs and industries.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter @IBD_ECarson and on Facebook.

It was its last report as a combined company with Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which was spun off earlier this month. The spinoff's shares gained 3%.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

Thin opening gains firmed in early action Wednesday following a flood of primarily positive economic news. The Nasdaq rolled ahead 0.3%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 held to 0.1% gains.Volume faded about 20% each on the NYSE and the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time on Tuesday.The stock market today launched to a heavy slate of economic news, led by better than expected — or at least as good as expected — October durable goods orders, weekly unemployment claim and personal income numbers.The preliminary services sector estimate from researcher Markit was also positive, with its Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 56.5 for November, up from 54.4 and above economist projections of 55. Employment gains aided the bounce off October's nine-month low, but business confidence remained subdued, the report said.Also above expectation: the Federal Housing Finance Agency's September House Price Index, which leaped 0.8%, up from August's 0.3% rise and vs. consensus projections for an 0.4% rise.New home sales jumped to an annualized rate of 495,000 in October, the Commerce Department reported. The reports also revised September's rate lower, to 447,000. Economist consensus had forecast a November increase to a rate of 499,000 homes sold.The University of Michigan offered the morning's leading down note. The final reading of its November Consumer Sentiment Index dipped to 91.3 — above October's tally of 90 but down from a preliminary November estimate of 93.1 and below views for no change.Oil prices were still down more than 1%, but losses eased a bit on the approach to the Energy Information Administration's 10:30 a.m. weekly report on inventories.Oil-related stocks held eight of the 10 worst losses among S&P 500 companies in early action. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) posted to the worst opening declines on the Dow.In other stocks, nothing runs like a Deere, the ads say, and that was true Wednesday morning as Deere (DE) led the S&P 500 after narrowing a 5% gain to 3%. The agricultural and construction equipment maker reported its fiscal fourth quarter earnings fell less than consensus forecasts. The stock is trying to climb off the floor of a three-month consolidation.Freshly halved PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) dived 13% at the start of trade. IT services and equipment sibling Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) surged 6%. The company late Tuesday reported its last full quarter as a combined outfit, following the Nov. 1 split into separate operations.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) charged ahead almost 4%, continuing its rebound from its week-ago low. The stock is deep in a year-long correction, attempting to retake support at its 10-week moving average.Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 3%, attempting to bounce back from the two-day sell-off that appeared to follow comments from retailer GameStop (GME) that sales of EA's Star Wars Battlefront were weaker than expected.On the IBD 50 list, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) climbed more than 2% at the start of trade. It put the stock in buying range on a rebound from its 10-week moving average. It is the first test since the ATM and card payment processor broke out above a cup base in September.China-based online game provider NetEase (NTES) added nearly 2%. The stock is working on its seventh straight gain and is extended above a 154.98 buy point.Overseas, Europe's market powered higher following mostly positive U.S. economic news. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded higher in afternoon action, led by Frankfurt's DAX, up 1.7%.

The stock market overcame early weakness Tuesday, ending with small gains in higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Nasdaq closed fractionally higher. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in higher than Monday's levels in the stock market today.The Dow was helped by strength in Pfizer (PFE), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil futures rose $1.12, or 2.7%, to $42.87 a barrel as tensions between Turkey and Russia raised output concerns in the region.In economic news, the second estimate to Q3 GDP came in at 2.1%, in line with expectations and up from an initial estimate of 1.5%. Separately, consumer confidence unexpectedly declined in November. The Conference Board's index slumped to 90.4, the lowest since September 2014, and well below the consensus estimate of 99.6.In earnings news, network security software company Palo Alto Networks (PANW) jumped 6%. Late Thursday, it reported earnings of 35 cents a share, up 133% from a year ago and 3 cents above the consensus estimate. Sales rose 55% to $297.2 million, also better than expected. Multiple analysts raised price targets.Dycom Industries (DY) ended solidly higher after a volatile session. Shares rose 3%. The specialty contracting services provider for telecoms reported its third straight quarter of triple-digit earnings growth. Sales growth accelerated for the third straight quarter, rising 29% to $659.3 million.Inside the IBD 50, Avago Technologies (AVGO) was the best percentage gainer, rising 3%.Microsemi (MSCC) gapped below its 50-day moving average, falling 6.5% in intense trading. The chipmaker reached an accord to acquire PMC-Sierra (PMCS) for about $2.5 billion. The deal ended a long bidding war with Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) for PMC-Sierra, a maker of network-drive chips. PMC shares fell 2%; Skyworks added nearly 3%.After the close, watch for earnings from Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE). Spun off from HP earlier this month, it's working on a first-stage IPO base.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.
But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.
Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.

As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.
Whitman is CEO of HPE.
Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.
Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.
Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.

The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.

"Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."

Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.Whitman is CEO of HPE.Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion."Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.

It should be among the most unusual earnings conference calls in corporate history — certainly in Hewlett Packard Enterprise's (HPE) history, which by the time the company reports after the close Tuesday will have gone back, oh, 24 days since it became a company, though it's also 76 years old and could claim to be the pioneering Silicon Valley tech outfit.Reporting its fiscal Q4, which ended Oct. 31, Meg Whitman will hold court as both the new chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett Packard Enterprise and as the continuing chairwoman and former chair and CEO of the former Hewlett-Packard, now known as HP Inc. (HPQ).HP Inc. kept the former Hewlett-Packard's ticker, HPQ. Hewlett Packard Enterprise got a new ticker, HPE.HP Inc. keeps the legacy computers and printer businesses. Hewlett Packard Enterprise takes the more ephemeral but — some analysts say — more promising enterprise services and cloud-enabled technologies businesses.In the past week, investors bid up Enterprise stock 6%, and 3% on Friday alone, to 14.21. That was its second best day of the month but still 5.5% off its open Nov. 2.Q4 might also be known as a clean-up quarter, a place to book some of the losses and charges related to the restructuring. Whitman said in September that the reorganization will impact cash by about $2.6 billion over three years starting in the current year, its fiscal 2016."These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," Whitman said in September. "We've done a significant amount of work over the past few years to take costs out and simplify processes, and these final actions will eliminate the need for any future corporate restructuring."Cost savings are coming, in part, from the elimination of as many as 30,000 jobs from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, three years after the old, combined Hewlett-Packard cut 55,000 jobs. At the time of the September Q3 earnings release, the combined company had about 302,000 jobs.For Q4 2015, the old Hewlett-Packard estimated that EPS minus items for the entire company would range from 92 to 98 cents. The estimate excludes 80 cents in separation costs and other charges.Analysts ascribed more than half of that income, 52 cents, to the future Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Thomson Reuters analysts estimated Q4 revenue at $13.5 billion.For Q1, ending Jan. 31, analysts expect Enterprise to earn 44 cents per share, minus items, on $12.77 billion in revenue.In Q3, ended July 31, the old Enterprise Group sales rose 2%, with a 13% operating margin, the old company said."While we have to wait for HP's Q4 results to see the first full post-split balance-sheet details, HPE's filings disclose a pro-forma cash and investment position totaled approximately $11.5 billion exiting Q3," wrote Stifel analyst Aaron Rakers in a research report. "HPE's total debt position stands at (about) $16 billion; however, it is important to note that this includes about $10.6 billion on HP Financial Services debt. This leaves HPE net operating cash at approximately $5.5 billion exiting Q3 (excluding about $615 million of reported HPFS cash)."We would note that prior conversations have suggested that HPE will be focused on maintaining an investment-grade debt rating or a debt-to-EBITDA in the 2.0x-2.5x range."We expect investors to focus on HPE's capacity to make strategic acquisitions."Stifel initiated Hewlett Packard Enterprise with a hold rating.

Now that Hewlett-Packard has split in two, the question for the iconic technology giant and pioneer is whether its divide-and-conquer strategy will spark a rebound and accelerate growth.

HP's efforts to revisit the heights that it reached during the dot-com boom 15 years ago have largely failed. Its shares and market cap have lagged those of many contemporaries. So, 14 years after it mushroomed in size through the huge acquisition of Compaq, the Silicon Valley stalwart is downsizing.

HP aims to unleash the growth-starved enterprise side of the company that serves businesses, and says that its consumer technology engine, run by PCs and its industry-leading printers, can keep chugging along despite few organic growth prospects.

It's a risky gambit that could backfire, some observers say. Others say that it's the only way for HP to keep from becoming a dinosaur. While such tech titans as Apple (AAPL) find success and blue skies in new businesses, others such as IBM (IBM), Oracle (ORCL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) see clouds, as in cloud computing, as they gaze into their crystal balls.

"HP is trying to figure out how to get off the innovation treadmill that's going 2 miles per hour," said Daniel Ives, a tech analyst at FBR & Co. "It makes sense that they're willing to do something to shake up the status quo."
Dell Does Opposite

Investors gave a mixed greeting to the split stocks in their first day of trading Monday. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which gets a new ticker, fell 1.6% to 14.49. But HP Inc. (HPQ), which retains the ticker Hewlett-Packard has used since it acquired Compaq, rose 13% to 13.83.

Ives says the split-up isn't meant to reverse HP's oft-criticized 2001 purchase of then-giant PC firm Compaq Computer for $25 billion. Opinions on that deal vary, but observers note that other tech Goliaths are trying the same method to keep from being slain by Davids. Most notably of late, privately held Dell announced an agreement in October to acquire EMC (EMC), at $67 billion the largest-ever merger of pure tech companies. That move could be considered the opposite of what HP is doing.
Many tech titans are scrambling to find ways to stay on their toes, but some observers question the strategy of HP and Chief Executive Meg Whitman. HP executives were unavailable for comment.
Rob Enderle, a longtime Silicon Valley analyst, is among the dubious. He points to Dell and China giant Lenovo as among companies that view offering a broad spectrum of technology as key.
"HP seems to be an example of a company determined to do something wrong," Enderle said.
Market Cap Vs. Sales

Right or wrong, Hewlett Packard Enterprise is the "new" company that will aim to deepen technology's ties to corporations. It looks to make money providing services via the cloud or Internet. HP Inc. will focus on the consumer PC and printing businesses.

One signpost by which to gauge the split's success is how it transforms HP's market capitalization. For now, HP is the only tech company of its size with a market cap smaller than its annual sales. Prior to the split, the combined HP was valued below $48 billion, while revenue for its fiscal year, which ended Saturday, is estimated near $106 billion. Prior to the split, there were roughly 1.8 billion shares of HP; its stock closed Friday at 26.96.

By comparison, Apple's world-leading market cap of $683 billion compares with annual sales of $234 billion. IBM has less than 1 billion shares outstanding, roughly half of HP's; but its market cap is nearly triple HP's, at $136.4 billion, with its stock closing Friday just above 140. IBM posted 2014 sales of $93 billion.

Oracle has roughly double the shares that HP has but more than triple the market cap: $166 billion, with annual sales near $38 billion. Cisco is roughly equal to Oracle, with $146 billion in market cap and $49 billion in sales this fiscal year.
Ranking Low
Excluding financial services firms, which don't record revenue, HP ranks No. 33 among multinational companies in the Financial Times Global 500 in terms of sales, but it ranks No. 125 in market cap.
And HP ranks No. 111 in revenue per employee and No. 162 in market value per employee.
"How the hell do you even get there?" asked analyst Enderle of HP's standing. "For the most part, it's being clueless."
But some — including Crawford Del Prete, an analyst at tech research firm IDC who has followed HP since the late 1990s — view the split as a solid move.
"It's hard for me to be skeptical (about whether) it's going to work," Del Prete said. "I don't see how they're going to have trouble executing the split."
FBR's Ives says that the key for HP is how well the enterprise unit adapts to cloud computing, a huge trend in the tech industry.

"HP was late to the cloud," Ives said. "A lot of these (older, legacy tech) companies miscalculated how quickly this shift would happen. I think these companies have hubris and are seeing through rose-colored glasses not only on the board but (in) the CEO seat as well."Now that Hewlett-Packard has split in two, the question for the iconic technology giant and pioneer is whether its divide-and-conquer strategy will spark a rebound and accelerate growth.HP's efforts to revisit the heights that it reached during the dot-com boom 15 years ago have largely failed. Its shares and market cap have lagged those of many contemporaries. So, 14 years after it mushroomed in size through the huge acquisition of Compaq, the Silicon Valley stalwart is downsizing.HP aims to unleash the growth-starved enterprise side of the company that serves businesses, and says that its consumer technology engine, run by PCs and its industry-leading printers, can keep chugging along despite few organic growth prospects.It's a risky gambit that could backfire, some observers say. Others say that it's the only way for HP to keep from becoming a dinosaur. While such tech titans as Apple (AAPL) find success and blue skies in new businesses, others such as IBM (IBM), Oracle (ORCL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) see clouds, as in cloud computing, as they gaze into their crystal balls."HP is trying to figure out how to get off the innovation treadmill that's going 2 miles per hour," said Daniel Ives, a tech analyst at FBR & Co. "It makes sense that they're willing to do something to shake up the status quo."Dell Does OppositeInvestors gave a mixed greeting to the split stocks in their first day of trading Monday. Research firm IDC is predicting that two of the top 10 PC makers will exit the market within the next 24 months.IDC made the prediction this week as part of its annual tech industry forecasts for the next year and beyond.

IDC also predicted that more than 30% of today's information technology vendors won't exist as we know them within five years. They'll either be acquired, merged, downsized or significantly repositioned by 2020. Those companies will be casualties of the shift to "third platform technologies," including cloud computing services, Big Data and analytics, mobile computing and social networking, IDC said.

The PC market has been impacted by the rise of mobile and cloud computing. Customers have shifted spending to smartphones and tablets, postponing PC replacements and sometimes substituting mobile devices for PCs. Also, the rise of Internet cloud-based applications and data storage has lessened the need for new personal computers.

Shifting priorities will drive IT organizations to push the average commercial PC lifespan past six years by 2017, IDC predicted. PC lifespans have been in the range of 4.5 to 5 years, IDC analyst Tom Mainelli told IBD.

As PC sales have shrunk in recent years, the top four vendors have consolidated market share. They are Lenovo, HP Inc. (HPQ), Dell and Apple (AAPL), Mainelli said. So the two companies likely to bow out of the PC market probably will be in the lower half of the top 10, he said.
The bottom six are Acer, Asus, Toshiba, Samsung, Tongfang and Fujitsu, Mainelli said.

"The most likely scenario is that two will simply leave the market," Mainelli said. "I don't expect there to be many acquisitions as the (top four) don't gain much from buying anybody in the bottom half of the list. There will likely be much discussion about possible mergers among the rest, but I'm not sure that this course of action will play out."

Dell explored the sale of its PC business ahead of its recent deal to purchase enterprise storage firm EMC (EMC), but couldn't find any takers, according to Re/code. It approached HP, Lenovo and Huawei without success, the news site said.

China-based Lenovo was the top PC vendor in the third quarter with 21% market share based on global unit shipments, IDC said. HP was second with 19.6%, followed by Dell (14.3%), Apple (7.5%) and Acer (7%). All other vendors combined for 30.6% market share.
Worldwide PC shipments fell 10.8% year over year to 71 million units in Q3, IDC said.
IDC foresees a modest recovery in PC shipments in 2017, following five years of decline.

Big shakeouts are coming for companies competing in two emerging technology areas — wearables and 3D printers — IDC predicts. In wearables, over half of today's players will exit the market by 2020, the research firm said.
In 3D printing, the top companies in five years will be ones not yet in the market, IDC said.
Those were among the predictions for 2016 and beyond made this week by IDC analysts in the firm's annual tech industry prognostications.
Wearables Wearing Out?
In a conference call with clients and press on Wednesday, IDC chief analyst Frank Gens predicted a "shakeout" in wearables.

The market includes activity trackers from Fitbit (FIT), Garmin (GRMN), Microsoft (MSFT) and others; smartwatches like Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch; and augmented reality glasses like Microsoft's HoloLens and Alphabet 's (GOOGL) Google Glass.

"We have identified at least 50 vendors in this space, and have lumped many smaller vendors into our 'others' category," IDC analyst Ramon Llamas told IBD. "Since 2013, we've already seen numerous vendors close up, and chances are more companies will come and go between now and 2020."

The fitness tracker segment will benefit from continued adoption of such devices by corporate wellness programs. Next year, 30% of Fortune 500 companies will distribute fitness trackers to their employees, IDC predicted.

The smartwatch segment will see next-generation models that won't need to be tethered to smartphones to fully function. IDC predicts that 18% of smartwatches shipped will have cellular connectivity by the end of 2016.
3D Printer Newbies Will Lead
The top 3D printer companies today will be displaced by new competitors to the market by 2020, Gens said.

"We'll see a complete leadership makeover in 3D printing," he said. "By 2020, we predict that the market will be led by four to five companies that today have 0% market share. They're going to jump into the market."

In the U.S. last year, the top five 3D printer makers by unit shipments were Stratasys (SSYS) (36.6% market share), 3D Systems (DDD) (17.2%), Flashforge (13%), Beijing TierTime (8.7%) and XYZ Printing (6.4%), IDC said.
Paper printer companies like HP Inc. (HPQ) are likely to take over the 3D printer market, IDC analyst Keith Kmetz told IBD.

"We expect the large printer players to come into this market shortly," Kmetz said. "HP announced their plans, but we also see activity from the traditional competitor base like Canon, Ricoh, Konica Minolta, etc. Right now, they don't have 3D printers, but they will soon."

Next year, 30% of Fortune 500 companies will distribute fitness trackers to their employees, IDC predicted.The smartwatch segment will see next-generation models that won't need to be tethered to smartphones to fully function. IDC predicts that 18% of smartwatches shipped will have cellular connectivity by the end of 2016.3D Printer Newbies Will LeadThe top 3D printer companies today will be displaced by new competitors to the market by 2020, Gens said."We'll see a complete leadership makeover in 3D printing," he said. "By 2020, we predict that the market will be led by four to five companies that today have 0% market share. They're going to jump into the market."In the U.S. last year, the top five 3D printer makers by unit shipments were Stratasys (SSYS) (36.6% market share), 3D Systems (DDD) (17.2%), Flashforge (13%), Beijing TierTime (8.7%) and XYZ Printing (6.4%), IDC said.Paper printer companies like HP Inc. (HPQ) are likely to take over the 3D printer market, IDC analyst Keith Kmetz told IBD."We expect the large printer players to come into this market shortly," Kmetz said. "HP announced their plans, but we also see activity from the traditional competitor base like Canon, Ricoh, Konica Minolta, etc. Right now, they don't have 3D printers, but they will soon."RELATED:Shakeout could eliminate 30% of today's IT vendors3D Systems, Stratasys Show Ongoing Pain With Earnings.

Good thing many investors used a "wait and see mentality" on Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), as analyst Aaron Rakers suggests, because those who couldn't wait drove its stock down as much as 5.6% before the shares almost completely recovered, ending Tuesday down less than 1%, at 14.36. The new enterprise service and cloud computing issue fell 1.6% in its debut…
Lacking firmer footing in the cloud "until it can prove otherwise," Oracle (ORCL) stock was downgraded Thursday by FBR & Co. to market perform from outperform, though FBR kept its price target at 44.
Oracle stock, up 14% since late September, was down a fraction, near 40, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.

"Although we have patiently awaited a turnaround story at Oracle, and the company has talked a great talk, the lack of consistent results, an empty M&A strategy ... and major secular challenges from the likes of Amazon (AMZN) Web Services are hard to ignore and thus make it tough to be bullish," wrote FBR analyst Daniel Ives in a research note.

Oracle is sailing against the "same headwinds," Ives said, as other "mature, tech stalwarts" such as IBM (IBM); newly divided Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc. (HPQ); EMC (EMC) and Dell, which are merging; and Cisco Systems (CSCO).
He says that more budget dollars are flowing toward the next-generation data centers and away from traditional IT purchase cycles.

For Oracle's fiscal Q2, ending Nov. 30, FBR lowered its revenue estimates to $9.1 billion from $9.5 billion, and its earnings per share estimate to 60 cents from 61 cents. The consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters also is 60 cents, which would be down 13% from the year-earlier quarter.

For fiscal 2016, FBR knocked down Oracle sales estimates from $38.4 billion to $37.6 billion and pro forma EPS from $2.67 to $2.61. In its fiscal 2015, which ended May 31, Oracle reported EPS of $2.21 on sales of $38.2 billion.
"Cloud is the focus; growth remains the problem," said Ives.

Ives says that the company's cloud products — software-as-a-service, platform-as-a-service and infrastructure-as-a-service — are expanding and improving. But, he said, "Oracle faces major company-specific and secular headwinds on its legacy database and applications business, which continue to see slower deal flow in light of an evolving IT landscape.

"To this point, we believe Oracle needs to be aggressive on M&A (big data, cloud, cybersecurity) and get back to its core DNA that helped create the Oracle powerhouse of yesterday, otherwise darker days could be ahead."

Oracle's annual shareholders meeting is slated for Nov. 18 at its Redwood City, Calif., headquarters.Lacking firmer footing in the cloud "until it can prove otherwise," Oracle (ORCL) stock was downgraded Thursday by FBR & Co. to market perform from outperform, though FBR kept its price target at 44.Oracle stock, up 14% since late September, was down a fraction, near 40, in afternoon trading on the stock market today."Although we have patiently awaited a turnaround story at Oracle, and the company has talked a great talk, the lack of consistent results, an empty M&A strategy ... and major secular challenges from the likes of Amazon (AMZN) Web Services are hard to ignore and thus make it tough to be bullish," wrote FBR analyst Daniel Ives in a research note.Oracle is sailing against the "same headwinds," Ives said, as other "mature, tech stalwarts" such as IBM (IBM); newly divided Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc.
