Even a car in motion is vulnerable to getting hacked. The OPM breach, linked to Chinese hackers, reportedly exposed the personal information of over 21 million people who had…
Cracking the Chinese tech infrastructure market is becoming more challenging for U.S. heavyweights Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard as the cyberspying issue heats up.

China's government is discouraging its companies from buying tech gear from large U.S. vendors such as Cisco (CSCO) and HP (HPQ) in the wake U.S. government allegations last year that the Chinese government had sponsored cyberspying on U.S. companies.

"They are really pushing harder now against buying U.S. infrastructure products like networking or servers — they have taken it up a notch," Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald who toured China in April, told IBD. "Last year, it was more pronounced, but then in April it was like a full-blown huge initiative."
White says the catalyst for the rift began two years when Edward Snowden, a former National Security Agency subcontractor, leaked classified documents about the agency's surveillance activities.
"Once the Snowden thing happened it was a validation of the Chinese fear that they were going to be spied on," White said.
The China government's mandate pertains mostly to areas critical to security, says White, who said he learned of the edict from a well-placed source in China.
"Certain industries, like military and government and oil, you have to buy 100% from China-based vendors," White said. "In other industries, they have to hit a goal of 70% in five years.
"The guys most impacted, according to my contact, would be Cisco and HP, especially Cisco."
Both companies reported poor results from China in their most recent earnings.

Cisco's product orders in Asia-Pacific, Japan and China rose just 1% in its fiscal Q3 ended April 25, vs. the year-earlier period. Minus China, growth would have been 8%, Cisco CEO John Chambers told analysts on the firm's earnings conference call.

In HP's earnings call for its fiscal Q2 ended April 30, CFO Catherine Lesjack called the company's networking sales in China during the period "disappointing." HP's global networking revenue tumbled 16%.
China represents only a sliver of total revenue for Cisco and HP, but neither can afford to be shut out of China too long, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for market tracker IDC.
"China has been a growth engine, so it's going to be important for the likes of Cisco and other U.S. companies like HP to be able to find ways to penetrate the Chinese market," Mehra told IBD.

By 2018, sales of Ethernet switches, a key networking product, in China will reach $3 billion, up 230% from 2014, says IDC. Sales of routers, also crucial in networks, will rise 26% in that span to $2.2 billion, IDC says. Cisco is the No. 1 seller of switches and routers.
U.S. sales of switches and routers will be $10.3 billion and $5.2 billion by 2018, says IDC, but their growth rates will be just 14% and 5%, respectively.

Server sales in China are seen rising 51% in that span to $9 billion, IDC says. U.S. server sales will hit $22.2 billion in 2018, it says, but that growth rate from 2014 is only 23%. HP is a top seller of servers.
China also is soaring in use of mobile devices and networks. In Q1, China added 8 million new mobile subscribers, vs. 6 million in the U.S., says mobile gear maker Ericsson (ERIC).
Cisco and HP don't want to miss China's growth in mobile, White says.
"The mobile Internet in China will be the biggest in the world and that requires routers, switches and servers," he said.

China's governmental clampdowns on Cisco and HP helps China vendors Huawei Technologies and ZTE. White says other Chinese vendors also will gain from the boost at home. "Ultimately, you will have some major IT companies coming out of China that will be global players," he said.
Huawei in particular is gaining traction, says Mehra.
"Huawei in the last five years has become much more of a competitor in the networking market, which was not the case five years ago in switching and routing," he said.
But HP might have found a way to compete in China.

HP's move to sell a 51% stake in HC3, HP's China-based networking, server and storage services company, to Tsinghua University for $2.3 billion last month should give it continued access to China's market, analysts say.
HC3 was originally a joint venture of Huawei and 3Com, a U.S.-based networking equipment and security products maker. HP bought 3Com for $2.7 billion in 2010.
HP could also leverage the partnership to sell additional products such as wireless networking equipment from its recent acquisition of Aruba Networks, Mehra says.
"It could evolve into a cross-selling relationship, then they could OEM all of the Aruba portfolio and sell it under the HC3 brand," he said.
Other U.S. tech sellers also appear to be hurt by China's political climate.

In a conference call to discuss its Q1 earnings in April, EMC (EMC) executive David Goulden said weakness in China was "due to increased scrutiny of U.S. technology purchases in the government and financial services sectors."
Some vendors, though, apparently see no impact.

This month, Israel-based Radware said it would provide its security software for China Railway, to help build its next-generation e-ticketing platform. And in January, Radware inked a deal to provide security software to the Shenyin & Wanguo Securities MU Fund.
U.S.-based Oracle (ORCL), the No. 1 database maker, is another seemingly safe, White says.

"Oracle shouldn't have much of an impact because it's tough to replace them," he said. "What are you going to replace them with?"Cracking the Chinese tech infrastructure market is becoming more challenging for U.S. heavyweights Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard as the cyberspying issue heats up.China's government is discouraging its companies from buying tech gear from large U.S. vendors such as Cisco (CSCO) and HP (HPQ) in the wake U.S. government allegations last year that the Chinese government had sponsored cyberspying on U.S. companies."They are really pushing harder now against buying U.S. infrastructure products like networking or servers — they have taken it up a notch," Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald who toured China in April, told IBD. "Last year, it was more pronounced, but then in April it was like a full-blown huge initiative."White says the catalyst for the rift began two years when Edward Snowden, a former National Security Agency subcontractor, leaked classified documents about the agency's surveillance activities."Once the Snowden thing happened it was a validation of the Chinese fear that they were going to be spied on," White said.The China government's mandate pertains mostly to areas critical to security, says White, who said he learned of the edict from a well-placed source in China."Certain industries, like military and government and oil, you have to buy 100% from China-based vendors," White said. Investors might want to take another look at Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) as the company gets closer to splitting into two entities by year's end, with PCs and printers in one company and its enterprise hardware, software and services in the other. In a research report Tuesday, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, upgraded his rating on HP stock to buy…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) hopes to draw away enterprise data storage customers from Dell and EMC (EMC) using the classic approach of spreading FUD, business shorthand for "fear, uncertainty and doubt," about its rivals.Last week, HP CEO Meg Whitman criticized Dell's planned $67 billion acquisition of EMC. HP later launched an opportunistic marketing campaign warning customers about potential upheaval in the storage business of the combined Dell-EMC.A recent Twitter (TWTR) advertisement by HP Storage said, "Dell's acquisition of EMC — uncertainty ahead," with a picture of what looks like an earthquake-damaged road. The promoted tweet included a link to an HP blog post knocking the deal.That post, written by Jorge Maestre, competitive strategist for global storage at HP Enterprise, said that the Dell-EMC merger would create complexity. The combined company will have to figure out which products to keep and what its unified storage strategy will be, Maestre said."A merger of this magnitude reshuffles the market, and every vendor on the planet is already in attack mode looking to pick off as many customers as possible," Maestre said. "That leaves Dell with a TON of work to do. They have to merge two completely independent product, sales and support organizations."When the deal was announced on Oct. 12, HP issued a statement claiming that the Dell-EMC merger provided a "real opportunity" for HP."Two of our largest competitors are attempting a highly distracting, multiyear merger, just as we are launching two new, focused companies," the HP statement said, according to Barron's . "The massive debt burden Dell and EMC are taking on undoubtedly means that they will have to radically reduce R&D, and integration inevitably will create disruption as they rationalize product portfolios, channel programs and leadership."Whitman later sent a memo to HP Enterprise employees titled "Seize the moment," which hammered home the same points.HP is scheduled to split into two publicly traded companies on Nov. 1. HP Inc. will run its PC and printer businesses. HP Enterprise will focus on enterprise information technology, including servers and storage.RELATED:Dell-EMC Deal Could Spark More Tech M&A Activity.Dell: Keeping VMware 'Important' To EMC Deal Success.
Troubled 3D Systems (DDD) announced the resignation of president and CEO Avi Reichental, one week before the maker of 3D printers is set to report third-quarter earnings.

The announcement came Thursday morning and was effective Wednesday at the close of business. Reichental held the position for 12 years. Taking his place on an interim basis is Andrew Johnson, the company's chief legal officer.

"The company's board of directors will immediately commence a comprehensive search and evaluation process to select a permanent replacement for the role of president and chief executive officer," the company said in a statement.

The resignation comes during a difficult time for 3D Systems and its chief competitor, Stratasys (SSYS). Last week, Stratasys reported preliminary third-quarter earnings estimates well below Wall Street expectations.

"We are profoundly grateful for the visionary leadership Avi has provided to our business and to our industry, and we wish him well in his future endeavors," said Charles Hull, company co-founder and chief technology officer, in the press release. "As our industry continues to evolve and we look to the future, we are focused on aligning our resources and programs to best serve our customers and are excited about the many opportunities ahead."

3D Systems, founded in 1986, pioneered the industry. It initially developed expensive 3D printers used in aerospace and automotive manufacturing to develop prototype parts, in what then was a niche market. Advances in technologies and materials led to 3D printers able to create physical objects from a wide array of plastics, metals, ceramics and other materials.

Stratasys and 3D Systems shares soared from early 2012 to early 2014 as media reports touted the technology as one of the next big things. The stocks began to tumble in early 2014 when 3D Systems and Stratasys began to lower their estimates. Nor did it help that short-seller Citron Research slammed 3D printer stocks in several reports.
3D Systems stock peaked at 97.28 on Jan. 3, 2014. The stock was down 5%, near 10.30, in early afternoon trading on the stock market today.
Stratasys stock also tumbled in early 2014 but regained momentum, hitting a peak of 130.83 on Sept. 19. 2014, then commenced to fall. Stratasys stock was near 26.75 Thursday afternoon, up a fraction.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) plans to enter the 3D printer market in late 2016. A research note last month by UBS, on HP's entry into the market, said the industry had many mountains yet to climb. Hewlett-Packard as of Sunday is set to split into separate companies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, focusing on enterprise products and services, and HP Inc., focusing on the PC and printer businesses.

"We think 3D printing is a significant long-term opportunity, but the technology is immature in terms of speed, quality and reliability, which has caused problems for Stratasys and 3D Systems," the report said.

Stratasys, when it lowered its Q3 outlook, said that during 2013 and 2014, the overall 3D printing industry experienced extraordinary growth that it said might have created excess capacity in the market. It said this is contributing to the current slowdown, as that excess is worked off.

Hewlett-Packard's ill-fated 2011 acquisition of software maker Autonomy once again came back to bite the company, with Autonomy's former CEO reportedly suing HP in Britain.Meanwhile, directors formally approved Hewlett-Packard's split into two separate companies, one focused on the PC and printer businesses and the other on enterprise services.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) stock was down 1.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, after reports of the suit, which seeks $150 million.Reports said the lawsuit was filed in British courts Thursday by Mike Lynch, founder and former CEO of Autonomy, the entity that HP purchased in 2011 for $11 billion. It is a counterclaim to HP's attempt to get $5.1 billion in damages from Lynch and Sushovan Hussain, Autonomy's former chief financial officer. In his counterclaim, Lynch reportedly says HP made statements that were damaging to him.The acquisition of the maker of Big Data analysis software has been a rough one for HP. The company took an $8.8 billion accounting charge related to the acquisition in 2012, and alleged that company executives fraudulently inflated the British software company's value.Lynch has said that HP mismanaged Autonomy after it bought the company in August 2011.The Financial Times reported that Lynch's filing says: "The fact that HP's impairment calculation fluctuated by such large sums in the days before the calculation was finalized show that HP's calculation was based (at least in part) on broad, subjective judgments on the part of HP's top executives."HP responded by saying: "Mike Lynch's lawsuit is a laughable and desperate attempt to divert attention from the $5 billion lawsuit HP has filed and the ongoing criminal investigation. HP anxiously looks forward to the day Lynch and Hussain will be forced to answer for their actions in court."Meanwhile, HP said Thursday that its board on Wednesday formally approved to split the company into two entities: HP Inc., handling its PCs, consumer products and printers; and Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co., handling enterprise services and more. The split is set to go into effect Nov. 1.Hewlett-Packard expects to cut as many as 33,300 total jobs once the split takes place, with 25,000 to 30,000 coming from enterprise operations and up to 3,300 from HP Inc.Follow Russ Britt on Twitter @IBD_RBritt and on Facebook.

Proofpoint (PFPT) stock soared Thursday to a two-month high after the cybersecurity firm late Wednesday posted Q3 revenue that jumped 37% vs. the year-earlier quarter and reduced its per-share losses by a nickel, beating views.The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company also announced a partnership with Intel (INTC) Security, formerly McAfee, that lets the chipmaker use Proofpoint's threat intelligence information in a "joint go-to-market collaboration," CEO Gary Steele told analysts during the company's Q3 earnings conference call.Proofpoint reported $69.2 million in sales for the quarter and a per-share loss minus items of 6 cents.Both metrics bested the consensus estimate of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which called for sales of $66 million and an 11-cent loss.Proofpoint stock rose as much as 18% in early trading on the stock market today and was up 13%, near 55.50, in midday trading.Proofpoint guided Q4 revenue up to $72.5 million-$73.5 million, up 28% at the midpoint vs. the year-earlier quarter. The company guided to a per-share loss minus items of 11-12 cents, vs. 9 cents in Q4 2014.For the year, Proofpoint models a 35% increase in revenue to $263 million-$264 million, and 35-36 cents losses per share vs. 40-cent losses in 2014. The company also preliminarily guided revenue up 29-30% for 2016.The company's billings were "white-hot," helped by a 90% subscription renewal rate, FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research report. Billings rose 37% year over year to $85 million, vs. the consensus forecast for $77.6 million and Proofpoint guidance for $77 million."Proofpoint posted an impressive billings/revenue performance as it penetrated further into its existing installed base with solid cross-sell/upsell execution," Ives wrote.Ives rates Proofpoint stock outperform and maintained an 80 price target.Gaining Vs. HP, SymantecSummit Research analyst Srini Nandury sees Proofpoint overtaking competitors Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Symantec (SYMC) in email archiving market share.And Proofpoint messaging security software will swipe customers from rivals Microsoft (MSFT), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Symantec, Nandury wrote.Tech research firms Gartner and Forrester both consider Proofpoint the best in email protection, he wrote.This status "confirms our belief that Proofpoint's core protection will continue to gain market share from established on-premise players," he wrote. "At present, only 49% of Fortune 100 and 24% of Fortune 1000 (companies) use Proofpoint protection, presenting the company with large headroom to grow its install base," Nandury wrote.Nandury rates Proofpoint stock a buy, with a price target of 80.CEO Steele didn't say much about the partnership with Intel Security, but Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski called it a positive."Management also hinted at several other partnerships that will be announced in 2016," he wrote in a research report. He added that the company's "guidance already factors in a contribution from these partnerships."Nowinski rates Proofpoint stock overweight, with a price target of 76.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

As IBM (IBM) kicks off the third-quarter earnings season Monday afternoon for those tech companies catering to businesses, analysts say the questions that investors need to ask is where the growth will come from for big-ticket stocks and whether smaller players on the rise can perform. Microsoft (MSFT) has joined its PC hardware partners to promote Windows 10 computers ahead of the holiday shopping season. But their relations are strained since the software giant unveiled its first notebook computer, the Surface Book, on Oct. 6.
Dell, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Intel (INTC), Lenovo and Microsoft on Thursday launched their first joint advertising campaign to showcase the innovation available in the latest personal computers.

The six-week campaign, which begins Oct. 19 in the U.S. and China, features ads with the slogan "PC Does What?" (To appeal to young people, the slogan is stylized as "PC Does Whaaat?!") The campaign will include TV commercials, online ads, social media and native advertising, which are ads that look like online articles.

The ads will promote new PCs from Dell, HP and Lenovo that run sixth-generation Intel core processors and Microsoft's Windows 10 operating system. The companies hope to inspire consumers to upgrade their PCs by showing them what they're missing with the latest technology.

The campaign will conclude on Nov. 30 after Black Friday and the Thanksgiving holiday weekend, which kicks off the Christmas shopping season. The ad campaign will cost $70 million, according to the Associated Press.
"The possibilities of today's PCs are endless, but millions of people are still using outdated systems," Karen Quintos, Dell senior vice president and chief marketing officer, said in a statement.
Microsoft: Hardware Vendor

Dell, HP and Lenovo are backing the ad campaign despite the fact that Microsoft is encroaching on their turf by making its own PCs. Historically, Microsoft has focused on operating systems and left PC design to hardware partners. But with its Surface tablets and new Surface Book laptop, Microsoft is competing with the PC vendors.
Lenovo has refused to sell Microsoft's Surface Pro tablet because of competitive concerns.

"I said no to resell their product," Lenovo President and COO Gianfranco Lanci said at the recent Canalys Channels Forum, according to the Register, a technology news website. Microsoft "asked me more than one year ago, and I said no. I don't see any reason why I should sell a product from, within brackets, competition."
However, Dell and HP agreed to be global resellers for Microsoft's enterprise tablet-cum-notebook last month, selling the hardware wrapped in a service blanket, the Register said.

PC sales have stagnated as consumers and businesses have held on to their current machines for longer periods. Market research firms Gartner (IT) and IDC last week estimated that PC shipments in the third quarter shriveled 7.7% and 10.8%, respectively, vs. Q3 2014.
Microsoft and its PC hardware partners are hoping the holiday shopping season will give computer sales a boost.
Microsoft is going after high-end consumers with its premium Surface Book notebook, which starts at $1,499. It will compete with Apple's (AAPL) 13-inch MacBook Pro, which starts at $1,299.

The consolidation trend buzzing around the semiconductor industry is expected to continue into 2016, with SanDisk and Maxim Integrated Products the latest companies rumored to be on the sales block.
Speculation about the pair of takeover candidates surfaced just this week, after a record pace of consolidation this year.
In the first half of 2015, chip M&A action reached a $72.6 billion combined value — an all-time high and nearly six times the annual average the previous five years, according IC Insights.
Chipmakers are scrambling to remain profitable as organic growth slows amid a limp global economy, MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing told IBD.
"It's hard to latch onto secular growth," he said. "Even smartphones and the Internet of Things markets are slowing. The industry is maturing."
M&A buzz accelerated this week with reports that SanDisk (SNDK) might be acquired by Micron (MU) or Western Digital (WDC), and that Analog Devices (ADI) might be courting Maxim (MXIM).
Also, Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) soared 16% Wednesday and another 3.1% Thursday on rumors it could be acquired.
They'd join a long list of deals.
In June, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR) for $16.7 billion.

In May, Apple (AAPL) iPhone chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) announced an agreement to acquire Broadcom (BRCM) for $37 billion — then the biggest merger of pure-tech companies. This week's $67 billion merger agreement announced by Dell and EMC (EMC) is now No. 1.

This year, China's Tsinghua Group reportedly was interested in buying Micron for $23 billion as China tries to become less dependent on chip imports. Tsinghua recently invested $3.8 billion in Western Digital.

In the 1980s and 1990s, only "IBM (IBM) and Motorola (MSI) were highly integrated," Ing said. "Fast-forward to today, and there are really only 20 customers that matter (for chipmakers), so it makes sense to vertically integrate and scale."

Rather than a fractured and specialized industry, chipmakers will join forces to better appeal to heavyweight chip users such as Apple, Samsung Electronics (SSNLF), Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), he says.
Fabless firms, which don't do their own chip manufacturing, are most susceptible to M&A activity, he said.
"The fabless model is broken because specialization is down in software now vs. hardware," he said. "It makes sense to in-source your manufacturing."

Skyworks Solutions' (SWKS) $2 billion acquisition of PMC-Sierra (PMCS), announced this month, makes sense, Ing says. Skyworks sells chips to Apple for use in its iPhones, while PMC reaps revenue from Cisco, HP and Dell on the equipment side.
By combining, the two firms have stretched their portfolios, Ing says, and count at least four big hitters among customers.
Layoffs Certain

Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan says chipmakers must diversify as sales growth slows. "One company might have Samsung as a customer, and one company might have Apple as a customer, so by joining forces, no matter who wins, (the chipmakers) win," Sundararajan told IBD.

Some employees, though, will lose their jobs in these big mergers, he says. Avago and Broadcom estimate $750 million in cost synergy savings. Given a hypothetical $200,000 per employee (accounting for salary and benefits), that means 3,750 layoffs could occur.
Which companies are on the hunt?
Ing sees Intel, Texas Instruments (TXN), Analog Devices, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Avago as among the likeliest suitors.

"Look at Avago; they buy a big company like Broadcom, and after some period of time they're acquisitive again," he said. "Companies are going to do these deals, take a breather, reduce the waste they took on, de-lever their debts and then go shopping again."The consolidation trend buzzing around the semiconductor industry is expected to continue into 2016, with SanDisk and Maxim Integrated Products the latest companies rumored to be on the sales block.Speculation about the pair of takeover candidates surfaced just this week, after a record pace of consolidation this year.In the first half of 2015, chip M&A action reached a $72.6 billion combined value — an all-time high and nearly six times the annual average the previous five years, according IC Insights.Chipmakers are scrambling to remain profitable as organic growth slows amid a limp global economy, MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing told IBD."It's hard to latch onto secular growth," he said. New Relic (NEWR) hopes to show it's starting to challenge larger incumbent vendors such as CA Technologies and Hewlett-Packard in the application performance management market when it reports its fiscal Q3 earnings after the market close Thursday.
The earnings report will be the company's first since it made its initial public offering on Dec. 12.
New Relic stock jumped 48% on its first day of trading, to 34, and it peaked above 37 on Jan. 5.
New Relic was down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 34.
New Relic's APM software lets companies monitor the performance of their software apps and related areas, including server applications and browser applications.
The company is one of four recent tech IPOs looking to cash in on the growing cloud and Big Data markets.
New Relic, after focusing on smaller companies, is starting to target enterprise customers, where it will face much larger rivals CA Technologies (CA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), IBM (IBM) and Dell.
New Relic already is making an impact, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James & Associates, said in a research report last month. He has an outperform rating on New Relic stock.

"New Relic is a disruptive software-as-service (SaaS) vendor taking share from legacy incumbents in APM and pioneering software analytics — using application data for IT operations management (ITOM) and business analytics," he wrote. "We see strong demand drivers in an increasingly software-defined IT environment and the need to leverage application Big Data for IT and business intelligence."
For the quarter ended Dec. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a loss per share minus items of 37 cents vs. a loss per share of 25 cents in the year-earlier period.
Revenue is expected to rise 52% to $26.1 million.
For the current quarter, analysts expect a loss per share of 27 cents vs. a loss per share of 21 cents.
Revenue is expected to rise 42% to $28.2 million.
Turits says New Relic's move to larger customers will accelerate profit growth.

"We expect a steady path to profitability as the installed base shifts toward higher-value enterprise customers," he wrote.New Relic (NEWR) hopes to show it's starting to challenge larger incumbent vendors such as CA Technologies and Hewlett-Packard in the application performance management market when it reports its fiscal Q3 earnings after the market close Thursday.The earnings report will be the company's first since it made its initial public offering on Dec. 12.New Relic stock jumped 48% on its first day of trading, to 34, and it peaked above 37 on Jan. 5.New Relic was down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 34.New Relic's APM software lets companies monitor the performance of their software apps and related areas, including server applications and browser applications.The company is one of four recent tech IPOs looking to cash in on the growing cloud and Big Data markets.New Relic, after focusing on smaller companies, is starting to target enterprise customers, where it will face much larger rivals CA Technologies (CA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), IBM (IBM) and Dell.New Relic already is making an impact, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James & Associates, said in a research report last month. Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Global sales of enterprise disk storage systems reached $10.57 billion in the fourth quarter at the factory level, up 7.2% from the year-earlier period, says research firm IDC.EMC (EMC), the longtime leader, retained its No. 1 spot with a 22% market share, down from 21% in Q4 2013. EMC's Q4 revenue in disk storage systems totaled $2.35 billion.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) was No. 2 with a 13.8% share. HP maintained its Q4 lead in server sales, however.Dell was No. 3 in disk storage system sales last quarter, while IBM (IBM) and NetApp (NTAP) tied for the fourth position."The storage market had a strong finish to 2014," IDC analyst Eric Sheppard said in a press release."Fourth-quarter spending on enterprise storage systems was up strongly in most major geographic markets, driven by traditional year-end seasonality, demand for midrange systems that incorporate flash capacity, and continued growth of systems designed for hyperscale datacenters," he said.Storage systems sales by original design manufacturers selling directly to hyperscale datacenter customers accounted for 12.8% of global spending during the quarter.Disk storage system spending for the year rose 3.6% to $36.2 billion.IDC defines a disk storage system as a packaged set of storage elements, including disk drives, controllers and cables.

A few of the largest and oldest tech firms may finally get a shot at beating the upstarts in the fast-growing data analytics software market.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Oracle (ORCL) and others are armed with software to tackle what is becoming a growing concern and a big pain for companies: how to derive useful information from the reams of social media conversations, e-mail and other unstructured data on the Internet.

The old tech giants have been losing ground in the data analytics business to companies such as Tableau Software (DATA) and Qlik Technologies (QLIK) that have perfected ways of analyzing structured data. Structured data include spreadsheets and information from databases arranged in columns in a relational database system. Tableau's visualization software lets business professionals arrange structured data in easy-to-read charts and graphs without the need for IT departments.
But so far, neither Tableau nor Qlik can tackle unstructured data — considered the next big virtually untapped territory for data analytics, says Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets & Co.
"Unstructured data is the Holy Grail," he told IBD. "Cracking that nut is really the gold on the other side of the rainbow."

Companies see a growing interest in mining social media sites like Facebook (FB) for customer feedback and other insights into their operations, says David Schubmehl, an analyst for market tracker IDC.

"This whole social media revolution has focused organizations' efforts on unstructured data (such as) Twitter (TWTR) and Facebook posts, and people are beginning to understand the potential value of unstructured data, so the future is very bright for this kind of analysis," he told IBD.

For now, the structured data analysis market will be much larger — and will grow much faster than — unstructured analysis. By 2018, global sales of relational database software for working with structural data will reach $50 billion, up from $30 billion, says IDC.

Global sales of non-relational database software for unstructured information are expected to reach $5.08 billion by 2018, up from $4.19 billion in 2013, IDC says. The market for unstructured data will likely accelerate as more companies become aware that it is an untapped resource, Schubmehl says.

"Right now, we have estimated that 90% of the data available in the world today is unstructured information," he said. "You have got people writing memos, emails, research reports, patents, discussing why they didn't like the Patriots' (Super Bowl) win and all of this is adding to the ever-growing amount of content that is out there."
But unstructured data are also a much tougher nut to crack for analytics firms, says Boris Evelson, an analyst for market tracker Forrester Research.

"How do you parse your text? How do you identify grammar rules? How do you identify sentiment?" he told IBD. "That is still pretty much rocket science; a plug-and-play approach doesn't exist in the text analytics world."
Many technology players, including HP and Oracle, have used acquisitions to help them serve the emerging unstructured market.
In one of the most controversial deals in recent history, HP paid $10.3 billion in 2011 to acquire Autonomy, a maker of software for sifting through unstructured data.
That same year Oracle paid $1 billion to acquire Endeca, which makes business intelligence software analyzing unstructured data.
More recently, Microsoft (MSFT) acquired Equivio, an Israel-based text analysis firm that can provide analysis of unstructured data.
Other technology giants SAP (SAP) and IBM (IBM) have used acquisitions to build a capability for unstructured data analysis, Evelson says.
"Among the big players, IBM has an edge, and SAP over the years has acquired a lot of unstructured data technologies," he said.
So far, Tableau and Qlik both rely on third-party partners when customers require analysis of unstructured data.

Tableau works with several partners including Splunk (SPLK) and Amazon.com (AMZN) units Amazon Relational Database Service, which helps customers set up a database in the cloud, and Amazon Elastic MapReduce, a Web-service that uses Hadoop open source database software to sift through large amounts of data.
A Qlik spokesman says using third-party companies is an effective strategy because it offers an unstructured expert to better serve the customer.
Others may be adopting a different strategy.
Late last year, Salesforce.com (CRM) launched a data analytics software service to serve help companies with both structured and unstructured data.
Some other data analytics players that focus on structured data will likely make a bigger push into unstructured data, Schubmehl says.
"You will see a Qlik and Tableau and some of these other companies begin to offer that kind of capability as time goes on," he said.
But not everyone agrees.
Structured and unstructured data are two entirely separate businesses, says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities.

"The market for analytics on unstructured data is more fragmented; it's probably better conceptualized by application area or use case," he said in an e-mail to IBD. "The market for business intelligence against structured data is large and well established and Tableau (and secondarily Qlik) are disrupting this market."
Tableau reported Q4 revenue growth of 75%, which soundly beat analyst estimates of 50% growth.

With revenue growth of 71%-95% in the last seven quarters, Tableau might not have to be too concerned with adding unstructured data anytime soon, says Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co.

"That is an enormous market opportunity for Tableau and they are in the early stages of penetrating that — and that is just structured data," he said.A few of the largest and oldest tech firms may finally get a shot at beating the upstarts in the fast-growing data analytics software market.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Oracle (ORCL) and others are armed with software to tackle what is becoming a growing concern and a big pain for companies: how to derive useful information from the reams of social media conversations, e-mail and other unstructured data on the Internet.The old tech giants have been losing ground in the data analytics business to companies such as Tableau Software (DATA) and Qlik Technologies (QLIK) that have perfected ways of analyzing structured data. Structured data include spreadsheets and information from databases arranged in columns in a relational database system. Tableau's visualization software lets business professionals arrange structured data in easy-to-read charts and graphs without the need for IT departments.But so far, neither Tableau nor Qlik can tackle unstructured data — considered the next big virtually untapped territory for data analytics, says Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets & Co."Unstructured data is the Holy Grail," he told IBD. says."Among the big players, IBM has an edge, and SAP over the years has acquired a lot of unstructured data technologies," he said.So far, Tableau and Qlik both rely on third-party partners when customers require analysis of unstructured data.Tableau works with several partners including Splunk (SPLK) and Amazon.com (AMZN) units Amazon Relational Database Service, which helps customers set up a database in the cloud, and Amazon Elastic MapReduce, a Web-service that uses Hadoop open source database software to sift through large amounts of data.A Qlik spokesman says using third-party companies is an effective strategy because it offers an unstructured expert to better serve the customer.Others may be adopting a different strategy.Late last year, Salesforce.com (CRM) launched a data analytics software service to serve help companies with both structured and unstructured data.Some other data analytics players that focus on structured data will likely make a bigger push into unstructured data, Schubmehl says."You will see a Qlik and Tableau and some of these other companies begin to offer that kind of capability as time goes on," he said.But not everyone agrees.Structured and unstructured data are two entirely separate businesses, says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities."The market for analytics on unstructured data is more fragmented; it's probably better conceptualized by application area or use case," he said in an e-mail to IBD. "The market for business intelligence against structured data is large and well established and Tableau (and secondarily Qlik) are disrupting this market."Tableau reported Q4 revenue growth of 75%, which soundly beat analyst estimates of 50% growth.With revenue growth of 71%-95% in the last seven quarters, Tableau might not have to be too concerned with adding unstructured data anytime soon, says Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co."That is an enormous market opportunity for Tableau and they are in the early stages of penetrating that — and that is just structured data," he said.

Year to date, tech M&As total $55.3 billion globally, according to a Thomson Reuters analysis of deals with disclosed financial terms. That's up 9.5% from the same period a year ago. At…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) likely will do little more than meet expectations when it reports its fiscal Q1 earnings after the market close Tuesday, as the company continues to work through restructuring plan and gets closer to cleaving itself into two separate companies by year's end.

HP is struggling to reaccelerate its revenue growth, which has mostly been in decline since July 2011. The company is scrambling to move into emerging growth areas including the cloud, Big Data and security to offset slowing or declining growth in other areas including printing and enterprise services.

The company is planning to split into two separate companies, with HP Inc. managing its PC and printing businesses and HP Enterprise consisting of its server, storage, networking, converged systems, cloud, software and financial services units.
HP is kind of in a holding pattern until it can regain some footing and show some traction in emerging growth segments, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold.
"There are not a lot of drivers underneath their business, underneath the portfolio, that can really drive strong growth," he told IBD.

Foreign exchange issues that have plagued other tech companies. They include HP rival IBM (IBM), which last month gave weak guidance that sent its stock falling. Currency also poses a problem for HP, White says.
"The currency foreign exchange has been a big headwind," he said. "I think that will clearly have an impact on HP."

For the quarter ended on or near Jan. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings per share minus items of 91 cents, up 1.11% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to decline 2.94% to $27.35 billion.
For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS of 96 cents, up 9%, and revenue of $26.81 billion, down 1.81%.

In a research report Wednesday, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, said he expects some upside from HP's printing segment but says other areas including PCs and enterprise services will be challenged. He rates HP stock neutral.

"Printing, which is about 40% of profit, should be in line to better than expected, with the weak yen bolstering margins and improved channel inventory presaging lesser supplies declines," he wrote. "The company has anticipated a return to flat PC results, but post fiscal Q1 there is risk based on reports from Taiwan and the upcoming separation. We are expecting the enterprise group to be down 3%, enterprise services down 7% and software flat, for a total enterprise decline of 4%."
HP stock is down about 5% this year after rising 43% last year.

Investors appear to be waiting for HP to show revenue growth or some new product segments that have growth potential, White says. For now, he said, the company is "at a crossroads."Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) likely will do little more than meet expectations when it reports its fiscal Q1 earnings after the market close Tuesday, as the company continues to work through restructuring plan and gets closer to cleaving itself into two separate companies by year's end.HP is struggling to reaccelerate its revenue growth, which has mostly been in decline since July 2011. He rates HP stock a hold."There are not a lot of drivers underneath their business, underneath the portfolio, that can really drive strong growth," he told IBD.Foreign exchange issues that have plagued other tech companies. They include HP rival IBM (IBM), which last month gave weak guidance that sent its stock falling. Currency also poses a problem for HP, White says."The currency foreign exchange has been a big headwind," he said. "I think that will clearly have an impact on HP."For the quarter ended on or near Jan. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings per share minus items of 91 cents, up 1.11% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to decline 2.94% to $27.35 billion.For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS of 96 cents, up 9%, and revenue of $26.81 billion, down 1.81%.In a research report Wednesday, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, said he expects some upside from HP's printing segment but says other areas including PCs and enterprise services will be challenged. He rates HP stock neutral."Printing, which is about 40% of profit, should be in line to better than expected, with the weak yen bolstering margins and improved channel inventory presaging lesser supplies declines," he wrote. Technology stocks are thriving as the Nasdaq composite closes in on 5,000 after a big February advance. Savvy investors know to focus on the very best companies.IBD's Screen Center runs a Tech Leaders screen. Today's Tech Leaders is on Internets. This article does a second sort focusing based on expected earnings growth in the next quarter. Here are the five best.GrubHub Eating Rivals' LunchGrubHub (GRUB), which came public at 26 in April IPO, provides online and mobile food ordering services for 30,000 restaurants in the U.S. and London, with an average commission of 14.5%. Q4 earnings shot up 550%, with a 180% EPS gain expected in Q1.GrubHub leads in online/mobile food ordering, but it's a fragmented, largely untapped market. Online restaurant and business review site Yelp (YELP) recently announced a deal for GrubHub rival Eat24.GrubHub shares leapt 6.2% on Feb. 5 on those Q4 results. After a forming a handle, GrubHub broke out on Feb. 25. Shares reversed on Thursday, closing just below the 41.85 buy point, but nudged back above that level with a 0.6% advance Friday. The stock peaked at 45.80 on Aug. 13.Vipshop Is No AlibabaVipshop Holdings (VIPS) is leading Chinese e-commerce stock, specializing in flash sales. Last quarter earnings rose 140%, with revenue doubling once again. Analysts expect an 83% gain in the current quarter.While it's a relative minnow to the Alibaba (BABA) whale, Vipshop has been delivering faster growth — and the stock reflects that. Vipshop had a couple of breakout attempts in recent months that quickly fizzed, but broke out on Feb. 17 to a new high, soaring 15.2% on its latest earnings. Shares have moved sideways since then, but fell 3.6% on Friday.(Meanwhile, Alibaba stock has been in a downtrend since peaking at 120 on Nov. 13. The stock tumbled following its last earnings report and has continued to slide, hitting a record closing low last week.)LinkedIn Stock Setting Up AgainLinkedIn (LNKD) is the leading social network for professionals. It's become a go-to site for people looking for jobs — and for companies looking for skilled workers. Earnings rose 56% in the latest quarter on 44% revenue growth, with a 47% EPS forecast for the current Q1.LinkedIn shares gapped up 10.7% on Feb. 6 to a record high following its latest earnings report. That cleared a resistance area going back to early September. Shares have moved sideways in the last few weeks, forming a 3-weeks-tight pattern.Aruba Soars On Earnings, HP BuzzAruba Networks (ARUN) provides WiFi access points and controllers, with a variety of customers that includes Google (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Starbucks (SBUX). Aruba late Thursday reported a 67% EPS gain and offered bullish guidance. Analysts expect a 35% increase this quarter, but that may not fully reflect the new outlook. Aruba was mum on reports earlier in the week that Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) might be interested in buying the company.The combination of the strong earnings report and buyout buzz said Aruba's stock soaring 34.7% last week to its best level since April 2013.Facebook Costs Sap Earnings GrowthFacebook (FB) is the dominant social network worldwide, with 1.39 billion monthly active users at the end of last year. Facebook has done a good job adding and monetizing mobile users, with mobile advertising accounting for 69% of ad revenue in Q4. Facebook earnings rose 69% in Q4 on a 49% revenue gain. Expenses shot up 87%, with R&D; costs more than doubling. Expenses are expected to climb 70% in 2015. That will curb earnings growth, with profit seen rising just 18% in Q1 and 12% for the year.Facebook shares hit a record high on Oct. 12. After forming a shallow cup base, the stock briefly peaked out to a new high on Dec. 22. But the next day shares retreated, consolidating again. Shares have moved sideways since the Jan. 28 earnings report. Last week the stock neared a new peak, but fell 1.8% on Friday.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.Related:IBD 50 Stocks Outperform; Several Setups EmergeMeet IBD's 4 A Stocks With Rising Earnings Estimates.

Rapidly advancing technology offers a mixed blessing. It doesn't take long for what was once highly advanced and expensive technology to become a more affordable standard. But it also often doesn't make a lot of sense to invest in costly stuff when a fairly short wait will make those products way less of a burden on your wallet.That's what's happening in the portables market. While you can still spend $500 on an Apple (AAPL) iPad Air 2 or $800 on a Microsoft (MSFT) Surface Pro 3, you can get much of the same utility for a lot fewer dollars.What can you get for $250 or less? Here are some options: Apple's tablets are expensive compared with alternatives, but if you have to have an iPad, the original iPad Mini is still being sold for $250.But if you can live with Windows 8.1, the E Fun Nextbook 10.1 has a lot to offer for the money. Selling for $179 at Wal-Mart (WMT), it's a 10.1-inch touchscreen tablet with a detachable full-size keyboard that turns it into a small laptop. Like many tablets, it doesn't have much memory, 2 GB of RAM and 32GB of solid state memory — but it does have an SD Card slot, so you can add another 32GB of RAM with an inexpensive card. The Nextbook 10.1 uses an Intel (INTC) Atom quad-core CPU, which does a decent job on multimedia streaming from YouTube and other sites like Hulu and Netflix (NFLX). If a 10.1-inch screen is a bit too small for you, consider one of the many slightly larger new laptops hitting the stores. The Samsung Chromebook 2 has an 11.6-inch touchscreen and runs the Chrome OS, which is based around Google's (GOOGL) Chrome Internet browser. Priced at $249, the Chromebook 2 doesn't have a lot of memory — 2MB RAM and 16GB of solid state storage — but is designed to be used primarily while connected to the Internet, with the on-device storage used to hold apps that can be downloaded from the Chrome store.Google Docs A BonusFor reports, spreadsheets and the like, you can use Google Docs online, or download these applications onto the Chromebook so you can work on documents, spreadsheets and presentations when not connected to the Internet. There are loads of free or cheap apps available for Chromebooks, but if you're mostly Windows-oriented, then it might not be your first choice. Fortunately, there are some very attractive choices in laptops priced at under $250 that run the new Microsoft Windows 8.1 operating system.The Stream 13 from Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is a $229 Windows 8.1 machine similar in concept to the Chromebooks. It has minimal memory (2MB RAM, 32GB solid state drive) and is meant to be used primarily while connected to the Internet. A free year's subscription to Microsoft Office 365 and 1 terabyte of online storage is included in the price, and after the first year you can continue this subscription for $99 a year.There's a slot for a MicroSD Card so you can add up to another 64GB of storage for very little money. The Stream 13 is powered by an Intel Celeron CPU (as are most of the laptops in this column) and has a 13-inch display (a version of Stream is available with an 11-inch display for only $200). The Stream 13 (and Stream 11) is available in a bright blue or magenta color and weighs 3.4 pounds. The $249 Acer Aspire E 11 is similar to the 11-inch screen version of the HP Stream but offers a number of features that justify the extra cost. Rather than a small solid state disk, the Aspire E 11 has a 500GB hard disk. It also has 4GB of RAM and an 11.6-inch display, and it weighs only 2.8 pounds. Neither the Aspire nor HP Stream has a fan, and both feature long battery life, with up to five hours claimed for the Aspire and more than seven hours for the Stream. Finally, if you want an affordable full-sized laptop, consider the Asus X551MAV-HCL1201E. Priced at about $230, it is larger, heavier and thicker than the other laptops detailed here, but that 4.7 pounds and 1.2-inch thickness also gets you a large 15.6-inch display, a 500GB hard disk drive and a DVD drive that can read and burn discs, something that's not included with the other portables mentioned.As with the HP and Acer, the Asus laptop features an Intel Celeron CPU and includes Wi-Fi. Also included are an SD card reader (which is nice if you have a digital camera that uses this type of removable memory), a standard Ethernet connector and 4GB of RAM. The Asus portable runs Windows 8.1, the latest version of the operating system.None of the above machines can really be considered appropriate for high-end gaming. But for everyday computing and Web browsing, they all represent an excellent value.

Stocks ended with solid gains Friday after battling back from weakness spurred by a disappointing jobs report. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ended up 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Both were down 1.6% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.2%. According to preliminary data, volume ended higher across the board in the stock market today.Among leading stocks, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) reversed higher to a 6% gain. The stock had already risen 3% Thursday, following the pricing of a share offering. Dave & Buster's was recently featured in Stock Spotlight.Verisk Analytics (VRSK) stretched its win streak to four straight sessions. It rebounded from a 2% loss and rose 2%. The stock nearly reached a 79.98 buy point in a flat base. Verisk, which provides data to insurance underwriters and banks, will be added to the S&P 500 after Wednesday's close.Tyler Technologies (TYL) added 2% for its second straight new high. It's now 15% past a 145.84 buy point from a flat base cleared Sept. 14. On Thursday, the company announced that it would buy privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock.Domino's Pizza (DPZ) climbed 0.5% after bucking morning weakness. It failed to retake its 200-day moving average. Domino's will report Q3 earnings Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the pizza chain's profit rising 17% to 74 cents a share..

Stocks rose Tuesday ahead of a highly anticipated two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve in an apparent bet the Fed will only mildly tinker with interest rates.
The Nasdaq rose 1.1%; the S&P; 500 gained 1.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 1.4% in the stock market today. Volume was higher on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data.

After the close, Hewlett Packard (HPQ) announced a restructuring that sent the stock lower. The company said it would deliver $2.7 billion in annual cost reductions and that 25,000 to 30,000 people would leave the company.

United Natural Foods (UNFI) was volatile after the close. It reported adjusted EPS of 72 cents a share. Guidance was in-line with estimates. The company said Michael Zechmeister will replace Mark Shamber as CFO in mid-October.

Before the open Wednesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports the consumer price index for August. Economist forecast no change. After the open, weekly crude oil inventories are reported by the Energy Information Administration. Recent reports have caused volatility in the energy markets.

The Federal Open Market Committee begins its two-day meeting. It ends Thursday with an announcement on whether the Fed will raise interest rates. The current Fed funds target is 0% to 0.25%. The CME Group FedWatch website is forecasting a 25% chance they will raise rates to 0.5%.
Also before the open, FedEx (FDX) will report first-quarter fiscal 2016 results. Analysts are expecting $2.45 a share, which would be a 17% increase from a year earlier.

Also, Cracker Barrel Old Country Store (CBRL) reports Q4 results. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.87 a share, a 17% increase from a year earlier.Stocks rose Tuesday ahead of a highly anticipated two-day meeting of the Federal Reserve in an apparent bet the Fed will only mildly tinker with interest rates.The Nasdaq rose 1.1%; the S&P; 500 gained 1.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 1.4% in the stock market today. Enterprise data-storage company EMC saw its shares jump Thursday on reports that it could be acquired by privately held Dell, a deal analysts say could lead to more consolidation among the largest tech hardware and services companies.

Dell is said to be in advanced talks with EMC (EMC) about a possible merger, as was first reported late Wednesday by the Wall Street Journal. With a market capitalization of $52 billion, EMC would be one of the tech's biggest takeover targets ever.

Dell's offer for EMC could be more than $27 a share, CNBC reported Thursday. The deal announcement could be only a week away. Dell likely would need $40 billion in financing for the acquisition, CNBC said.

"A combined EMC/Dell would create a larger vendor that would own the entire stack and give it scale to compete against other large OEMs and cloud vendors, though the company would have to integrate and execute a strategy," Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um said in a research report Thursday.
EMC stock rose 4.7% Thursday, to 27.18, its seventh up day in a row after hitting a two-year closing low of 23.13 on Sept. 29.
EMC has been under pressure by activist investor Elliott Management to divest assets, including its 80% ownership in virtualization-software leader VMware (VMW) .

Dell was taken private in October 2013 by Dell founder and CEO Michael Dell and private-equity firm Silver Lake Partners, in a deal worth $25 billion. Since going private, Dell has shifted its emphasis from personal computers to enterprise hardware, software and services.

Other media reports suggest that Dell is interested in buying only part of EMC. Re/code reported Wednesday that EMC approached Dell within the last six weeks to sell its VNX storage product line, not the whole company.
VNX has annual sales of about $3 billion, Re/code said.
A purchase of part of EMC would be easier to digest for Dell, which has about $12 billion in debt on its books.
Wall Street Skeptical Of Deal
A breakup of EMC would unlock more value for EMC shareholders than a sale to Dell, BMO Capital Markets analyst Keith Bachman said in a report Thursday.
"EMC's individual business units are worth more than the current aggregate valuation," Bachman said. "We believe the sum of the parts valuation is between $30 and $32 (a share)."
Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi doubts that Dell could buy EMC.

"We don't think that Dell has the financial capacity to buy EMC, even if EMC were to spin-out VMware," Sacconaghi said. "Dell currently has about $12 billion in debt and an enterprise value likely around $20 billion to $25 billion, vs. EMC's enterprise value of around $45 billion.

"Even spinning out VMware, Dell would likely have to pay $25 billion or more for EMC to ensure a premium for EMC shareholders, which we believe would be financially very difficult to do. Moreover, it is unclear how compelling EMC without VMware would be to Dell, particularly since Dell has its own storage line-up."
'Head-Scratcher'

The possible sale of EMC's VNX storage business to Dell appears more plausible, given its size ($2 billion to $6 billion in annual sales), he said. "But it is still not obvious why Dell would be eager to acquire the assets," he said.
FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives calls any Dell-EMC deal a "major head-scratcher."
"It would be a very financially complex merger, high integration issues, and fundamentally would combine two very mature companies into one," he told Bloomberg.
But EMC CEO Joe Tucci is under pressure to boost returns for EMC investors, Ives said in a note late Wednesday.

"Joe Tucci and the EMC board have their backs against the wall as activist investor Elliott Management appears to have put enough heat in the kitchen to force this mature stalwart to figure out a strategic plan after years of struggles," Ives said. "Of all the options potentially on the table, we would view a merger with the now-private Dell as a 'nightmare scenario' that would lack strategic synergies and further complicate EMC's troubled growth path."

The information-technology industry "is ripe for consolidation," Macquarie Capital analyst Rajesh Ghai said in a report Thursday. "EMC, with its market leadership in the storage and virtualization markets, has significant strategic value and is likely to be the first candidate for consolidation."
A merger of EMC and Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) HP Enterprise would have more cost synergies than a merger with Dell, Ghai said. But Dell may be more willing to divest EMC's stake in VMware, he said.
HP stock rose 4.2% Thursday.
A Dell-EMC deal could kick off a wave of M&A activity in the IT infrastructure industry, William Blair analyst Jason Ader said in a report.

"Such a deal would be a response to massive secular changes occurring in the market," Ader said. "A deal of this magnitude would also effectively 'blow up' the current IT chess board, forcing the hand of other incumbent vendors to gain greater scale and/or assemble vertically integrated stacks."Enterprise data-storage company EMC saw its shares jump Thursday on reports that it could be acquired by privately held Dell, a deal analysts say could lead to more consolidation among the largest tech hardware and services companies.Dell is said to be in advanced talks with EMC (EMC) about a possible merger, as was first reported late Wednesday by the Wall Street Journal. The recent construction of an entire house by the Chinese 3D-printing company ZhuoDa Group is the latest sign that so-called additive manufacturing is going beyond small widgets and into such large-scale projects. Last year, China's Shanghai WinSun Decoration Design Engineering mass-produced 10 houses in less than 24 hours with a massive 3D printer that it developed. The printer is capable…

While it has yet to ship a single 3D printer, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is in a strong position to lead the market, says UBS. HP expects to begin delivering its first 3D printers in late 2016 and will target sales to businesses and other enterprises.HP's timing is good, says the investment bank, after the early 3D printer leaders Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD) encountered some big ups and big downs."The market was overhyped, with the technology still immature, resulting in roller-coaster rides for the stocks of Stratasys and 3D Systems," wrote UBS analyst Steven Milunovich in a research report. "However, we think the market is real and could be about $20 billion in 2020."Sales in the 3D printer market this year are estimated to come in at about $5 billion.Stratasys and 3D Systems are the two largest providers of 3D printers. The stock of both companies soared from early 2012 through early 2014. Then the stocks fell, on the reality that the industry had many mountains yet to climb."We think 3D printing is a significant long-term opportunity, but the technology is immature in terms of speed, quality and reliability, which has caused problems for Stratasys and 3D Systems," Milunovich wrote.He says that HP has solved bottlenecks holding back 3D printing, such as speed.It is "entirely believable that HP could become the leading 3D printing company," due to its current strength as a printing vendor, he wrote."Our view is that 3D printing is in the early innings of commercial implementation, with the industrial greater than the consumer opportunity," Milunovich wrote. "3D printing lacks economies of scale today for most applications. Over time, however, we believe 3D printing is on a path to overcoming its shortcomings in throughput, process stability, equipment life, post-processing elimination, materials know-how, production qualification and ease of use."Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.

A down week for stocks on Wall Street didn't prevent top management at some big names like Netflix (NFLX) and Google (GOOGL) from selling some of their own companies' shares.  Netflix CEO Reed Hastings on Monday filed for the planned sale of 90,860 shares for $9.2 million. On Friday, Netflix unveiled its first app for virtual reality headsets. The…

Lenovo held on to the top spot in PC market share in the fourth quarter, but former No. 1 Hewlett-Packard clawed its way back to within striking distance of the lead.Lenovo shipped 16.05 million personal computers worldwide in Q4, giving it 19.9% market share, research firm IDC reported late Monday. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) shipped 15.88 million PCs worldwide in Q4, giving it 19.7% market share, IDC said.Lenovo increased its PC unit shipments by 4.9% year over year, but HP grew its unit shipments by 15.1%, IDC said.Lenovo surpassed HP to become the No. 1 PC seller in world in Q2 2013. HP had been the top dog since late 2006, when it took the crown from Dell.Overall PC shipments fell 2.4% in the fourth quarter, IDC said. Rival research firm Gartner, which measures the market differently, said PC shipments rose 1% last quarter.IDC said the top five vendors each increased their unit shipments year over year, while all other vendors saw PC shipments decline 20.7%.Apple (AAPL) posted the fastest growth among the top five, IDC said. Apple increased its Mac computer shipments by 18.9% to 5.75 million units in Q4. It maintained its No. 5 ranking with 7.1% market share, IDC said.Rounding out the top five were Dell (13.5% market share) in third place and Acer (7.7%) in fourth, IDC reported.For the year, PC shipments fell 2.1% to 308.6 million units, IDC said. Gartner put the decline at 0.2%. It was the third straight year of declining PC volumes, IDC said."The strength from market leaders, as well as improvement in Asia-Pacific and the consumer market more generally, are positive signs for the PC market," IDC analyst Loren Loverde said in a statement.Gartner analyst Mikako Kitagawa said Q4 sales were boosted by improved consumer PC business and lower-priced notebooks."The fourth quarter of 2014 was the best holiday for PC sales in recent history," Kitagawa said in a statement. "The primary driver was mobile PCs including regular notebooks, thin and light notebooks and two-in-ones. Low priced notebooks with about a $200-$300 price point boosted shipments, while thin/light notebooks and two-in-ones (laptops with a detachable or bendable screen) showed strong growth. These results supports our assumption that consumer spending is returning to the PC as tablet penetration has reached the majority of the market."In the U.S. market, HP was the top PC vendor in Q4 with 30.1% market share. Dell was second with 23.8%, followed by Apple (12.7%), Lenovo (10.2%) and Toshiba (6.5%), IDC said.Later this year, HP plans to split into two publicly traded companies: Hewlett-Packard Enterprise will focus on servers, storage, networking, services and software; and HP Inc. will sell personal computers and printers.

Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.

Now that Carly Fiorina has gained some steam in her longshot bid for the Republican presidential nomination, more questions are surfacing about what she did — or failed to do — as CEO of Hewlett-Packard.
Fiorina left the tech giant more than a decade ago, but her controversial five-year-plus tenure leading the tech giant is her biggest claim to fame as voters try to assess her abilities.

The 60-year-old Fiorina has been relatively inactive since she was dismissed by the Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) board in February 2005, so her time at HP gets scrutiny as a barometer of her leadership capabilities.

Fiorina touts her HP experience as proof that she can deal with complex issues. And like Republican rival Donald Trump, Fiorina says her outsider status as a non-career politician with business sensibilities will bring a fresh outlook to the White House.
Just how good Fiorina was as CEO is a question with a lot of answers. Fiorina herself declined to comment for this story.

The highlight, or lowlight, of her HP days was pushing through a contentious acquisition of Compaq Computer, which made HP the No. 1 maker of PCs. (It's now No. 2, behind China's Lenovo.) The acquisition came with public fights with members of the Packard and Hewlett families, and the subsequent layoffs earned Fiorina the enmity of many former and current HP employees.
Others, though, consider the Compaq deal a big win for HP.

"I think she's gotten a bad rap," said Robert Wayman, HP's longtime CFO, who served under Fiorina and took over as interim CEO after she left. "More analysis would lead you to a different conclusion than she was just a failure. I do not think she was a failure."
Others say Fiorina's tenure as the first female chief executive of a Fortune 20 company was too full of potholes to be deemed a success.
Besides the awkward merger with Compaq, HP's stock flailed and the company's vaunted culture deteriorated, many say.

"I believe that if you're not some ISIS mass murderer, you're probably entitled to a second beginning," Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the Yale School of Management, told IBD. "But she's done nothing to (deserve) that redemption, other than wanting to be commander in chief."
Sonnenfeld recently wrote a piece for Fortune magazine examining Fiorina's qualifications.
After leaving HP, Fiorina made an unsuccessful bid for a California U.S. Senate seat in 2010, sat on several boards and served as a commentator on Fox News.
Fiorina was a surprise choice as HP CEO in 1999, to replace the retiring Lewis Platt. Fiorina had been running a division for Lucent Technologies, now Alcatel-Lucent (ALU).
She not only broke the glass ceiling at HP but was the first outsider hired to run the pioneering Silicon Valley stalwart, which was founded in a garage in 1939 by William Hewlett and David Packard.

The founders' vaunted principles, known as "The HP Way," fostered a collaborative and collegial atmosphere. Longtime HPers were mistrustful of outsider Fiorina, who responded by ... not cleaning house.
"Everyone thought I was going to be dismissed, that she would bring in her own team," Wayman said. "That just didn't happen."

One former HP executive from that period, who spoke only if not identified, said Fiorina violated the company's culture by laying off a few thousand employees within her first couple of years. While HP had made some employee buyouts in its past, these were its first involuntary layoffs.

The layoffs upset many employees, the executive said, but the big trauma for HP came in September 2001, about a week before the 9/11 attacks. Fiorina announced that the company would acquire Compaq for about $24 billion.
It was the defining moment in Fiorina's tenure, and the merger continues to be debated today.

Compaq led in PCs and was big in servers. But competition was fierce, and the timing hurt, with the deal coming amid the economic downturn sparked by 9/11. Detractors say HP was too late in making the move, with PCs fast becoming commodities.

Detractors say Fiorina mainly wanted to put her stamp on the company, instead of pursuing a strategy. Fiorina had failed months earlier to acquire a company in a completely different field, PricewaterhouseCoopers' management and tech consulting practice.
"It was a bad move," said Yale's Sonnenfeld of the Compaq deal.

The deal would result in roughly 15,000 people at the combined company losing their jobs because of overlap. The shareholder vote was close, with opposition led by sons of HP's co-founders, Walter Hewlett, who was then on HP's board, and David Woodley Packard.
Wayman says he warmed to the merger.
"It took me two to three weeks to really study what it might mean to us," he said. "But I became a big supporter of the merger. To this day, I think it was a good decision for the company."
Added the unidentified HP executive: "It was reasonable. It wasn't a crazy thing to do."
Fiorina wasn't looking to simply boost PC sales, the executive said. She wanted to make HP the leader in servers and a number of other product lines, able to trump the likes of IBM (IBM) and Dell.
"Dell was taking over the world — of PCs in particular, but they were also moving into servers," said Wayman. "This merger changed that. It absolutely did."
Mikako Kitagawa, an analyst with tech research firm Gartner, also liked the deal.
"Fifteen years ago, (the PC) was not a commodity," Kitagawa said. "The market stopped growing about five years ago. But up until then, it was growing."

Many investors didn't see the value in the Compaq deal. Two months after the May 2002 acquisition, HP's stock reached its lowest point in the Fiorina years, falling to 10.75, down 84% from its all-time high of 68.09 hit in July 2000, at the end of the dot-com bubble.

Detractors note that HP's stock underperformed IBM and Dell during Fiorina's tenure. HP stock lost about half its value from July 1999 through February 2005, vs. about 30% for IBM and just more than 3% for Dell.
But Dell soon had its own growth problems. When Dell turned private in October 2013, its shares were down nearly 80% from its dot-com era high. At that point, HP was off 63% from its high.

IBM's stock has done better. But HP did what might have been unthinkable in the 1990s and eclipsed Big Blue on the top line. HP continues to be bigger than IBM in revenue, though it trails far behind in market cap.Now that Carly Fiorina has gained some steam in her longshot bid for the Republican presidential nomination, more questions are surfacing about what she did — or failed to do — as CEO of Hewlett-Packard.Fiorina left the tech giant more than a decade ago, but her controversial five-year-plus tenure leading the tech giant is her biggest claim to fame as voters try to assess her abilities.The 60-year-old Fiorina has been relatively inactive since she was dismissed by the Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) board in February 2005, so her time at HP gets scrutiny as a barometer of her leadership capabilities.Fiorina touts her HP experience as proof that she can deal with complex issues.
