Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) enterprise unit will cut 25,000 to 30,000 jobs from its work force as part of the restructuring as it separates from HP's consumer operations, company officials said Tuesday.HP made the announcement at a meeting with analysts and later disclosed the plan publicly in a press release. The tech giant now has 302,000 employees worldwide across all its operations, and would end up with as few as 272,000 as a result of the enterprise unit cutbacks. Company officials told analysts they may do some rehiring once the restructuring is complete.Further guidance on HP's consumer unit, known as HP Inc., was expected later in the day but sources didn't expect the company to announce further layoffs from that division, which formally separates from the enterprise operations Nov. 1.The enterprise unit's restructuring is expected to take out $2.7 billion in annual costs, company officials said in a press release. The costs associated with the restructuring will amount to a $2.7 billion GAAP charge, beginning in the fourth quarter, and the move will impact cash by $2.6 billion over the next three years, starting in fiscal 2016."These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," HP Chief Executive Meg Whitman said in a prepared statement. "We've done a significant amount of work over the past few years to take costs out and simplify processes and these final actions will eliminate the need for any future corporate restructuring."RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a research note late Tuesday that the "expectation is that some of the savings will be invested back in the business and savings will be fully realized by fiscal-year 2017 to 2018 time frame."The reductions come three years after HP slashed 55,000 jobs in 2012.HP also said it expects 2016 earnings, excluding items, of $1.85 to $1.95 a share for the enterprise unit. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters have been expecting $3.72 in adjusted income per share for both the consumer and enterprise divisions in 2016, 2.8% up from 2015's expected $3.62. Revenue for the combined entity, however, is expected to drop 1.6% to $102.4 billion.HP stock ended Tuesday's regular trading session in the stock market today up marginally to 27.11, but was trading down more than 2% after hours.
Despite the release of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system, personal computer sales are expected to remain weak through early 2016, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) executives predicted Thursday.

On a conference call with analysts to discuss fiscal third-quarter earnings, HP executives were cautious on their outlook for PC and printer sales. "We now see a difficult business environment for at least several quarters to come," HP CEO Meg Whitman said.
Sluggish demand and competitive pricing pressures in PCs and printers could continue well into HP's next fiscal year, which starts Nov. 1, she said.

HP is splitting off its PC and printer business into a separate, publicly traded company called HP Inc. on Nov. 1. The remaining business, HP Enterprise, will focus on enterprise information technology.
HP's PC and printer revenue dropped 11% year over year to $12.56 billion in fiscal Q3, which ended July 31.
Revenue from its PC group was down 13% year over year. Commercial PC revenue decreased 9%, and consumer PC revenue fell 22%. Printing revenue dropped 9%.
HP Executive Vice President Dion Weisler, who will be CEO of HP Inc., says that the company is focused on gaining market share in key areas such as high-end consumer PCs.
"We're not chasing share for share's sake," Weisler said on the call. "And we're very selective about what are valuable units."
HP is not interested in chasing low-margin consumer PC sales, which Weisler called an "empty calorie business."
Windows Conversion Tough
The transition from Microsoft's Windows 8 PC operating system to the new Windows 10 will be challenging on a couple of fronts, he said.
First, Microsoft is making its latest operating system available as a free update to users of Windows 7 and 8 PCs for a year, extending the life of those existing PCs.

Also, HP and the industry have to work through their channel inventory of Windows 8 machines, he said. Many consumers paused their PC purchase decisions in anticipation of the Windows 10 launch on July 29, Whitman said.

"Management's tone on PCs was much more subdued than we expected, and our PC checks have not been great," BMO Capital Markets analyst Keith Bachman said in a research note Thursday. "PC margins are weak at 3% on a historical basis, and we don't think this changes near-term."
Hewlett-Packard is the world's second largest PC manufacturer by unit shipments behind China's Lenovo.
In Q2, Lenovo led the PC industry with 20.3% market share, followed by HP with 18.5% and Dell with 14.5%, according to market research firm IDC.
Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty said that HP might reset expectations for its PC and printer business at its financial analyst meeting on Sept. 15.

Whitman said that she expects consolidation to continue among the major PC manufacturers. The top six PC vendors were responsible for 74.2% of PC shipments in the second quarter, IDC says.Despite the release of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system, personal computer sales are expected to remain weak through early 2016, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) executives predicted Thursday.On a conference call with analysts to discuss fiscal third-quarter earnings, HP executives were cautious on their outlook for PC and printer sales. But shares…
Hewlett-Packard disappointed investors late Thursday with a mixed report for its fiscal third quarter and earnings guidance below views.
HP (HPQ) stock was down 1% after hours. During the regular session, HP shares dipped 1.4% to 27.35.
The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company earned 88 cents a share ex-items for the quarter ended July 31. That's down 1% from a year earlier but 3 cents above the 85 cents a share expected by Wall Street.
Earnings based on generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) came in low. HP said GAAP EPS fell 10% year over year to 47 cents, vs. analyst views for 55 cents.

Sales also missed, dropping 8% year over year to $25.35 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected sales of $25.44 billion in fiscal Q3. Excluding the impact of foreign currency exchange, HP's sales would have been down just 2%.
Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Brian White called HP's Q3 report "another uninspiring performance."

"Fiscal Q4 EPS outlook is light, supporting our cautious view on the company," he said in a research note. "Moreover, this was the 15th quarter out of the past 16 quarters that sales have declined on a year-over-year basis."
HP improved its flagging enterprise services unit and met its overall Q3 guidance while meeting goals for the upcoming corporate separation into two units, in November.

The company's PC and printer business was hit by market declines and competitive pricing pressures since May, HP CEO Meg Whitman said on a call with analysts late Thursday. "We now see a difficult business environment for at least several quarters to come," she said.

HP faced a "challenging macroeconomic and IT spending environment in the quarter, with soft consumer spending, continued weakness in Russia and China and stock market volatility driving uncertainty," Whitman said.

HP got 63% of its net revenue outside the U.S. in Q3. Several big tech companies have been hit by foreign currency headwinds in their latest-reported quarters, including Google (GOOGL), IBM (IBM) and Microsoft (MSFT).
On the conference call, Whitman said she was pleased with HP's progress on multiple fronts.

For the current quarter, HP's fiscal Q4, Wall Street had been modeling for EPS of $1 ex items, on sales of $26.82 billion. But HP guided to non-GAAP EPS of 92 to 98 cents, or 95 cents at the midpoint.

The Q3 report was the company's last before it splits into two publicly traded companies on Nov. 1. HP Enterprise will focus on enterprise information technology and HP Inc. will sell PCs and printers.
While the separation of HP into two companies makes sense, each of the businesses "are rapidly being commoditized and thus future growth potential appears limited," analyst White said in his note.

HP named the boards of directors for the two firms on Aug. 12. CEO Whitman will lead HP Enterprise. Dion Weisler, HP's executive vice president for printing and personal systems, will be CEO of HP Inc.

"HP delivered results in the third quarter that reflect very strong performance in our Enterprise Group and substantial progress in turning around Enterprise Services," Whitman said in a statement with the quarterly report. "I am very pleased that we have continued to deliver the results we said we would, while remaining on track to execute one of the largest and most complex separations ever undertaken."
Sluggish PC sales were a drag on HP's Q3 results. Revenue from its personal systems group was down 13% year over year. Commercial PC revenue decreased 9% and consumer PC revenue fell 22%.
Printing revenue dropped 9% year over year in the July quarter. HP's PC and printer revenue dropped 11% year over year to $12.56 billion.

Enterprise hardware sales were a bright spot, with revenue up 2%, driven by servers and networking gear. The end of an era is drawing near for tech behemoth Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and the company is laying the groundwork for its upcoming incarnation as two separate companies — one focused on enterprise technology and the other on personal computers and printers. HP on Wednesday announced the makeup of its two boards of directors, both of which will include HP's…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) appears to be making progress as it works through the third year of a five-year restructuring process launched in May 2012 and prepares for a company split into two entities by the end of next year.
That's the assessment from several analysts after the global computer product giant reported a mixed bag of fourth-quarter results after the market close on Tuesday. Here is IBD's report.
HP's restructuring process involves putting more emphasis on emerging markets, including cloud computing, Big Data and security, to offset declining growth in other businesses such as printing.
In a Wednesday report, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, called HP's Q4 performance "a decent end to a strong year." He has a neutral rating on the company.

"Although light revenue was the headline after the close, we aren't too concerned, as improving margin performance was a positive offset," he wrote. "HP continues to have some momentum due to improved products, cost savings to protect profits, the coming breakup that adds modest value, and the roll-out of Meg Whitman's 'Playing to Win' approach borrowed from Procter & Gamble."
Others agreed.
In a report late Tuesday, Maynard Um, an analyst for Wells Fargo Securities, says HP is making significant strides in its restructuring plan. He has an outperform rating on the company.

"We believe HP has largely turned the corner and is well positioned in a number of segments — share gain potential in PCs, strong portfolio and cycles in servers, improvement in services, a bottoming of supplies in printing, improved margins across its segments, strong cash flow generation, good growth in new higher margin businesses (networking, security, Big Data, Inkjet Pro X) and catch-up share repurchases ahead," he wrote. "While it doesn't change the secular forces in the industry and the impact to HP, we think the company is much better positioned to move forward than it has been in quite some time."

In a report late Tuesday, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, noted that healthy notebook PC growth of 9% was masked by a revenue shortfall in the enterprise group, which declined 4% vs. the year-earlier period. Storage and industry-standard servers revenue also fell by the most in over a year.

But HP's coming separation, which would place its PC and printer groups in one company and its enterprise and software businesses in another, could help reaccelerate the company's growth, Bracelin wrote.
"We are maintaining our outperform rating based on the separation that could enhance shareholder value and justify upside to $40 (a share)," he wrote.
Some investors seem to share the analyst optimism. Shares rose more than 3% in the stock market today.

But some analysts remain cautious. In a report Wednesday, Ambrish Srivastava, an analyst for BMO Capital Markets, said that while the coming split will likely drive the stock higher, several questions remain. He has a market perform rating on the company.

"Will total costs increase in fiscal year 2016 post-split, since HP will have to carry two public companies? Can HP grow revenues, even post-split (more nimble and more focused)? Until we satisfy our concerns surrounding these two questions, we choose to sit on the sidelines," he wrote.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) appears to be making progress as it works through the third year of a five-year restructuring process launched in May 2012 and prepares for a company split into two entities by the end of next year.That's the assessment from several analysts after the global computer product giant reported a mixed bag of fourth-quarter results after the market close on Tuesday. "HP continues to have some momentum due to improved products, cost savings to protect profits, the coming breakup that adds modest value, and the roll-out of Meg Whitman's 'Playing to Win' approach borrowed from Procter & Gamble."Others agreed.In a report late Tuesday, Maynard Um, an analyst for Wells Fargo Securities, says HP is making significant strides in its restructuring plan. Hewlett-Packard's road to revenue growth has hit another pothole.The computer products giant reported a mixed bag of fiscal fourth-quarter numbers late Tuesday as the company continues to work through a restructuring that will include splitting it into two separate entities by the end of next year.The company's Q4 sales missed analyst views, while its earnings for the quarter were merely in line.Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) earnings forecast for the current quarter was lighter than expected.Shares fell about 1% in after-hours trading. HP stock ended the regular session up a fraction at 37.63.HP's revenue fell 2% year over year to $28.4 billion in the quarter ended Oct. 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a 1.2% decline to $28.76 billion.HP reported earnings per share minus items of $1.06, up 5% from the year-earlier period and in line with analyst estimates.The company's 2% decline in revenue in Q4 failed to match the 1% year-over-year revenue growth in the prior quarter, which had been its first positive revenue gain in 11 quarters dating back to July 2011. HP's sales miss comes even as the company posted its fourth consecutive quarter with year-over-year revenue growth in its PC business.HP has been scrambling to move into newer areas such as cloud computing and Big Data to offset declining growth in its printing and other businesses.The company launched what is expected to be a five-year restructuring effort in May 2012.But HP's third-quarter growth was more of an anomaly than a new direction for the company — at least for now, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald."When you look at the big picture of HP and you look at all of the different businesses, there is really not one market where you can say, 'That is going to take off in terms of revenue,'" he told IBD. "Whether it's services or the enterprise group, PCs or printers — none of them is really growing, or at least the markets are not growing at respectable rates."For the current quarter, HP said it expects earnings per share of 89 to 93 cents, or a decline of 1.1% to an increase of 3.3%.Analysts had modeled for 93 cents EPS and revenue to decline by 2.1% to $27.55 billion. HP doesn't provide a revenue forecast.For the full year, HP said it expects EPS of $3.83 to $4.03, up 2.4% to 7.7%.Analysts have been expecting $3.94 EPS, or growth of 5.3%, and revenue of $110.35 billion, down 1%.During a conference call with analysts, HP CEO Meg Whitman expressed confidence in the company's direction."Overall, I'm very pleased with the progress we have made," she said. "On the top line, I have always said that turnarounds aren't linear and, while we are seeing clear pockets of growth, other areas still need more work. But overall our revenue performance has improved dramatically over the past three years."HP will keep a sharp focus on its fundamental operations, she said, including its cost structure and supply chain.As in prior quarters, HP's line items reveal a company with more misses than hits.Revenue from the company's personal systems group, which is mostly PCs, increased 4% year over year to $8.94 billion.Sales of notebooks increased 9% to $4.86 billion while desktops decreased 3% to $3.18 billion.Printing revenue declined 5% to $5.74 billion.Sales of supplies slipped 7% to $3.59 billion.HP stock is up 35% year to date through Tuesday's close. Investors might be buying into the promise that HP can carve a niche in the growing 3D printing market after it announced the development of a product last month that is expected to be ready for sale in 2016, White says."The 3D dream helps the perception around the stock," he said. "The market does believe in 3D printing, and they are definitely a leader in printing."Revenue from HP's enterprise group, including servers, storage and networking systems, declined 4% to $7.27 billion.Sales of industry standard servers fell 2% to $3.37 billion.Technology services revenue decreased 3% to $2.11 billion.Enterprise services revenue declined 7% to $5.51 billion.Sales of infrastructure technology outsourcing fell 7% to $3.44 billion, while revenue from application and business services fell 6% to $2.06 billion.HP will need more than just a resurging PC business to reaccelerate its growth, White says."It comes back to (the question): Is this portfolio positioned for Big Data, cloud, Internet of Things, things that are major trends?" he said. "I don't think it's as well positioned as other companies."Even though HP plans to split the company into two separate companies, the challenge for the company doesn't end there, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for IDC."The bigger challenge is for the personal systems side as well as the enterprise side to actually show the market that they have entered a period where they can show sustained growth," he told IBD.

OpenStack could soon be the software that runs the non-Amazon cloud.Open-source software available for free, OpenStack helps corporate IT departments manage data centers packed with computer servers.OpenStack has also gained popularity as a tool to connect data centers to public clouds, where computing resources are shared via the Internet.But Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services (AWS) is by far the biggest provider of infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS). And it uses its own software, not OpenStack.Still, OpenStack has gained popularity among enterprises that want to use multiple cloud platforms.For investors, the question is: which companies will gain the most from OpenStack's rise as a cloud operating system?"There's a big roster of household name IT vendors that are backing OpenStack — Intel (INTC), IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dell and HP (HPQ) — a lot of companies have placed a bet," said Al Sadowski, an analyst at 451 Research.Worries over whether OpenStack could handle large business workloads have eased. So OpenStack seems primed for wide adoption, though there are open-source rivals such as Citrix Systems' (CTXS) CloudStack, points out James Staten, a Forrester Research analyst."The concerns now are less about the platform itself and who is influencing its development," Staten told IBD. "The concerns instead are about who takes OpenStack successfully to market and begins to lead through market power. That's a key theme worth watching in 2015."Rackspace, NASA DevelopedRackspace Hosting (RAX) and government space agency NASA co-developed OpenStack in 2010, aiming to make the software a cloud computing standard. Rackspace's main business has been hosting websites. Rackspace stepped up investments in OpenStack in 2012 and 2013, but its revenue growth slowed as companies lingered in testing OpenStack's capabilities.Rackspace now supports multiple cloud platforms and has become less dependent on OpenStack near term."While Rackspace continues to develop solutions on the OpenStack platform, management is providing managed cloud solutions across multiple technologies," wrote James Breen, a William Blair analyst, in a research report last month.The OpenStack ecosystem is growing, says 451 Research. The market research firm says that OpenStack-related revenue will rise to $3.49 billion in 2018 from $890 million in 2014."All OpenStack needs to do is get to the same reliability and resiliency as the computing platforms it's replacing," Sadowski said. "It's clear, though, that OpenStack is gaining mindshare and marketing power."Early backers hoped that OpenStack would slow the march of AWS. Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan estimates that AWS revenue will jump 40% to roughly $5 billion in 2015. Even so, "OpenStack is starting to mature as enterprises shift legacy IT workloads to cloud environments," Horan said.Expedia (EXPE), Walt Disney (DIS), Time Warner Cable (TWC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and BMW are among recent OpenStack adopters, says 451 Research. Earlier users included eBay's (EBAY) PayPal, Best Buy (BBY) and Fidelity Investments.To attract corporate customers, OpenStack supporters positioned the open-source software as an alternative to VMware 's (VMW) software, widely used in data centers to make servers more efficient.Red Hat (RHT), the leading provider of Linux open-source server software and a VMware rival, has lined up behind OpenStack.But pushing its own cloud platform is still VMware's top priority, analysts say. With partners such as the privately held Mirantis, VMware sells software that helps its customers use OpenStack for building so-called "private" cloud data centers that are accessible by branch offices, clients and others.Analysts say that most enterprises are interested in a public-private hybrid cloud model — running the most important business apps on their own servers behind a private corporate firewall and accessing public IaaS providers as needed.Many tech vendors are focused on providing tools for hybrid clouds. Rackspace aims to provide managed services in the hybrid cloud market rather than struggle vs. much bigger IaaS firms AWS, Microsoft (MSFT) and Google (GOOGL).Positioned As Cloud Concierge"Rackspace continues to remain technology agnostic even as the company's OpenStack is increasingly attractive as a platform for public cloud," said Barclays analyst Sandeep Gupta in a report. "As AWS, Microsoft and Google continue to put pressure on pricing, we wouldn't be surprised if Rackspace positions itself as a cloud concierge to a hybrid cloud environment."Many tech suppliers aim to use OpenStack to bridge private and public clouds."The strong leaders in OpenStack today are a mix. Hewlett-Packard and Red Hat are clearly strong voices in the community, as is SuSE, Mirantis, Internap (INAP) and arguably Cisco Systems due to their recent moves," said Forrester's Staten. "Rackspace still has a strong voice, IBM to a lesser degree, as they are really only focusing on it for their private cloud initiatives."IBM last year acquired cloud-service firm SoftLayer for $2 billion. HP has said that it'll spend $1 billion over the next two years on products and services around OpenStack.451 Research says that Europe-based OVH and startup Blue Box have gained traction with OpenStack customers. Some companies are using acquisitions to gain a foothold in cloud computing services and OpenStack. EMC (EMC), another cloud company, acquired Cloudscaling in October, Cisco bought Metacloud in September and Red Hat purchased eNovance in June.Lydia Leong, an analyst with research firm Gartner, agrees that OpenStack has gained momentum. The OpenStack Foundation, with more than 430 members, has regularly rolled out improved versions of the software."OpenStack is gaining more traction than it had before as the product starts to become more useable," Leong told IBD. "The primary beneficiaries are those that sell (software) distributions, such as Red Hat, HP and Mirantis."

On Wednesday, at least one analyst said that this announcement won't mean much for troubled…
Now, Amazon (AMZN) is talking real quick delivery.

The company announced Thursday that it's launched a one-hour bicycle delivery service in Manhattan for Prime members that buy eligible daily items through a mobile app — confirming earlier reports that such a program was in the works.

The service, called Prime Now, for now is starting only in select areas of Manhattan. It's slated to be rolled out to more U.S. cities in 2015. The cost for a one-hour delivery in Manhattan is $7.99 for buyers of such everyday essentials as batteries, towels, shampoo and books. But two-hour deliveries are free.

Amazon says its new building at 34th Street in Manhattan in New York City is serving as the bike base and operations hub for local Prime Now orders. The company says tens of thousands of items are on its list of eligible products.

Prime Now is open to Amazon customers who pay the $99 annual Prime membership fee. Amazon says the new service is made possible by Amazon's expanding network of fulfillment centers that use cutting-edge technology to accelerate order delivery times for customers.

Prime members in Manhattan can download the Prime Now app, which is available on Apple (AAPL) iOS and Android devices, on Amazon.com. Prime members will be notified when the service is available in their local area. Prime Now is available from 6 a.m. to midnight, seven days a week.
Amazon stock was down more than 1% in morning trading in the stock market today.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) might not show much progress on reaccelerating its revenue growth when the company reports its fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, analysts say.
Analysts expect revenue to slip 1.2% from the year-earlier quarter. Three months ago, HP posted a 1.3% year-over-year revenue gain for the first time in 11 quarters.
HP is amid a restructuring effort as it focuses on emerging growth areas such as cloud services and Big Data to offset declines or slowing growth in its computer and printer businesses.
Last month, HP announced it would split itself into two separate companies, on for PCs and printers and the other enterprise services. It plans to complete the split by the end of next year.

HP's recent $2 billion on share buybacks, however, prompted Sherri Scribner, an analyst for Deutsche Bank, to add 5 cents per share to her EPS estimates for fiscal 2015 and 2016, and to boost her price target on HP stock to 45 from 40.
Scribner now expects EPS minus items of $4 for 2015 and $4.15 in 2016, where the consensus analyst estimates are 3.94 and 4.19. She rates HP stock a buy.

"We have raised our price target to $45 from $40, driven by our higher fiscal year 2015 estimate EPS and by higher multiple of 11x (vs. 10x previously)," she wrote in a research note. "An 11x multiple is in line with HP's historical average multiple and in line with peers."

She said downside risks include an inability to deliver on restructuring plans, lack of growth from PCs and printers, risk of cannibalization from the cloud and the split not taking place, for whatever reason.
For fiscal Q4, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of $1.06, up 4.9% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to fall to $28.7 billion.
For the current quarter, analysts expect an EPS of 93 cents, up 3.3% and revenue to decline 2% to $27.55 billion.
HP stock was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 37.50 and near a more than three-year high of 38.25 touched in September. HP stock is up nearly 35% this year.
Investors are likely buying in on the promise of future performance, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold.

"What HP has going for it is its restructuring initiatives and the fact that they are going to split the company in two," White told IBD. Hewlett-Packard's  (HPQ) decision to resume its stock repurchase program likely means that any potential merger with software giant EMC (EMC) is now off the table. HP on Wednesday issued a press release saying that it will resume its share repurchase program after previously suspending activity "due to the possession of material non-public information," the company said. Cloud-based communications and storage company J2 Global aims to acquire the remaining shares of backup services provider Carbonite that it doesn't already own.

Los Angeles-based J2 Global (JCOM) submitted a non-binding proposal to acquire shares of Carbonite (CARB) for $15 per share, or about $366.4 million, according to an SEC filing. J2 Global provides Internet cloud-based software for government agencies as well as for digital media companies and other businesses.

Boston-based Carbonite said in a press release on Wednesday that it has received the unsolicited proposal from J2 Global and that its board of directors will "carefully review and consider the offer."
Carbonite stock was near 14.40, up 22% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Shares of J2 Global were near 60, up 5%.

The J2 Global filing comes after a $10.50 per share offer that it made to acquire Carbonite back in August 2012 — an offer that Carbonite rejected, FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives said in a research report on Wednesday.

"To this point, we believe J2 Global is more apt to 'play hardball' (as evidenced by the 28% premium to Carbonite's closing price on Tuesday) this time around as it represents a more opportune time to finally consume Carbonite, given the underlying business momentum at J2," Ives said.

On Nov. 5, 2012, J2 Global said in an SEC filing that Carbonite had rejected its acquisition offer without making a counteroffer. J2 Global said in the filing that it still hoped to discuss the potential purchase with Carbonite.
Ives sees the proposed acquisition as "a smart move" because J2 Global has been eyeing Carbonite for the last few years.

"With J2 successfully integrating its media acquisitions (Ziff Davis, IGN and others) into the fold over the last year and hitting on all cylinders across the board, we believe J2 is ready to take this step in the online backup segment — thus complementing its organic initiatives and providing major cross-sell opportunities over the coming years," Ives said.
Ives adds that J2 Global's management team has done "a commendable job of picking the right spaces" that make sense for the company to expand its growth.

"While this potential transaction is not a total shock to the Street, given the existing relationship between J2 and Carbonite, the key question now will be Carbonite's move in this game of high-stakes poker, as the company has experienced execution issues and business challenges over the past few years," Ives said. "We ultimately believe the $15 bid is a fair price and should be a move applauded by J2 investors as it speaks to a company looking to expand growth opportunities, given inherent challenges in its core fax business."
RELATED:

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.
Several analysts Tuesday said they're skeptical about an unsolicited bid by Chinese chipmaker Tsinghua Unigroup for Boise, Idaho-based Micron Technology (MU).

The Wall Street Journal, citing unnamed sources, reported Monday that China state-owned company Tsinghua Unigroup "has prepared a $23 billion bid," about $21 a share, to buy memory chipmaker Micron. Micron stock closed Monday at 17.61, so the offer would be a 19% premium.

In a July 2 research note, Summit Research Partners analyst Srini Sundararajan said Micron is a likely acquisition candidate for the Chinese government, which aims to establish a dynamic random access memory (DRAM) fabrication plant in China.
In a research note Tuesday, Sundararajan said it's "hard to imagine Micron being satisfied with such a low-ball bid."

Sundararajan said that Micron's investor relations and representatives said they have yet to receive an offer in writing, "so this could be a trial balloon to figure out how Micron's management and shareholders think of such an offer."

Micron stock was up nearly 12% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 20. Micron is trading 19% below a 13-year high touched in December. Micron stock hit a 21-month low of 17.14 on Thursday.

Tsinghua is the largest state-owned chip designer in China, after acquiring Spreadtrum Communications in 2013 and RDA Microelectronics last year. In May, Tsinghua acquired a controlling stake in Hewlett-Packard's (HP) China-based networking equipment unit.
In September, Intel (INTC) announced an agreement with Tsinghua to pay about $1.5 billion to acquire a 20% stake in Spreadtrum and RDA.
Intel stock was up a fraction in midday trading Tuesday, near 30.
Micron makes DRAM memory chips and Nand flash-memory chips, which are used to store data in smartphones and other mobile devices.
U.S. Might Object

UBS analyst Stephen Chin said in a research report Tuesday that Tsinghua's offer "could make sense but appears low," and he said the U.S. government might object to any such deal, viewing DRAM as an "economically sensitive technology given that all servers and network switches use it."

Chin also said that replicating Micron's memory fabs in China could be difficult given a talent shortage in semiconductors and limited research and development synergies with Tsinghua's wireless semiconductor assets.
Micron manufactures many of its chips in U.S. factories, but also has fabs in Singapore and Taiwan.
Cowen and Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri cited several reasons why the deal might not make sense for Micron shareholders.

"First, we think that the U.S. Department of Justice would not allow this to happen given the increasingly strategic nature of DRAM to Intel and the U.S. technology sector," Arcuri said in a research report. "We also doubt that Tsinghua would be able to effectively manage Micron's manufacturing assets in the U.S."

Chin said it's possible China made the bid "solely in order to show it remains committed to building a larger semiconductor industry despite the significant stock market correction in its domestic market." Chin says Tsinghua's unsolicited bid goes against the pattern of its previous deals.

Sundararajan, however, said antitrust issues could be less of a hurdle than imagined because Tsinghua has friendly relations with Intel, "whose advice carries a lot of weight with the U.S. Department of Justice."
RELATED:

Worldwide spending on cloud computing infrastructure rose 25.1% year over year in the first quarter to nearly $6.3 billion. That is the second largest total spending in at least the last nine quarters, market research firm IDC says.Cloud IT infrastructure spending climbed to nearly 30% of overall IT infrastructure spending in Q1, up from 26.4% a year ago, IDC said in a report Thursday. That includes spending on servers, storage and ethernet switches to power public and private cloud systems.Non-cloud IT infrastructure spending grew just 6.1% year over year in the first quarter, IDC said."Cloud IT infrastructure growth continues to outpace the growth of the overall IT infrastructure market, driven by the transition of workloads onto cloud-based platforms," IDC analyst Kuba Stolarski said in a statement. "Both private and public cloud infrastructures have been growing at a similar pace, suggesting that customers are open to a broad array of hybrid deployment scenarios as they modernize their IT for the 3rd Platform, begin to deploy next-gen software solutions, and embrace modern management processes that enable agile, flexible, and extensible cloud platforms."Among cloud hardware vendors, the top three companies outpaced the overall cloud infrastructure market and gained market share in Q1.No. 1 vendor Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) increased its cloud infrastructure revenue by 37.4% year over year in Q1 to $985 million. Its market share rose to 15.7% from 14.3% a year earlier.No. 2 vendor Dell grew its cloud hardware sales by 34.2% to $745 million. Its market share increased to 11.9% from 11.1% in Q1 2014.The third largest vendor, Cisco Systems (CSCO), increased its cloud infrastructure revenue by 30.1% to $582 million. Its market share climbed to 9.3% from 8.9% a year earlier.Fourth place vendor, EMC (EMC), trailed the overall market with year-over-year growth of 23.5%.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped as much as 8.5% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted fiscal Q4 revenue that beat views and guided fiscal 2016 performance better than analysts expected.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended the day at 14.12, up 3.1%."Our overall opinion on HPE remains unchanged" after the earnings call, wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research report. He said the stock "already reflects an anticipated stabilization in some of its most troubled areas."He said positives include growth in large, tier-one hyperscale servers, while negatives included a decline in services revenue."Overall, the outlook for FY16 is unchanged (albeit more back-end loaded) and the stock is likely range-bound at current levels," said Kugele, who maintained a hold rating on HPE stock.Responding to those who say HPE isn't selling enough services and products in the cloud, company CEO Meg Whitman told CNBC Wednesday that spending for private cloud products — networks and data centers that businesses keep in-house, which is HPE's focus — is growing as fast as public cloud. "Most people don't understand that," she said."Yesterday, we announced that we were partnering with Microsoft (MFST) Azure to provide the public cloud," she told CNBC. "And then we have this great cloud system automation that helps you orchestrate your clouds in your data center. So if you think about where the money is spent today, interestingly, still about 85% of the spend is in traditional I.T. ... The next-biggest segment is private cloud. And the next after that is public cloud. And private and public cloud are growing at about the same rate."So we are going right to the heart of what our customers are asking. And I feel really good about our strategy and excited about the partnership that we announced yesterday with Microsoft Azure."Microsoft Azure competes with market leader Amazon Web Services, a unit of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and others in providing public cloud services.Needham's Kugele liked the Azure partnership and the fact that HPE was "abdicating" in the public cloud sector, but he pointed out that Azure is fighting against AWS, "and ultimate success is going to be a marathon and not a sprint."New Era BeginsEnterprise is roughly half — most analysts say the more promising half — of the Nov. 1 split of the legendary 76-year-old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other half, HP Inc. (HPQ), focuses on the PC and printer businesses, and it kept the old HPQ ticker.The Q4 report was the last for the old company, which Whitman also chaired. It earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Enterprise's pro forma portion of Q4 sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion but was up 3% in constant currency. Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion.Enterprise reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.Whitman told analysts in the conference call following Tuesday's earnings release that HPE "will double down on our private and managed cloud (efforts), and sunset our public cloud." Of "the move to a hybrid cloud environment ... you can expect to hear more."Needham analyst Kugele said that with HPE still on its way to 30,000 layoffs, and the service business determined to "drag its margins higher through careful contract signings, we are most focused on the storage and server opportunity for HPE. In servers, the lumpy buying pattern of tier-1 hyperscale customers helped them in the quarter but is hardly consistently reliable."Nevertheless we expect the segment to show slight growth in fiscal '16."He said storage has benefited from "aggressive pricing," but he sees more competition from rivals such as NetApp (NTAP) and Pure Storage (PSTG)."Bottom line, there are more puts and takes and caveats than investors should accept in a long thesis," Kugele wrote. "Staying on the sidelines."

Newly minted PC and printer company HP Inc. (HPQ) late Tuesday gave its first guidance as a publicly traded company — and it was a letdown. For the current quarter, HP Inc.'s fiscal Q1, it expects earnings per share minus items of 33 to 38 cents, vs. analyst expectations for 42 cents. On a GAAP basis, it is targeting EPS…

Hewlett-Packard continues to stumble toward its split-up this year. The computer products giant reported mixed Q2 earnings after the close Thursday, with EPS beating Wall Street expectations but revenue coming in short.
HP's (HPQ) earnings outlook for the current quarter also was light.

Still, HP stock was up more than 1% in after-hours trading, after it released its results for the quarter ended April 30. HP stock rose 2.3% in Thursday's regular session but is down more than 15% this year.
HP has struggled to reaccelerate growth. The company has posted a year-over-year decline in revenue in every quarter but one — a 1% rise — since July 2011.

HP launched a five-year restructuring effort in May 2012 to expand into emerging growth areas including cloud services, Big Data and security to offset declines in its core PC and printing businesses. The company made a little noise in March with an agreement to acquire Aruba Networks for $2.7 billion to boost its wireless business.
With its split-up, HP will create one company focused on its PCs and printers and another focused on enterprise hardware, services and software.
But HP faces many challenges, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald.

"I don't think there is any driver (for revenue growth)," White told IBD. "HP, as a story, has been: How bad is it going to get? They did a massive restructuring that is still in the works. They have done a great job marketing that story, but there is no real fundamental driver."
For fiscal Q2, HP reported earnings per share minus items of 87 cents, down 1% from 88 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 85 cents.
Sales fell 7% to $25.5 billion. Analysts had expected $25.6 billion.
Guides To Lower EPS
For the current quarter, HP expects EPS ex items of 83 cents to 87 cents, at the midpoint down 4.5% from the year-ago quarter.
Analysts had modeled 87 cents, on revenue of $25.87 billion, down 6.1%. HP doesn't provide a revenue outlook.

In the company's earnings conference call with analysts, HP CEO Meg Whitman said the company is on track with its restructuring plan, despite a challenging market and execution issues in software and networking, in particular.
"We executed well in a tough market environment," she said. "We continue to invest in innovation across the company and improve our go-to-market approach.

"At the same time, we face significant market challenges due to currency movements, softness in PCs, home printing and IT outsourcing markets, and execution challenges in pockets of the business that require more work. But overall, I'm pleased with our progress in the turnaround."
As in past quarters, HP's Q2 contained more misses than hits.

Notebooks and industry standard servers were the only two product segments that posted year-over-year sales growth. The enterprise group showed some promise by declining only 1%, to $6.56 billion. But enterprise services revenue fell 16% to $4.81 billion.
"The enterprise business is going through the biggest change in 30 years," White said. "Everyone is trying to figure it out.
"I just don't think they have a portfolio that is differentiated enough to say that, at the end of this major transition, they are going to come out a major winner."
Revenue from the personal systems group, which is mostly PCs, fell 5% to $7.74 billion.

Notebook computer sales rose 5% to $4.17 billion, but desktop computer sales fell 17% to $2.76 billion. Industry standard servers grew 11% to $3.13 billion, but workstation sales fell 6% to $513 million.
"The PC market is starting to fall off again," White said. "We started to see that in March, and the IT landscape is just ultracompetitive, especially in the commoditized parts that they play in."

Sunnyvale, Calif.,-based Ruckus, a maker of Wi-Fi networking gear, competes with Aruba Networks in the enterprise market. In March, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) agreed to acquire Aruba Networks for…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) continues to stumble as it gets closer to its split later this year.The computer products giant reported mixed Q2 earnings after the close Thursday, with EPS beating Wall Street expectations but revenue coming in short. HP's earnings outlook for the current quarter also was on the light side. Still, HP stock was up 1% in after-hours trading, after…

The silver lining for Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), with its Q2 earnings posted late Thursday, appears to be more about cost savings than growth.The computer products company posted a mixed bag of earnings numbers for the quarter ended April 30, but still HP stock was up Friday.Along with reporting EPS that was 2 cents better than expected, HP said that costs associated with its move to split into two companies will be $400 million to $450 million, where some analysts had expected up to $1 billion.HP stock was up 3% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 35.The results could have been far worse, says Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities in a report Friday. He rates HP stock at outperform."The bottom line is that this was a mixed report but not as bad as some had feared in light of HP's foreign exchange risk due to high international exposure (65% revenue), and expected dis-synergy costs (associated with the split) came in lower than expected," he wrote.HP continues to slog through a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 and aimed at pushing new initiatives, including the cloud and security, to offset revenue growth decline in PCs and printers. The company has failed to post steady quarterly year-over-year revenue growth since July 2011. Splitting the company into two entities with PCs and printers in one company and enterprise services, equipment and software in the other is expected to help solve that issue.HP still has a lot of work to do, Seyrafi says."Key concerns in the report include enterprise services revenue, down 16% year-over-year and 6% below consensus due to key account runoffs, weakness in EMEA, and IT outsourcing; ... desktop weakness as desktop units declined by 14% year-over-year due to less end-of-(Microsoft (MSFT) XP support benefit compared to last year and slight pause in front of W10; printing margins declining to 3% from 3.7% in the first quarter with weakness in consumer printing due to strong competition from Japanese competitors (Canon (CAJ), Epson), which are being price aggressive (note that consumer hardware revenue declined by 18% year-over-year, and consumer units declined by 6% year-over-year, so the average selling price decline here was over 10% year-over-year); and some deceleration on a constant currency basis year-over-year in EMEA and Asia-Pacific, Japan," he wrote.

Tsinghua Holdings, a group owned by China's Tsinghua University, will purchase the stake in a new business called H3C. HP stock…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) will have a lot to prove when it reports its fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday.The computer products giant aims to rebound from its first-quarter earnings report, which included revenue that fell short of analyst estimates. Sales fell or were flat across all six of HP's business sectors. HP stock tumbled nearly 10% on Feb. 25, the day following its earnings report, to a seven-month low. HP stock is down more than 15% this year.Prior to Q1, HP had been building a groundswell of support from investors as the company gets closer to splitting into two separate companies, with PCs and printers in one company and enterprise services, equipment and software in the other. The split is expected to occur in October.HP is also amid a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 aimed at placing more emphasis on emerging growth areas, including the cloud and security, as PC and printer growth slows.HP is in a quandary by operating in a difficult PC and printer market while trying to compete with rivals such as Accenture (ACN) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) in the enterprise services and equipment businesses, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold."PCs is obviously a very difficult business," White told IBD. "though they did pretty well last year. And they do a good job in printing, but it's kind of a secular, declining business."They are not really great at the enterprise side. In services, they kind of stubbed their own toe and weren't investing in the right places and making promises (to customers) that they didn't deliver on... . I don't think there is anything to look at in services and say that is a great growing business for them."EPS, Sales Both Seen FallingThis month, Cisco reported stronger-than-expected April-quarter earnings that included growth in its data center enterprise business.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of 85 cents, down 3.4% from the year-earlier quarter. That would be its first EPS decline in six quarters.Revenue is expected to fall 6% to $25.65 billion, which would be its worst showing in the past seven quarters.For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS to fall 2.2% to 87 cents and revenue to fall 6.1% to $25.88 billion.HP's coming split should boost its shares, Sherri Scribner, an analyst for Deutsche Bank, said in a May 14 research report. She has a buy rating on HP stock."We view HP as well positioned to benefit from growth in emerging segments like Big Data and converged infrastructure, and expect further operating margin improvements in HP's enterprise business," she wrote. "With shares not currently reflecting HP's strong industry position, growth opportunities and operating margin expansion, we view current valuations as attractive and the stock remains one of our top picks for 2015."While many investors have focused on near-term negative synergies of the deal, we believe the split will create positive synergies for the company, which should offset any negative synergies over the longer term."

Some companies will slowly bump up their dividends from time to time; Helmerich & Payne (HP) is not one of them.On Wednesday, the company more than tripled its quarterly dividend to 50 cents from 15 cents a share for its fiscal Q3 ending June 30. Helmerich & Payne will pay the dividend Aug. 30 to shareholders of record Aug. 15."We are pleased to be in position to deliver a meaningful level of yield to our shareholders while retaining a strong ability to continue to pursue growth opportunities," said Chairman and CEO Hans Helmerich in a press release.Helmerich & Payne had already sharply increased its dividend for its fiscal first quarter. The firm has hiked its dividend each year for more than 40 years.At the new rate, Helmerich & Payne pays $2 a share each year, giving it a yield of about 3.2%. It has one of the highest yields among the 10 dividend-paying stocks in the Oil & Gas-Drilling group.Helmerich & Payne drills oil and gas wells for oil and gas exploration companies in the U.S. and abroad. Weather, oil and gas prices, the economy and foreign country risks can impact its bottom line.In 2009, earnings fell due to contract terminations stemming from lower commodity prices and tough credit conditions. Profit was also down in 2010, hurt by losses from discontinued operations in Venezuela. The Venezuelan government seized its rigs and other property. The declines weigh on its Earnings Per Share Rating, which is 75.Helmerich & Payne is in a cup-with-handle base with a 66.12 buy point. The current pattern's correction of 20% is less than half of its prior base.While the market is having a tough time this week, Helmerich & Payne is holding just above its 50-day moving average.

ServiceNow (NOW) may have found the ticket to becoming a multibillion-dollar revenue company, but it will put the company in competition with a new and bigger rival.
The enterprise software company is expanding its core IT service-management (ITSM) software into new areas, including human resources, sales and marketing departments.

Already known as one of the fastest growing companies in the technology space, ServiceNow gave its followers a taste of its new capabilities on April 23 when it reported that 34% of its revenue in Q1 came from outside of its core IT service-management business.
Revenues in Q1 grew 62% vs. the year-ago period. The company also expects annual revenue to grow to as much as $657 million this year. That's up 55% from a year ago.
But ServiceNow's product expansion could set the company on a much larger growth path in the next few years, says Kirk Materne, an analyst for Evercore Partners.

"They can keep growing at those levels just in their core market for the foreseeable future, but it's more important when you look at three to five years down the road in terms of the company developing into a multibillion-dollar revenue company," he said.

Though the company's core IT service-management market is still growing at a strong pace, it's probably not enough to satisfy the company's desire for additional revenue growth, says J. Derrick Wood, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group.

"I'm sure they look and say, 'We want to be a $5 billion (a year) revenue company,' and you are probably not going to do that just by being in ITSM," he said. "They have aspirations to be a lot bigger company, and they have built a much broader portfolio to go after new opportunities."

ServiceNow has been growing at the expense of rivals CA (CA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and others through its core software service, which allows companies with multiple offices to manage information requests among several departments and devices. The company's Internet-based cloud software has become a preferred alternative and replacement for bigger vendors that sell older products through a license model.
But ServiceNow appears positioned to grow beyond its core business of providing software to power service desks for IT departments, says Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co.

"Management is taking that concept outside of IT and into the HR department, the sales department and the marketing department," he said. "This is the first time where their product has been purchased at a very high level within the organization with the intent of using it more broadly."
Bumping Into Salesforce.com
ServiceNow's expansion is earning the company a new rivalry with Salesforce.com (CRM), the leading maker of cloud-based customer-relationship management software.
The company's stepped-up effort is running up against Salesforce's service cloud, which helps companies better manage their work with customers, says Frank Slootman, ServiceNow's chief executive.

"We see them regularly when we get closer to what they direct their service cloud at, which is these customer-facing type of applications," he told IBD. "That is typically where it's possible for us to come in contention with Salesforce."
Some analysts believe that ServiceNow's expansion effort will also bring the company into competition with Workday (WDAY).
But Slootman says that the leading provider of cloud-based human-resource management software services is a business partner and not a rival because each serves different needs.

"(When) people have requests, they have to manage knowledge and they have problems with benefits or pay, that happens in our system; and when the records themselves have to be changed about employees or policies, that happens in Workday," he said. "They are a system of record, and we are a system of engagement."
ServiceNow is expanding beyond IT service desks in response to customers who want better ways to manage information requests in other departments and across entire companies, Slootman says.

"Any department that has to respond to service requests from other people or other departments or other organizations, and it becomes a repeatable high volume of activity, a service-management system becomes incredibly important, because the amount of resources that gets consumed with these activities is insane," he said.

Fueling the demand are companies using older, licensed-based systems produced by companies including CA, HP, IBM (IBM) and Microsoft (MSFT). Some companies even manage their data exchanges through reams of spreadsheets and e-mail, Slootman says.

"Those are the people that we replace," he said. "Those are legacy vendors; they are typically not involved in new projects."ServiceNow (NOW) may have found the ticket to becoming a multibillion-dollar revenue company, but it will put the company in competition with a new and bigger rival.The enterprise software company is expanding its core IT service-management (ITSM) software into new areas, including human resources, sales and marketing departments.Already known as one of the fastest growing companies in the technology space, ServiceNow gave its followers a taste of its new capabilities on April 23 when it reported that 34% of its revenue in Q1 came from outside of its core IT service-management business.Revenues in Q1 grew 62% vs. the year-ago period. Worldwide personal computer shipments fell 11.8% year over year to 66.1 million units in the second quarter. But Apple (AAPL) defied the overall market trend and saw its Mac shipments rise 16.1% to 5.14 million units, research firm IDC said late Thursday.Apple was the only top 5 PC vendor to show an increase in shipments last quarter, IDC said. It ranked No. 4 behind Lenovo, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Dell.Though they all experienced year-over-year declines in PC shipments in Q2, Lenovo, HP and Dell gained market share because their declines were less than the overall market.China-based Lenovo was tops with 20.3% market share in Q2, up from 19.4% a year earlier, IDC said. Its shipments dropped 7.5% year over year.Palo Alto, Calif.-based HP was No. 2 with an 18.5% market share, up from 18.2%. Its PC shipments fell 10.4%.Round Rock, Texas-based Dell was No. 3 with a 14.5% market share, up from 14%. Its PC shipments fell 8.7%.The PC market's year-over-year decline was 11.8%, a little more than expected, IDC said.The market faced tough year-over-year comparisons because of the surge in PC buying last year related to Microsoft (MSFT) ending support for its popular but aging Windows XP operating system, prodding many users to upgrade to newer PCs. Also, sales channels last quarter reduced their inventories ahead of the July 29 launch of Windows 10, IDC said.Plus, weaker exchange rates for foreign currencies led to increased PC prices in many markets and reduced purchasing power, IDC said."Although the second-quarter decline in PC shipments was significant, and slightly more than expected, the overall trend fits with expectations," IDC analyst Loren Loverde said in a statement. "We continue to expect low to mid-single digit declines in volume during the second half of the year, with volume stabilizing in future years."PC shipments in the U.S. fell 3.3% to 16.4 million units, IDC said.Rival market research firm Gartner late Thursday said global PC shipments declined 9.5% to 68.4 million units. It expects PC shipments to fall 4.4% in 2015.

Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

Box (BOX) stock gapped up as much as 15.8% in early trading Thursday after the company late Wednesday reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss and raised its full-year revenue outlook on strong corporate demand for its cloud data storage products.

"The first quarter showed solid improvement from the prior quarter as billings accelerated to the highest growth level in over a year and other financial metrics, including revenue, operating margin and cash flow, all exceeded expectations," Rob Owens, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, wrote in a research report. He maintained a neutral rating on Box stock, however.

"The quarter was punctuated by the addition of over 2,000 new paying customers and a push into enterprise accounts such as Deloitte, HP, Nationwide Insurance, Chipotle, the U.S. Department of Justice and the U.K.'s Government Digital Service," Owens said. "Box now boasts over half of the Fortune 500 as customers."
Owens added that customer acquisition costs remain a concern.
Los Altos, Calif.-based Box said revenue rose 45% to $65.6 million for its fiscal Q1 ended April 30 vs. the year-earlier quarter, topping Wall Street views.

For the current quarter, Box forecast revenue of $69.5 million at the midpoint of its range vs. consensus estimates of $67 million. Box said it expects fiscal 2016 revenue of $286 million to $290 million, up from its earlier guidance of $281 million to $285 million.
The online storage and file management provider reported a loss of 28 cents compared with 29 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had modeled a 31-cent per-share loss.
Under a freemium business model, Box provides consumers with free personal data storage accounts.

"Box signed over 2,000 new paying customers in the quarter, bringing the total to over 47,000," Richard Davis, analyst at Canaccord Genuity, said in a report. "The company now counts over 37 million users, with the number of paying users growing 70% year over year and now making up over 10% of the base.
"The company also reported that the cost to support free users is now roughly 14% of revenue, down from 18% last year."

Canaccord edged up its price target on Box stock to 21 from 20. Box stock was up 10%, near 20, in early trading in the stock market today. Earlier, Box stock touched a three-month high of 20.60. Box made its IPO in January, pricing its shares at 14.

One big concern about Box is its competition, which includes such tech heavyweights as Microsoft (MSFT), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Google (GOOGL), along with privately held Dropbox and others.Box (BOX) stock gapped up as much as 15.8% in early trading Thursday after the company late Wednesday reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss and raised its full-year revenue outlook on strong corporate demand for its cloud data storage products."The first quarter showed solid improvement from the prior quarter as billings accelerated to the highest growth level in over a year and other financial metrics, including revenue, operating margin and cash flow, all exceeded expectations," Rob Owens, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, wrote in a research report. Lenovo and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), the top two sellers of personal computers worldwide, were the only major PC vendors to increase their PC shipments year over year in the first quarter.
Overall PC shipments fell more than 5% vs. Q1 2014, market researchers Gartner and IDC reported late Thursday. Gartner put the decline at 5.2%, while IDC said shipments fell 6.7%.
Q1 shipments of 68.5 million PCs in the first quarter marked the lowest recorded volume since Q1 2009, IDC said.
PC shipments faced multiple headwinds last quarter, including an inventory buildup of low-cost Windows Bing-based notebooks and a slowdown in commercial buying after the Windows XP refresh cycle.

PC sales likely will get a boost this summer from the release of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system, IDC analyst Rajani Singh said in a statement. There is still a pent-up demand to replace older PCs, she said. Windows 10 is expected to combine the best of Windows 7 and Windows 8, the two prior generations of the PC operating system.
"Only part of the installed base needs to replace systems to keep the overall growth rate above zero for the rest of the year," Singh said.

China-based Lenovo remained the top PC vendor in Q1, with a global market share of 19.6%. Gartner pegged Lenovo's market share at 18.9%. IDC and Gartner estimated Lenovo's year-over-year PC shipment growth to be 3.4% and 5.7%, respectively, in Q1.
Lenovo experienced its strongest growth in Europe and the U.S. It has become one of the top providers of hybrid notebooks, especially its Yoga line in mature markets, Gartner said.

"This quarter and for the last two consecutive years, Lenovo again maintained the No. 1 position in the worldwide PC market by demonstrating outstanding innovation in the PC product line," Lenovo CEO Yang Yuanqing said in a statement. "PCs remain at the heart of our business, delivering 65% of our revenue and record pre-tax income last quarter of almost $500 million. Given industry consolidation, Lenovo's consistent focus on innovation and delivering award-winning PCs, and our ongoing momentum, we are confident that PCs will continue to be a great engine of strong, profitable growth."
HP stayed in second place with 19% market share, IDC said. Gartner put HP's market share at 17.3%. IDC and Gartner estimated HP's PC shipment growth to be 3.3% and 2.5%, respectively, in Q1.

Other major vendors, including Dell and Acer, saw their PC shipments drop with the overall market last quarter.Lenovo and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), the top two sellers of personal computers worldwide, were the only major PC vendors to increase their PC shipments year over year in the first quarter.Overall PC shipments fell more than 5% vs. Q1 2014, market researchers Gartner and IDC reported late Thursday. Stocks came out of the gate with a bang.....moving higher in the early seconds after the bell rang only to weaken as the mins ticked by......at 10:20 - the mkt was not only negative but was testing support .......and like I said in yesterday's note - it found the buyers......that's all it needed. The fact that the mkt failed to 'break' WAS the positive and it was off to the races...... By 3:30 - the indexes were once again flirting with their highs....and Nasdaq? Well that index was not only flirting, it was teasing traders and investors - daring them to push it up and thru its March 2000 high of 5048.....But alas - that was not to be yesterday.....and it may have a bit of trouble today as well....at least until investors have a chance to react to the disappointing tech numbers reported after the bell last night.

Now - let's put this in perspective....Facebook (FB) - which everyone was waiting for - did not disappoint.... Sales rose by 42%....not bad, but the afterhours crowd was looking for 49%...so those bozo's were disappointed and took 2 1/2% out of the stock in the moments following the release....Now - revenue growth was impacted by the stronger dollar - and since FB generates more than 50% of its revenue overseas - then you can see the impact that the strong dollar had....BUT we KNEW THIS.....And since they don't 'produce' a product overseas - they did not get the benefit of weaker foreign currencies like so many of the multi-nationals are getting... In the end - earnings of 42 cts were ABOVE the 40 cts expectation and well above a year ago of 35 cts.... So - get over yourself....This was not a negative report....In early pre-mkt trading - the stock is holding right in line at $83.65 - which was yesterday's low...Now on Tuesday - the stock did gap up - just a bit - so technically - it might want to go back and 'fill that gap' at $83.15......and then after that...well - I suspect it could go on to challenge the March highs of $86/sh.

Texas Instruments (TXN) and Qualcomm (QCOM) - well those are different issues - and in fact more concerning...as they missed on earnings and 'lowered forward guidance'.....So my sense is that these stocks will cause investors to focus on the negatives....causing the mkt to once again stall - for now.

Look - Earnings results so far from 110 companies reported in the S&P are on track to fall 4% from a year earlier.... The S&P is trading at 17.4 X's the previous 12 months' earnings, - this is 17% ABOVE the historical 10-yr average of 14.6 X's...... This is why the mkt has been tossing and turning of late.....We are trading above historical averages all while U.S. economic indicators continue to miss and disappoint causing long term investors to sit tight - thus the lack of real commitment and volumes......

One of the most interesting reads on this are the 'Economic Surprise Indexes' that exist across the street. Citigroup (C) has one, BB has one and both are negative as of the 20th......In fact the BB Surprise Index is making fresh lows......The index measures whether the eco data is beating or missing forecasts, and the fact that it is sitting at its lowest level since the end of the GFC (Great Financial Crisis) - should be just a bit concerning....Next week we get 1Q GDP, which we know is not going to be 'robust' , the Atlanta Fed is projecting growth of ZERO and yet here we are testing new highs. Does anyone else suspect a disconnect? Is someone 'spoofing' us?

Next week (28/29) we will hear from the FED - you can expect to hear more about a weak global economy, strong dollar, weak earnings, zero GDP growth and lack of inflation - all as reasons for caution in the months ahead.....June is OFF the table - rates not going anywhere.....August is most likely off the table as well - but they will not close that door in April......they need to keep hope alive that rates will begin the move higher......with probably no real intent on doing anything as long as the US economy continues to waffle back and forth. NY Fed Pres. Dudley had this to say:

"While I am relatively optimistic about the growth outlook for 2015, I also must acknowledge that there are some significant downside risks...in particular the 15% appreciation of the exchange value of the dollar since mid 2014 is making US exports more expensive and imports more competitive"
(The strong dollar is expected to reduce GDP growth by about 0.6%).

Speaking of 'spoofing' - have you seen the latest on the story of the week? Exchanges in both the US and Europe had this clown on 'trader watch' - identifying numerous suspicious trades over a period of months....very large orders entered and then cancelled over and over.....in '09 and '10 they even questioned his actions...telling him that on the very day of the crash that "orders are expected to be entered in good faith for the purpose of executing bona fide transactions".

How's that working for you? It wasn't until 2012 when the still unknown whistle blower identified all of these suspicious trades dated May 6th. The CFTC (Commodities Futures Trading Commission) saying that they do NOT have the technology to monitor cancelled trades in 'real time' hindering their ability to police the mkt...( you mean to tell me that technology can follow me around the world, knowing everything about me yet - we can't monitor trades in a completely electronic world?) ...Gary Gensler former head of the CFTC, former GS MD, and now Hillary's CFO for her Presidential campaign, issues a 104 page report explaining the cause of the flash crash and admits that they never even looked at spoofing, layering , manipulation or order cancellations....... You can't make this up...who would believe it?
