Hewlett-Packard showed some muscle in the fledgling Network Functions Virtualization market by beating Cisco Systems, VMware and others in signing telecom carrier Telefonica to a multiyear pact.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is one of several tech giants scrambling to offer NFV, a virtualization computing system that relies more on software than hardware to help service providers speed an increasing amount of data through their networks at a reduced cost.Besides Cisco Systems (CSCO) and VMware (VMW), other NFV providers include Juniper Networks (JNPR).HP will fuel Telefonica's Unica project. Telefonica is moving all of its services, including Internet and mobile, to a new platform driven by NFV and software-defined networking, another technology system where software presides over hardware. The project will take several years.Spain-based Telefonica (TEF) is a large telecom operating in 21 countries, mostly in Europe and Latin America.HP is stepping up its NFV efforts, launched only last year, as the company gets closer to splitting into two separate companies. One will focus on PCs and printers, the other on enterprise products and services.Signing Telefonica should boost HP's revenue and set a bar for rivals in the NFV market, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC."It's a nice win in advance of the split," Del Prete told IBD. "Carriers are going to be moving more toward these network functions and virtualization environments. This is a big industry shift that is going to be measured in billions."UBS on Tuesday upgraded HP to buy from neutral and hiked its 12-month price target to 40 from 37.25. HP stock is trading near 33. In a research report, UBS analyst Steve Milunovich said, "(HP Enterprise is) too hardware-dependent but improving. Software and services need to pick up, or HP Enterprise might be forced to merge with another larger computing vendor."With the Telefonica contract, HP has seemingly leapfrogged rivals in what looks to be a very large market, says Roz Roseboro, an analyst for Heavy Reading, a market research firm that focuses solely on the telecom market."From an endorsement standpoint, it's very big," she told IBD. "The market right now is very much up in the air in terms of who is going to end up in the lead position with all of this NFV transformation."HP provides NFV services for several customers, but Telefonica is a milestone for the company, says Saar Gillai, general manager of HP's NFV program."This is our biggest deal in terms of providing end-to-end capabilities across our entire portfolio with open NFV," he told IBD.Not all of HP's rivals can handle such a large NFV migration, Gillai says."We are uniquely positioned in this space because a lot of the traditional vendors are playing defense — they have a lot of existing systems that are in the old architecture, and they are not necessarily that motivated to get the new architecture that quickly," he said.Other vendors, such as Cisco, are stepping up their efforts in the NFV and SDN markets, said Amitabh Passi, an analyst for UBS Securities, in a March 2 research report."Unlike years past, Cisco is more openly embracing shifts to software defined networking and Network Functions Virtualization, and in fact accelerating the shift to software and cloud services," he wrote.Several other telecom carriers, including AT&T (T) and Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), are in the process of adopting NFV.Reducing costs and streamlining networks are top priorities, says Roseboro."They are moving from a world where you have lots of different boxes that are specialized to do one thing and moving all of that onto more commodity servers, which allows you to lower your capex," she said. "And once it's virtualized, you can start using some other kind of IT tools to automate a lot of your processes and reduce your opex quite significantly."Gillai declined to put a value on the Telefonica contract."I can say that it's meaningful revenue, and it's also an indicator of things to come," he said.HP's revenue needs a boost. In the quarter ended Jan. 31, its enterprise revenue was flat with the year-earlier quarter, at $6.98 billion. And its enterprise services revenue fell 11% to $4.99 billion.

Google (GOOG) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) have officially recalled their HP Chromebook 11 power supply chargers due to fire and burn hazards.

The announcement, made through the U.S. Product Safety Commission on Tuesday, warned consumers that "the computer's charger can overheat and melt, posing fire and burn hazards" and that the unit should be replaced. The agency says consumers should contact Google for a free replacement charger.

The CPSC says the recall affects about 145,000 Chromebook 11 rechargers that were sold at Best Buy (BBY) stores nationally, on Amazon.com (AMZN), at Bestbuy.com, at Play.google.com and at Shopping.hp.com from October through November. The recharger units were included with the Chromebook 11, which sold for about $280.
Google and HP yanked the Chromebook laptop from the market in November, citing the possible fire hazard. The charger was made in China.
Related: Google Seen Readying 'Viewable' Online Ad Strategy.

Hewlett-Packard is taking aim at Cisco Systems with its bid to buy Aruba Networks, but HP might not be done making acquisitions before its split-up, analysts say.

The struggling computer maker early Monday confirmed plans to acquire Aruba for $24.67 a share, or about $3 billion. The deal, which both boards have approved, is expected to close in the second half of HP's fiscal year, ending Oct. 31.
Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) stock rose a fraction Monday. Aruba stock jumped 35% last week as reports of the pending deal surfaced.
Among wireless networking equipment vendors, Aruba is No. 2 to Cisco (CSCO), the No. 1 maker of computer networking equipment.
HP is also in the Wi-Fi market, but is far behind Cisco or Aruba.
Acquiring Aruba will change that, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC.
"This definitely moves them to be competing more with Cisco than any other (Wi-Fi) networking supplier today," Del Prete told IBD.
HP aims to boost its networking business, Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald, said in a research report Monday.

"Given HP's bigger push into the networking market over the past few years that included the acquisition of 3Com in 2010, we believe the planned acquisition of Aruba Networks complements HP's existing networking portfolio," he wrote.

As of Sept. 30, Aruba had an 11.5% share of the wireless local area network gear market, IDC says. Aruba trailed only Cisco's commanding 48.4% share. HP was No. 4 at a 5.8% share. Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) ranked No. 3 at 6.3%, says IDC.
Analysts say Aruba will bolster HP's enterprise group business, which reported revenue of $6.98 billion for its fiscal Q1 ended Jan. 31, flat vs. the year-earlier period.
Before year's end, HP plans to split into two separate companies, one focused on the PC and printer businesses and the other on its enterprise and software businesses.

The company is also working through a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 that involves building up emerging growth areas, including mobile, security and the cloud, to offset little or no growth in PCs and printers.
"They need to be able to show they have the IT assets to keep the enterprise group growing," Del Prete said.
White, however, says HP can choose better targets.
"Although we believe this deal expands HP's networking portfolio, we believe HP's capital would be better spent on cloud and Big Data software vendors," he wrote.
Enterprise software companies will likely be HP's next targets, Del Prete says. In Q1, HP's software sales fell nearly 5% year over year.

"They are not moving fast enough in software," he said. "They need to continue to build out that portfolio, particularly around information management, security and Big Data — and it's just not there yet."Hewlett-Packard is taking aim at Cisco Systems with its bid to buy Aruba Networks, but HP might not be done making acquisitions before its split-up, analysts say.The struggling computer maker early Monday confirmed plans to acquire Aruba for $24.67 a share, or about $3 billion. Dell rose from dorm-room startup to global giant during the 1990s as a PC maker stayed focused on businesses with its build-to-order, direct sales model.
That's not to say it didn't try to tap the retail market.

"Even though we were tempted and did venture off into some areas that didn't prove very attractive for us, the core direct-business model was so powerful that it kept chugging along and did very well for us," founder Michael Dell told IBD in 1999.

But that laser focus also might have caused it to miss the industry's shift to the consumer market as businesses slowed their spending. Dell got blindsided by the rapid rise of ultraportable devices such as tablets and smartphones, and fell behind the curve.

Struggling since the mid-2000s, Michael Dell took the company private last year. The company continues to serve the corporate PC market, where it remains a leader as it emphasizes services and more. But it's also boosting its presence in tablets, software and services.
One key constant, analysts say, has been Dell's strong customer relations.

"Dell was able to emerge as this player that was able to provide custom-built PCs very quickly and had strong direct engagement with customers," said Krista Macomber, an analyst with Technology Business Research. "As a result, the business was able to grow, and Dell was able to really establish itself as a partner with customers.
"We see that even today. Dell is the IT department for many of its midmarket customers."
The Round Rock, Texas-based company shook up the PC industry with its custom-built, mail-order business model.

The PC business, which Michael Dell famously started out of his University of Texas dorm room, thrived on his concept of building the machines at low cost to customer specifications using commodity components from high-volume electronics manufacturers. Efficient assembly, logistics and just-in-time inventory management sparked Dell's success.

The streamlined business model enabled Dell to sell at lower prices than others, often 15% or so lower. Some other companies also offered build-to-order PCs at low prices, but were not considered up to par with Dell's quality.
Michael Dell said tailoring personal computers to user preferences would make Dell computers easier to use and troubleshoot. And if users had problems, Dell's customer service was a phone call away.

Turned out he was right. He launched Dell Computer Corp. in 1984 with $1,000 and a few employees. By 1995, the company employed more than 7,000 people in 15 countries and boasted $3.5 billion in sales.
High-End Yet Affordable

The company became known for its relatively affordable but high-quality PCs and reliable customer service — keys to its tremendous success against stalwart rivals such as Compaq Computer, IBM (IBM), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Gateway.
Dell's stock surged a staggering 124,000% from its February 1990 low to its April 2000 peak.
While Dell continues, many of its 1990s PC rivals are gone. HP bought Compaq in 2001. IBM sold its PC business to China's Lenovo in 2005. China's Acer bought Gateway in 2007.
Dell's secret to its longtime success in the corporate market goes back to the strong relationships it formed with customers, analysts say.
"That was a very big differentiator for Dell ... . It helped Dell to keep a pulse on its customers and what they needed with their technology," Macomber said.

Michael Dell conducted his own due diligence by surfing the Internet to gather insight on market trends, speaking directly with customers to find out how they use technology, and walking around at trade shows testing out the latest technology.

"In an industry that changes as fast as ours, where product innovation is a constant, if you don't know how your customer feels you're in trouble," Michael Dell told IBD in a 1996 interview. "It's important to deal directly with the customer."
He also made sure to keep the communication lines open within the company, bringing brown-bag lunches and discussing strategy with employees.

"My job is to communicate what's going on inside the company and make employees feel proud," he said in '96. "I try to develop an environment that's self-critical and challenging, and encourage people to speak up."
In 1992, the then-27-year-old became the youngest chief executive to run a Fortune 500 company. As CEO, he earned a reputation as a straight-shooter who knew his stuff but didn't crave the spotlight.

In presentations to analysts, "my feeling is that I'm getting the truth, not spin," Kurt King, an analyst with Montgomery Securities at the time, told IBD in 1996. "With other CEOs, you sometimes get campaign speeches, and you have to discount some of what they say.

Yet for many years, the company's build-to-order computers were not attractive to consumers, since some key components, including the Intel (INTC) chips that it mostly used, could be expensive, making PCs often too pricey for most consumers.

Asked by IBD in a 1995 interview if the company was missing out by not catering to consumers, Michael Dell responded: "Given the multitude of options we have, we see the consumer market as the least attractive of them. We're more focused on expanding in the business market. Dell is outgrowing the industry and key competitors in a profitable way. If we weren't, then that would be a more interesting question."
'Dude' TV Commercials
Dell, though, became a force in the consumer market in the early 2000s, when it started running TV commercials with the popular catchphrase, "Dude, you're getting a Dell!"
But businesses still accounted for the bulk of its sales, and as PC spending by companies began to slow in the mid- to late 2000s, so did the PC maker's revenue growth.
Michael Dell resigned as CEO in 2004 but remained chairman as he handed the reins to Kevin Rollins. In 2007, Rollins stepped down and Michael Dell became chief again.
That same year, the company finally began selling Dell systems through retailers, enabling potential customers to see, touch and try out PCs and laptops before making a purchase.

In his return as CEO, Dell made management changes, closed plants and cut jobs. Then, in February 2013, Michael Dell and Silver Lake Partners announced a $24.4 billion leveraged buyout, taking the company private. The deal closed in October, 25 years after Dell first went public.
Today, besides PC competitors such as HP, Acer, Asus and Lenovo, Dell faces Apple (AAPL) and Google 's (GOOGL) Android on the consumer tablet front.
Dell's commercial business is still larger than its consumer segment.

"Dell was not able to get ahead of these trends and so as a result, for example, its consumer notebook market share was declining quite rapidly, particularly in 2012," Macomber said. "It re-entered the entry tablet space last year, so we think this will help them in the consumer marketplace."

Dell might face some tough sledding as it tries to grow share in the consumer market, but its customer-engagement reputation could again become the differentiator as it competes in tablets, software and other newer markets.

"I think Dell is going to be certainly a competitor to watch over the next couple of years," Macomber said. "It's a private company now, so this means that it has a lot more leeway to act strategically on a longer time horizon. We think Dell is going to be focused on really disrupting markets and vying for leadership in all of its markets."Dell rose from dorm-room startup to global giant during the 1990s as a PC maker stayed focused on businesses with its build-to-order, direct sales model.That's not to say it didn't try to tap the retail market."Even though we were tempted and did venture off into some areas that didn't prove very attractive for us, the core direct-business model was so powerful that it kept chugging along and did very well for us," founder Michael Dell told IBD in 1999.But that laser focus also might have caused it to miss the industry's shift to the consumer market as businesses slowed their spending. Dell got blindsided by the rapid rise of ultraportable devices such as tablets and smartphones, and fell behind the curve.Struggling since the mid-2000s, Michael Dell took the company private last year. The company continues to serve the corporate PC market, where it remains a leader as it emphasizes services and more. But it's also boosting its presence in tablets, software and services.One key constant, analysts say, has been Dell's strong customer relations."Dell was able to emerge as this player that was able to provide custom-built PCs very quickly and had strong direct engagement with customers," said Krista Macomber, an analyst with Technology Business Research. "As a result, the business was able to grow, and Dell was able to really establish itself as a partner with customers."We see that even today. Dell is the IT department for many of its midmarket customers."The Round Rock, Texas-based company shook up the PC industry with its custom-built, mail-order business model.The PC business, which Michael Dell famously started out of his University of Texas dorm room, thrived on his concept of building the machines at low cost to customer specifications using commodity components from high-volume electronics manufacturers. Efficient assembly, logistics and just-in-time inventory management sparked Dell's success.The streamlined business model enabled Dell to sell at lower prices than others, often 15% or so lower. Some other companies also offered build-to-order PCs at low prices, but were not considered up to par with Dell's quality.Michael Dell said tailoring personal computers to user preferences would make Dell computers easier to use and troubleshoot. And if users had problems, Dell's customer service was a phone call away.Turned out he was right. He launched Dell Computer Corp. in 1984 with $1,000 and a few employees. By 1995, the company employed more than 7,000 people in 15 countries and boasted $3.5 billion in sales.High-End Yet AffordableThe company became known for its relatively affordable but high-quality PCs and reliable customer service — keys to its tremendous success against stalwart rivals such as Compaq Computer, IBM (IBM), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Gateway.Dell's stock surged a staggering 124,000% from its February 1990 low to its April 2000 peak.While Dell continues, many of its 1990s PC rivals are gone. Revenue for HP's fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31 fell 3% from the year-earlier quarter to $29.1 billion, but that beat the $27.9 billion expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. It marked the smallest sales decline…

ServiceNow (NOW) also won high marks for avoiding uncertain economic conditions and other pitfalls plaguing many enterprise tech companies this earnings season. Analysts say that the company is on track to expand its market opportunity outside of its core IT service…

IBM stock dropped after the company fell well short of third-quarter earnings estimates, lowered its forecasts and announced it would sell its chip division.
The broad-based tech vendor said it is selling its chip manufacturing business to Santa Clara, Calif.-based GlobalFoundries for $1.5 billion.

IBM (IBM) early Monday reported adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $3.68 per share, below the consensus estimate of $4.31, as polled by Thomson Reuters. Earnings fell 10% from the year-earlier quarter, reversing four straight quarters of double-digit gains.
IBM had been scheduled to report its Q3 earnings after the close Monday.
IBM stock was down 7.5% in early-afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 168.50, and earlier touched a nearly three-year low.

IBM now expects 2014 operating EPS to fall 2% to 4% from the $16.64 it reported in 2013. It had previously projected 2014 earnings of at least $18 a share. It no longer expects to deliver at least $20 operating EPS in 2015, which had been a long-standing goal.

GlobalFoundries will acquire and operate existing IBM semiconductor manufacturing operations and facilities in East Fishkill, N.Y., and Essex Junction, Vt. GlobalFoundries was founded in 2009 through a partnership between Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Advanced Technology Investment.
IBM said Q3 revenue fell 4% to $22.4 billion. That missed the consensus estimate of $23.7 billion and was IBM's 10th quarter in a row of declining revenue.
IBM has shed many of its hardware unit operations as it transforms to focus on growth areas that include cloud computing, Big Data analytics, mobile computing and security.
The company this month completed the sale of its low-end server business for $2.3 billion to China's Lenovo Group and sold its PC business to Lenovo in 2005.

IBM said a business slowdown during September hurt sales. But the company also said that it experienced business execution issues. The strength in the U.S. dollar also impacted results and is expected to have more impact ahead, IBM said.

"We are disappointed in our performance," IBM CEO Ginni Rometty said in the company's earnings release. "We saw a marked slowdown in September in client buying behavior, and our results also point to the unprecedented pace of change in our industry."
Rometty said IBM "performed well" in strategic growth areas where IBM is continuing to shift its businesses. These include cloud computing, data analytics, security and mobile.

"Management commentary was quite negative, indicating disappointment in performance, a marked slowdown in September client buying behavior, and the need to accelerate its transformation," wrote Steven Milunovich, an analyst at UBS, in a research report. "Shrinking in hardware makes sense, but IBM has not shown improving momentum in software and services.
"Our problem is that two-thirds of revenue is legacy and that IBM's hope of keeping revenue and margins flat is a stretch given technology disruption."

Sales of IBM's servers, mainframes and other hardware products have slowed as those products go through transitions and market changes. Rivals such as Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) are also making their own similar transition in the face of below-average industry spending on information technology. HP this month announced it would split into two companies, one focused on PCs and printers and the other on enterprise products and services.

But in his research report early Wednesday, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin also was quick to add, of the turnaround, that "we are not sure it…
Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) remains a work in progress.
The global computer products giant isn't expected to do any better than meet analyst expectations when it reports its fiscal fourth-quarter results after the market close Tuesday.

HP is working through a troublesome restructuring process with a plan to build up its enterprise, software, storage and other businesses to offset declining and flat growth in its core PC and printing units. HP is the world's No. 2 PC seller, having lost its crown to China-based Lenovo.
For the quarter ended Oct. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of $1, down from $1.16 in the year-earlier quarter.
Revenue is expected to fall 6.8% to $27.9 billion.

"We expect HP to report fiscal Q4 in line with expectations as PC/server stabilization is offset by federal/EM (emerging market) head winds," Katy Huberty, an analyst for Morgan Stanley, wrote in a research note Friday.
The company faces the same market factors affecting its peers, Amit Daryanani, an analyst for RBC Capital Markets, said in a research note Thursday.

"We think HP, like its peers (IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO), EMC (EMC), NetApp (NTAP) etc.) witnessed head winds within Asia-Pacific (China) and U.S. federal," he wrote. "Positively, HP may have seen more stable trends within printing as they saw muted benefits from back-to-school coupled with lean inventory in the channel.
"PCs should remain a focal point during the quarter, not so much for the revenue/EPS contribution but rather implications to free cash flow."
For the current quarter, analysts expect HP to report EPS ex items, of 85 cents, up from 82 cents in the year-ago period.
Revenue is expected to fall 5.4% to $26.8 billion.

After a scary morning sell-off, stocks rebounded and were trading mixed in the final hour of trading on little news and with volume lightened by the Columbus Day holiday.
The Nasdaq was flat, the S&P 500 was down 0.2% and the Dow Jones was down 0.1% in the stock market today.

But growth stocks were still staggered by the morning decline. Among IBD 50 stocks, 18 were up and 32 were down. The top performer was Chinese automobile website Autohome (ATHM), up nearly 5%. But volume was running well below average and the stock is recovering from a steep sell-off from a failed breakout.

The worst performer was Lithia Motors (LAD), down 19% after issuing an earnings warning. The stock looked like it was building a new base until Monday's gap down. Auto-related issues have fared poorly in the past few weeks.

Shutterfly (SFLY) dropped nearly 10% in the wake of a report that Silver Lake Management has decided not to pursue the acquisition of Shutterfly along with Snapfish from Hewlett-Packard (HPQ). HP was also down, but recovering and finding support at its 200-day line.

Two recent stellar performers, GoPro (GPRO) and Mobileye (MBLY), were also suffering declines. Action sports camera maker GoPro was down more than 8%, its fourth straight down day. The stock nearly doubled after breaking out of an IPO base in early September. It was down nearly 5% Friday.

Mobileye, which develops technology for driver-assisted automobiles, was off 3%, but well off its lows of the day. Hewlett-Packard going splitsville could lead to a marriage down the road to EMC or some other suitors.
The computer giant early Monday said it would split into two separate companies, one focused on PCs and printers and the other on products and services for companies and other enterprises.

While each company individually would still be huge, at more than $50 billion in annual sales, cleaving HP (HPQ) into two halves clearly could help facilitate a sale, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald.
HP reportedly had merger talks with storage systems leader EMC (EMC) earlier this year.
EMC wouldn't want the PC or printer business, says White, "so now they have the flexibility" to acquire the enterprise business.
Enterprise M&A More Likely

The enterprise group is the more likely takeover candidate, says Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities. "Enterprise is where the M&A activity is going to occur, vs. the PCs and printing segments," he told IBD.
Others agree.

"The enterprise segment would likely be the first to go," said Bill Kreher, an analyst for Edward Jones. "I think EMC is a takeover candidate, given the rumors of HP and EMC's discussions earlier this year."
HP's combination hardware-software products that compete with rivals such Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Oracle (ORCL) offer upside for EMC, says Kreher.
"If (EMC is) going to go with these more integrated solutions, then HP has an offering for basically every technology that is available, whether it's storage or hardware or networking," he said.
HP plans to complete the split by Oct. 31, 2015, the end of its next fiscal year.
HP stock, which touched a 40-month high of 38.25 on Sept. 4, rose 4.7% Monday, to 36.87.

The company is midway through a five-year restructuring effort launched by then-new HP CEO Meg Whitman in May 2012, with the goal of reigniting HP growth. Hurt by slowing sales in its printer business, which had been its longtime profit center, HP's year-over-year revenue fell 11 consecutive quarters before the company eked out a 1% rise last quarter.

Whitman had long advocated keeping the company together, and she was brought in shortly after a brief, failed attempt to sell the PC business. Enterprise rival IBM (IBM) had sold off its PC business to China's Lenovo a decade ago.
Divide And Conquer
Now, Whitman says the situation has changed. In a conference call Monday with analysts, she said the split would help efforts to reaccelerate growth.

"Separating into two companies will enable each management team to have a sharper focus on the opportunities that the different markets represent," she said. "We think it is the right time to be able to do this."

The move follows a similar announcement last week from eBay (EBAY), to spin off its PayPal online payment services unit into a separate company. Analysts have suggested spinoffs or split-ups for some other tech giants with slow growth, such as Cisco and Microsoft (MSFT) .

Whitman will take over as president and CEO of what will be called Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. Dion Weisler, executive vice president of HP's printing and personal systems business, will become president and CEO of that business, called HP Inc.
"Whitman is the strongest leader they have, so they put her with the business that I would view they care the most about," analyst White said.
HP's enterprise businesses have been hit and miss.

For its Q3 ended July 31, revenue for HP's enterprise group, which includes server and storage products, rose 2% to $6.89 billion. But enterprise services revenue fell 6% to $5.59 billion, and software group sales fell 5% to $959 million.
In Q3, HP's printing group revenue declined 5% to $3.66 billion.
Revenue from the company's personal systems group, which is mostly PCs, climbed 12% to $8.64 billion. It was the third consecutive quarter of year-over-year revenue growth for that business.

That could help a possible sale of that business, says analyst Kreher. "The PC environment has improved markedly in the last 12 months," he said.Hewlett-Packard going splitsville could lead to a marriage down the road to EMC or some other suitors.The computer giant early Monday said it would split into two separate companies, one focused on PCs and printers and the other on products and services for companies and other enterprises.While each company individually would still be huge, at more than $50 billion in annual sales, cleaving HP (HPQ) into two halves clearly could help facilitate a sale, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald.HP reportedly had merger talks with storage systems leader EMC (EMC) earlier this year.EMC wouldn't want the PC or printer business, says White, "so now they have the flexibility" to acquire the enterprise business.Enterprise M&A More LikelyThe enterprise group is the more likely takeover candidate, says Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities. "Enterprise is where the M&A activity is going to occur, vs. the PCs and printing segments," he told IBD.Others agree."The enterprise segment would likely be the first to go," said Bill Kreher, an analyst for Edward Jones. "I think EMC is a takeover candidate, given the rumors of HP and EMC's discussions earlier this year."HP's combination hardware-software products that compete with rivals such Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Oracle (ORCL) offer upside for EMC, says Kreher."If (EMC is) going to go with these more integrated solutions, then HP has an offering for basically every technology that is available, whether it's storage or hardware or networking," he said.HP plans to complete the split by Oct. 31, 2015, the end of its next fiscal year.HP stock, which touched a 40-month high of 38.25 on Sept. 4, rose 4.7% Monday, to 36.87.The company is midway through a five-year restructuring effort launched by then-new HP CEO Meg Whitman in May 2012, with the goal of reigniting HP growth. Hurt by slowing sales in its printer business, which had been its longtime profit center, HP's year-over-year revenue fell 11 consecutive quarters before the company eked out a 1% rise last quarter.Whitman had long advocated keeping the company together, and she was brought in shortly after a brief, failed attempt to sell the PC business. Enterprise rival IBM (IBM) had sold off its PC business to China's Lenovo a decade ago.Divide And ConquerNow, Whitman says the situation has changed. In a conference call Monday with analysts, she said the split would help efforts to reaccelerate growth."Separating into two companies will enable each management team to have a sharper focus on the opportunities that the different markets represent," she said. "We think it is the right time to be able to do this."The move follows a similar announcement last week from eBay (EBAY), to spin off its PayPal online payment services unit into a separate company. Analysts have suggested spinoffs or split-ups for some other tech giants with slow growth, such as Cisco and Microsoft (MSFT) .Whitman will take over as president and CEO of what will be called Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. Dion Weisler, executive vice president of HP's printing and personal systems business, will become president and CEO of that business, called HP Inc."Whitman is the strongest leader they have, so they put her with the business that I would view they care the most about," analyst White said.HP's enterprise businesses have been hit and miss.For its Q3 ended July 31, revenue for HP's enterprise group, which includes server and storage products, rose 2% to $6.89 billion. But enterprise services revenue fell 6% to $5.59 billion, and software group sales fell 5% to $959 million.In Q3, HP's printing group revenue declined 5% to $3.66 billion.Revenue from the company's personal systems group, which is mostly PCs, climbed 12% to $8.64 billion. It was the third consecutive quarter of year-over-year revenue growth for that business.That could help a possible sale of that business, says analyst Kreher. "The PC environment has improved markedly in the last 12 months," he said.
When an employee decamps, breaking a contract and taking the secret sauce formula and customer list with him, the result can be an unholy legal mess.
Companies can bypass that grief by looking at how and why they hire, says Carlos Becerra, an attorney with the southern California firm of Tredway Lumsdaine & Doyle.
"The biggest thing employers need to understand is that there can be a fine line between promoting and growing your own business and engaging in acts of unfair competition," said Becerra.
Employers shouldn't target one particular company for their personnel needs. National advertising is the way to go, says Becerra.
And employers need a clear purpose in mind when adding new workers to the payroll — not to destroy a competitor but to bolster their own enterprise.
"You're not hiring the employee to bring clients or proprietary information with them," Becerra said. "You're hiring them for their skills and experience."
A well-written employee handbook helps, he says.
Make sure it's up to date and addresses the company policy of not bringing confidential or proprietary information from a previous employer, he advises.
Secret Sauce
Many employers don't get across how important trade secrets — the secret sauce recipes — are to a company, says attorney Kurt Kappes of New York and Miami-based law firm Greenberg Traurig.
That's not at the time of hiring, not during the course of employment and sometimes not even when the employee leaves, he says.
"A lot of it is educating the workforce," says Kappes, who is based in Sacramento and is a visiting professor at the University of California at Davis.
When an employee has signed an agreement not to work for a competitor for a certain period of time after leaving — a noncompete agreement — it can get tricky.
"At least in California, some employees will go to work for a new employer and then turn around and sue the previous employer to throw out the noncompete agreement," Kappes said.
Employers may want to consider whether a particular hire justifies the potential downside.
"One thing they need to do is figure out whether the hire is worth it," said Kappes. "From a business standpoint, the question is, do they want to take the risk?"

It can work out in the new employer's favor, he says, pointing to a 2011 wrangle between two tech giants that he mentions both to clients and to his UC Davis class on trade secrets and employee mobility.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) hired an IBM (IBM) general manager to come over as a senior vice president. HP structured the job so that it involved different work, different geographic responsibilities and a different level of responsibility, Kappes says.
IBM sued the HP employee, alleging violation of a noncompete agreement — and lost.
In a lawsuit-happy environment, human resources professionals have their hands full making sure they do things right.
Wayne Perrett knows the drill. He looks for professionals from engineers to salespeople in his work.

Perrett heads human resources for ComAp, a Roscoe, Ill., subsidiary of a Czech Republic-based company that designs and manufactures electronic control systems for nuclear plants and offshore drilling engines.
The company has 20-25 employees and expects to have four times that many by 2018, Perrett says.
He likes to work with recruiters to find candidates, ideally those already employed elsewhere.
"My job is to work with a recruiter and get that person to convince our candidate to talk with me," Perrett said. "I'll convince the candidate, if they're the right one, to come and work for us."
One of the first questions Perrett asks a prospective employee is whether the person has a noncompete agreement in place and what the terms are.
That question and others that follow are for the protection of all concerned, Perrett says.
Companies' reputations can sustain damage in the hiring process. A company doesn't want to get known as one that "steals" competitors' employees. Bad for ethics, bad for business, Perrett says.
"Reaching out to competitors is not illegal," he says. "There are some land mines, though. One is from a reputation standpoint."
Do The Research
Companies wanting to recruit that ideal new hire need to do their research, says Sally Stetson, principal at Philadelphia area-based executive search firm Salveson Stetson Group.

No blanket emails to the competition's employees, for example, says Stetson, who heads her firm's human resources practice. Research means determining who might be the right choice and honing in on them and them alone, she says.
Companies should keep in mind that potential new employees may have heard bad information about them, she says.
"It's a tradition to bad-mouth competitors," Stetson said.
If it gets to the stage of sitting down and talking to a potential new hire, that's the time to clear the air, she says.
"In the interview, it's important to dispel any myths about the company conducting the hiring," Stetson said.
Interviewers themselves need to watch that they don't reveal more than they intended to, she says.

"It's a little bit of a tightrope for the interviewer," Stetson said. "It would be problematic if the interviewer disclosed sensitive information and the employee was not hired."When an employee decamps, breaking a contract and taking the secret sauce formula and customer list with him, the result can be an unholy legal mess.Companies can bypass that grief by looking at how and why they hire, says Carlos Becerra, an attorney with the southern California firm of Tredway Lumsdaine & Doyle."The biggest thing employers need to understand is that there can be a fine line between promoting and growing your own business and engaging in acts of unfair competition," said Becerra.Employers shouldn't target one particular company for their personnel needs. "You're hiring them for their skills and experience."A well-written employee handbook helps, he says.Make sure it's up to date and addresses the company policy of not bringing confidential or proprietary information from a previous employer, he advises.Secret SauceMany employers don't get across how important trade secrets — the secret sauce recipes — are to a company, says attorney Kurt Kappes of New York and Miami-based law firm Greenberg Traurig.That's not at the time of hiring, not during the course of employment and sometimes not even when the employee leaves, he says."A lot of it is educating the workforce," says Kappes, who is based in Sacramento and is a visiting professor at the University of California at Davis.When an employee has signed an agreement not to work for a competitor for a certain period of time after leaving — a noncompete agreement — it can get tricky."At least in California, some employees will go to work for a new employer and then turn around and sue the previous employer to throw out the noncompete agreement," Kappes said.Employers may want to consider whether a particular hire justifies the potential downside."One thing they need to do is figure out whether the hire is worth it," said Kappes. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) on Tuesday announced a new Google (GOOG) Chromebook, the HP Chromebook 11, which the companies are marketing as a "new option for schools and businesses."
The 2.3-pound laptop has an 11.6-inch screen and a mostly white body with "color accents." It sells for $279.99, HP says.
The stock market wasn't impressed. Hewlett-Packard stock and Google stock were both down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market Tuesday.
The new Chromebooks are aimed at schools and businesses, Rajen Sheth, Google's Chrome OS director of product management, wrote in a blog post Tuesday.

The new Chromebooks can be charged with a micro-USB charger, the same type of charger that many Android cellphones use, according to another blog post, this one by Caesar Sengupta, a Google vice president of product management.

Like all Chromebooks, the new laptops run Google's Chrome operating system, which relies on saving files to the Internet "cloud" and not on the device itself. Chromebooks compete with the many laptops that run Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows.
The version announced Tuesday has Wi-Fi Internet. A version that is expected to launch later this year will have 4G LTE via Verizon Wireless, Hewlett-Packard said in a news release.
Related: Hewlett-Packard Launches Holiday Notebook Lineup.

EMC (EMC) could be next up on the breakup wave, as hedge fund manager Elliott Management urged the data storage company in a letter Wednesday to spin off VMware.

Elliott, which owns 2.2% of EMC, recommended it separate VMware (VMW) and sell other assets to improve shareholder value. EMC, the largest global provider of data storage systems, owns about 80% of VMware, the No. 1 provider of virtualization software.

"Though EMC is a leader in numerous markets with great products, EMC's stock price has deeply underperformed its proxy peers and the market over all relevant time periods," Elliott said in its letter. "Both EMC and VMware have grown and are now competing against one another, confusing customers, employees, Street analysts and shareholders."
EMC declined to comment.
EMC stock up a fraction, near 28, in afternoon trading on the stock market today and it's up more than 10% in 2014. VMware stock was down a fraction, near 91.
The letter comes on the heels of spinoff announcements by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and eBay.

Hewlett-Packard plans to separate its personal systems and printing business into a separate company, with rumors rising that EMC and the HP enterprise business could merge. EBay (EBAY) is spinning off its PayPal unit.

Daniel Ives, analyst at FBR Capital Markets, in a report Wednesday said these developments reflect the growing pressures and growth challenges faced by mature technology giants such as IBM (IBM), Symantec (SYMC), Oracle (ORCL) and others. The challenges come amid sluggish spending on information technology and increased competition from new companies.
"Elliott Management could spark changes at EMC, as the company has significant flexibility in areas such as capital allocation and M&A," Ives wrote.

Ives and others also have suggested that Symantec could be part of the breakup wave, splitting its security and storage businesses into two entities. Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Dow futures were level, trading 92.5 points above fair market value.
Nasdaq 100 futures and S&P 500 futures were also steady, up 33.4 and 11.4 points, respectively.

The stock market today has its work cut out for it, although Christmas week trade generally tends to be light. The young uptrend ran into heavy distribution Friday, raising questions as to how long it will last.

Economic news isn't likely to have much impact. The Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, the most prominent piece of economic news prior to the open, showed a 0.3% slip in November. That accelerated October's 0.17% contraction and was not what economist consensus had expected — a 0.15% increase.

International markets also appeared to have negligible effect. Stocks in Europe traded modestly higher at midday. China's markets rose, including a 1.8% jump from the Shanghai Composite, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan slipped 0.4%.

The dollar rose. Bonds edged up. Oil prices slipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1%, bobbing between $34 and $35 a barrel, and Brent crude down 2% to just above $36. Most metals traded higher, but with no big gains.

There could be a "Star Wars" effect on early trade, with Walt Disney (DIS) being one of three stocks leading the Dow with a better-than 1% gain in premarket trade. Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL) also gained more than 1%.

Disney's "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" grossed an estimated $238 million in the U.S. and Canada over the weekend. That was above expectations, beating out prior record holders "Jurassic World," which grossed $208.8 million when it premiered in June, and "The Avengers," which pulled $207.4 million in its 2012 premier.
Disney shares briefly cleared a 117.678 buy point in a cup-with-handle base in November, then dropped and undercut the buy point by more than 8%, triggering a sell rule.

Huge-screen, 3D-savvy Imax (IMAX) jumped 3%. The new "Star Wars" film reportedly premiered on 667 Imax screens over the weekend, pulling in $48 million — setting an Imax record and topping the $44.1 million opening weekend take of "Jurassic World," according to box office figures from Deadline Hollywood. Imax, an IBD 50 stock, ended Friday about 2% below a 39.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Also on the IBD 50 list, ARM (ARMH) perked up 3% ahead of the open. Shares of the Cambridge, England-based chip designer tumbled 6% last week, ending below the stock's converged 10- and 40-week lines of support.Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. U.S. tech company job cuts rose by 68% in the first half of 2014 and Microsoft's  (MSFT) big layoffs announced this month ensure that 2014's tech job losses will exceed last year's, consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas said Monday. The tally is ironic, given the overall job growth in the economy, including in technology. "Oddly, the rise in technology…

Hewlett-Packard has stepped up investments in cloud computing, prompting some analysts to speculate that it could make a big move such as acquiring Rackspace Hosting.That, however, would require HP (HPQ) to ratchet up its spending significantly, since Rackspace (RAX) could sell for $6 billion or $7 billion.HP in May said that it plans to spend $1 billion over the next two years to develop cloud products and services. At an annual conference for business customers in Las Vegas this month, the Palo Alto, Calif.-based HP said that it will expand from two data centers to 25 by the end of 2015. The data centers will be packed with servers and data-storage systems that customers rent via the cloud.HP is playing catch-up to Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), in the cloud field known as Infrastructure as a Service. Microsoft (MSFT), Google (GOOGL) and IBM (IBM) also are IaaS leaders.As in the case of IBM and other traditional IT suppliers, HP's sales of hardware and software could slow as more companies opt to rent computing technology rather than build new data centers of their own. That's why expanding into IaaS and related cloud products and services is a good move for HP, analysts say. HP stock is up nearly 25% in 2014 as the company is two years into its turnaround plan.Rackspace sells cloud services, including extra customer support and custom tools, as well as self-serve, on-demand IaaS products. The company is a co-developer, with NASA, of the open-source OpenStack cloud operating system.Would acquiring Rackspace, which has a market cap of $5.2 billion, boost HP's cloud strategy? Views are mixed."It's possible that HP will decide to do something foolish, but I don't think Rackspace is a logical acquisition. Rackspace really hasn't been successful selling OpenStack to the enterprise," Lydia Leong, an analyst with market-research firm Gartner, told IBD. "It would be a $6 billion to $7 billion acquisition."And if HP were to spend so much on an acquisition, it could get a lot more for that money, Leong says.HP, IBM and Red Hat (RHT) are among companies that have embraced OpenStack, which helps companies connect private data centers to the public cloud.Large companies, though, have been slow to move big computing workloads to OpenStack. Amazon and others, meanwhile, have different cloud software.Some Pluses To Merger"An HP/Rackspace combination could drive favorable top-line synergies by combining Rackspace's strong brand in the cloud/hosting segment with HP's established enterprise sales channels as well as greater momentum in OpenStack, which both companies are actively sponsoring," Jonathan Atkin, an RBC Capital analyst, said in a recent research report."However, Rackspace's lack of a highly automated (cloud) platform compared to earlier hosting/cloud takeout targets could present an additional operating challenge in the eyes of a potential acquirer," Atkin wrote.IBM acquired IaaS firm SoftLayer for $2 billion last year after taking a look at Rackspace, analysts say.Last month, San Antonio-based Rackspace hired Morgan Stanley to explore strategic options, including a sale or partnership. Rackspace's year-over-year earnings have fallen the past four quarters amid slowing revenue growth.Rackspace has been hurt by severe price cutting in the IaaS market, analysts say. AWS, by far the biggest IaaS company, in particular has been slashing prices.However, Jim Breen, an analyst at William Blair, sees Rackspace's OpenStack as possibly valuable for a potential acquirer."Rackspace has had difficulty keeping pace with Amazon Web Services and with monetizing OpenStack's nascent popularity," Breen said in a research report. "OpenStack is still in the early innings of paid deployment, and Rackspace lacks the enterprise reach of many of its competitors, namely Red Hat, VMware (VMW), HP and Microsoft."Because Rackspace operates the largest production deployment of OpenStack and is the second-largest public cloud provider to AWS, it could be a strategic asset to other companies in the OpenStack ecosystem, such as AT&T (T), IBM, EMC (EMC), HP and VMware."Most OpenStack supporters are pushing a hybrid cloud-computing model, which meshes both private and public infrastructure. Some business apps stay behind a private corporate-security firewall, but companies can access public IaaS providers for on-demand services.Gartner's Leong says that HP has hundreds of its own software engineers already working on OpenStack, one reason why it doesn't need Rackspace.Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan says that Rackspace has been augmenting its OpenStack-based platform with more VMware-compatible offerings.Some analysts say that Rackspace's market cap and asking price might put off HP and other possible buyers. Horan speculates that Rackspace might sell in the low to mid $50 per share range."At around $7 billion, Rackspace would require a significant commitment," said UBS analyst Steven Milunovich, who has a neutral rating on Rackspace stock.Cisco Systems (CSCO) last month signaled that it is not interested in buying Rackspace.Mark Kelleher, an analyst at D.A. Davidson, downgraded Rackspace on Friday to underperform."With the stock now trading at an enterprise value of approximately 7.5 times our 2015 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) estimate, we believe the valuation is more than fair for the ongoing cloud business, given the growth profile," Kelleher said in a research note.

Aerohive Networks (HIVE) is challenging rivals such as Motorola (MSI), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Juniper Networks (JNPR) in the wireless networking equipment market as use of mobile devices explodes and companies look for better ways to manage usage growth. That was the upshot from a presentation by David Flynn, Aerohive's chief executive, at William Blair & Co.'s annual growth stock conference…

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) is expected late Wednesday to report triple-digit earnings growth for the second consecutive quarter, but revenue growth is forecast to hit record deceleration.For its fiscal Q4 2015, the consensus of 34 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters sees Palo Alto Networks pulling in 25 cents earnings per share ex items, up 127% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Revenue is forecast to increase 44% up to $256.25 million.While still robust, the revenue increase would be Palo Alto Networks' smallest percentage gain since the company's IPO in December 2010. Over the past year, the Silicon Valley firm has posted revenue growth above the 50%-mark every quarter.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Palo Alto Networks has handily beat consensus earnings and revenue estimates every quarter this year.Wall Street's Q4 forecast mostly mirrored the company's. During its Q3 earnings conference call, Palo Alto Networks guided to between 24 and 25 cents non-GAAP EPS on $252 million to $256 million in revenue.CEO Mark McLaughlin expressed revenue optimism during a recent company sales event, Wells Fargo analyst Gray Powell wrote in a research report.McLaughlin claimed revenue would breach $2 billion over the next two years, Powell wrote.The growth will happen organically, McLaughlin said. But, Powell points out, analysts don't see Palo Alto Networks nearing the $2 billion line. For the year, the consensus models $900.6 million in revenue."PANW's unofficial target is some 20% above current Street forecasts and implies 40% per year growth vs. the Street (estimate) at 29% for the next two years," Powell wrote.Powell acknowledged the comments were likely aspirational, but "we view the fact they were made just three weeks after the close of FQ4 '15 as an indication that current trends remain strong."The company's position on Wall Street hasn't been strong recently, however. Palo Alto Networks stock has declined 18% over the past six weeks vs. the Nasdaq drop of 8%.Powell saw the silver lining."We think this creates a compelling entry point into a high quality/high growth security company that benefits from favorable secular trends," he wrote.Palo Alto Networks' marketing efforts have paid off, Powell wrote. Currently, the marketing focus is on endpoint software Traps, the next generation firewall and WildFire, a cloud-based malware analysis machine, he wrote.Powell maintained his outperform rating on Palo Alto Networks stock.Palo Alto Networks closed up fractionally Friday at 162.39. With the market in a correction, Palo Alto stock dropped 3.3% for the week after hitting a four-month low at 140.39 on Aug. 24.The same day, IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group fell 3.4%, hitting a seven-month low.Palo Alto Networks leads the group with a 97 Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99. Competitors CyberArk Software (CYBR), Check Point Software (CHKP), AVG Technologies (AVG) and Verisign (VRSN) follow distantly with Composite Ratings in the 80s.Follow Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook .

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) extended its lead in the global market for server computers in the second quarter, while principal rivals IBM and Dell lost ground, market research firm IDC reported Tuesday. HP took 25.4% of the server market based on factory revenue in Q2, up from 25% a year earlier. It increased its server sales by 4% year over year to…

Hewlett-Packard's  (HPQ) PC business, of all things, could be the lone upside when the computer products and services company reports earnings for its fiscal third quarter after the market close Wednesday. The tech giant continues to slog through a five-year restructuring plan aimed at pushing growth in cloud services, software and other areas to offset declining sales in its…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) seems poised to continue its recent positive performance in notebooks and commercial business revenue, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research report Friday, ahead of HP's Discover user conference next week.
HP's notebook and commercial business revenue rose by 7% and 12%, respectively, year over year in fiscal Q2 ended April 30, Bracelin said.

"Our semiconductor team raised our notebook forecasts for the month of May based on enterprise-PC demand trends, which remain healthy," he wrote. "Despite this being a small uptick, it was an encouraging sign that perhaps a corporate refresh cycle has legs beyond just the (Microsoft) XP (operating system) expiration in April."
In April, Microsoft ceased offering support for its 12-year-old, but still popular, Windows XP operating system.
Bracelin also expects big things to come out of HP's Discover user conference.

"Not only do we expect HP to weigh in on how its new product and service offerings are enabling Big Data and cloud, but we also expect to hear an update on new innovations coming out of HP Labs," he wrote.

HP has posted a year-over-year decline in revenue in its past 11 quarters, as the company works through a five-year restructuring effort launched in May 2012 and aimed at pushing growth in its emerging cloud, Big Data, security and other businesses to offset declines in its core PC and printing units, which provide the bulk of its revenue.

But HP reported year-over-year growth in its PC business in the past two quarters. HP posted disappointing Q2 revenue last month, but it also said that it would lay off more employees to cut costs further, and the stock continued its uptrend.

HP stock is up more than 20% in 2014, though shares were down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) seems poised to continue its recent positive performance in notebooks and commercial business revenue, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research report Friday, ahead of HP's Discover user conference next week.HP's notebook and commercial business revenue rose by 7% and 12%, respectively, year over year in fiscal Q2 ended April 30, Bracelin said."Our semiconductor team raised our notebook forecasts for the month of May based on enterprise-PC demand trends, which remain healthy," he wrote. Move over Hewlett-Packard, Cisco Systems (CSCO) is No. 1.
Computer networking leader Cisco supplanted HP as the top maker of x86 blade servers in the Americas, according to a report released Wednesday by market tracker IDC.
And Cisco's overall server growth of 39% for the 12 months ended March 31 led all rivals, says the market research firm.

HP and IBM (IBM) are the global server leaders, but IBM is in the process of selling its x86 server business to China's Lenovo. The 'x86' refers to servers that run on industry-standard x86 chips, generally the lower end of the server market. Dell, now privately held, and Oracle (ORCL) are the others in the top five.
Other than Cisco, the others in the top five had flat or falling server revenue in the 12 months ended March 31, says IDC.
Cisco stock, though, was down a fraction in morning trading in the stock market today, while HP stock was up a fraction.

Cisco has been building share in the server market since 2009, when it launched its Unified Computing System, which combines computing, networking and solid-state application acceleration technology into a single integrated platform, Paul Perez, general manager of Cisco UCS, said in a company press release Wednesday.

"Disruptive innovation has been the secret to our server success," he said. "In 2009, we delivered the first true innovation the server industry had seen in over a decade. Five years later, we're now the undisputed leader in x86 blade servers across the Americas, and we are poised to capture the worldwide market over the next few quarters."
Cisco posted better-than-expected April-quarter earnings last month.

HP is working through a five-year restructuring plan launched two years ago. The company recently announced more layoffs.Move over Hewlett-Packard, Cisco Systems (CSCO) is No. 1.Computer networking leader Cisco supplanted HP as the top maker of x86 blade servers in the Americas, according to a report released Wednesday by market tracker IDC.And Cisco's overall server growth of 39% for the 12 months ended March 31 led all rivals, says the market research firm.HP and IBM (IBM) are the global server leaders, but IBM is in the process of selling its x86 server business to China's Lenovo. Privately held Dell isn't slashing prices in the personal computer market, which is good news for Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), says UBS in a report.
Though privately held since an October buyout by founder Michael Dell and investment partner Silver Lake Partners, Dell held an analyst day event in Austin, Texas, last week.

"The good news for competitors is that Dell says it has become more price-disciplined, so it does not appear to be taking a scorched-earth approach as a private company," UBS analyst Steven Milunovich said in a report. "Dell says it has gained PC share for five consecutive quarters.
"The single fastest-growing business for Dell was commercial PCs in Q1. The company has implemented more pricing discipline; it wants to be competitive on price but not a low-price leader."
China was the fastest-growing component of Dell's PC business, R.W. Baird analyst Jayson Noland said in a report, "despite local competition from Lenovo."

In the server market, Dell aims to take share from "IBM (IBM)/Lenovo during their transition," said Milunovich. IBM is selling its Intel x86-based server business to Lenovo, which bought IBM's PC business in 2005.
"Dell has reached out to partners that were aligned with IBM and has found two camps: ones that really want to work with Dell and one that is looking to Dell as a hedge," he wrote.
Dell told analysts that its Q1 server sales rose 7% from the year-earlier period.
"The company sells high-volume, low-margin servers to cloud service providers like Microsoft (MSFT)," Milunovich said.
"We believe the HP-Foxconn partnership to sell servers to the hyperscale cloud could be a reaction to Dell's traction in this category," added Milunovich.
He says Dell does not plan on introducing wearable devices. Apple (AAPL) is expected to roll out the iWatch later this year, joining Samsung, Google (GOOG) and others in the wearables market.

"Like Apple, Dell does plan on investing in and selling tablets," Milunovich said. "It sees Android on tablets as viable and believes Windows tablets will get a lift from security and upcoming (4G wireless) LTE."

At R.W. Baird, Noland says Dell does not plan a big investment in cloud computing services, like HP. Amazon Web Services, part of e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft and Google are big players in the infrastructure-as-a-service market.
"Instead, Dell will help build private clouds, sell equipment to cloud service providers, and resell public cloud offerings from (partners) like Google and Microsoft," Noland said.

Internet service providers need some techie help dealing with the crushing weight of Big Data, and it increasingly looks like they might have an answer: NFV. Little-known Network Functions Virtualization is a software-based system that can help speed the flow of increasing amounts of data through networks at reduced costs. The biggest networking vendors are vying to be top NFV…

ServiceNow's (NOW) trajectory as one of the fastest-growing companies among the young gun high-growth software names will likely continue when the company reports its second-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday.The maker of software-as-a-service used to manage service desk functions is growing at the expense of larger rivals BMC Software, CA Technologies (CA) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).ServiceNow stock was up more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 59. But ServiceNow stock is down 18% since touching an all-time high of 71.80 on Feb. 27. ServiceNow made its IPO in June 2012, pricing its initial shares at 18.The company is expanding into new areas, including software to help manage human resources and sales and marketing departments.Growth won't be an issue with the Q2 results, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James, said in a report Tuesday."U.S. checks with systems integrators, (value added resellers and large account resellers) this quarter indicated continued strong business momentum with ServiceNow's product suite," he wrote. "Increasingly, we heard resellers and integrators say customers are standardizing on ServiceNow instead of deploying in mixed environments with legacy vendors, and are viewing ServiceNow as a more strategic vendor."For Q2, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a loss per-share minus items of 7 cents vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period.Revenue is expected to climb 58% to $161.5 million.For the current quarter, analysts expect a per-share loss of 3 cents, up from a penny a share loss, with revenue rising 52% to $169.5 million.Turits rates ServiceNow stock a strong buy, for a number of reasons."ServiceNow is our analyst current favorite and we continue to be positive on the stock given the company's role as a pioneer and leader in SaaS-based ITSM, ability to displace legacy on-premise ITSM vendors including BMC and HP, expansion of both ITSM and new packaged operations management applications within customers and ability to drive usage of its business workflow development platform," he wrote.RELATED:CA Seen Gaining By Selling Storage-Software Business.

Hewlett-Packard stock popped higher Tuesday on a bullish analyst report that made a case for improved profitability at the information-technology company.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin upgraded Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) stock to outperform from sector perform and set a price target of 37. HP stock was up nearly 2.5%, near 33, in midday trading in the stock market today."We are upgrading HPQ to outperform based on increased confidence in a profit recovery from a seven-year low, led by operating-margin expansion, enterprise-share gains and stabilizing PC trends," Bracelin wrote.HP should benefit from IBM's (IBM) decision to exit the x86 server market, he said. IBM sold its low-end server business to Lenovo (LNVGY) in January.HP has made solid progress in its turnaround efforts under CEO Meg Whitman, Bracelin said."We see meaningful upside to consensus EPS as profits recover this year and next year," Bracelin wrote. "Operating margins are still at a seven-year low of 8.5% vs. a peak of 11.4%."Bracelin raised his earnings-per-share estimates on expectations for a PC refresh cycle, enterprise-share gains — mostly from IBM and Acer — and profit-margin expansion."Despite the sharp move in the stock off the bottom, HPQ is still in the early innings of a multiyear turnaround, in our view," Bracelin said.Pacific Crest has historically had a neutral or negative bias toward HP, stemming from concerns about its eroding core business, market-share losses and secular head winds. The upgrade to outperform is the first time that Pacific Crest has been positive on HP since initiating coverage on the stock in 2004, Bracelin said."Our bias on HPQ today has substantially improved after careful examination of the IT supply chain, changing competitive dynamics, turnaround progress, strategic direction from new leadership and new initiatives that are rebuilding channel support," Bracelin wrote. "We now have increasing confidence and improving visibility that HP can begin to deliver a sustainable profit recovery in (fiscal) 2014, which should build further momentum into (fiscal) 2015."RELATED: HP Moonshot Servers Gain Traction.

AT&T, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), EMC (EMC), Cisco Systems and IBM loom as possible buyers of Rackspace Hosting (RAX), whose stock jumped late Thursday after the company said it had hired Morgan Stanley to explore strategic options, including a sale or partnership. Rackspace's stock rose 14% before the market open in the stock market today. Shares in Rackspace popped 7% on Thursday…

Google (GOOGL) stock rose Friday to a four-month high after the search powerhouse posted Q2 revenue that beat Wall Street expectations, fueled by a 33% jump in paid ad clicks on its own sites.The No. 1 search provider's earnings per share actually missed analyst views, but analysts and investors liked the top-line numbers.Google stock was up 3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today ex items jumped 27% to $6.08, its best year-over-year gain in three years. But that fell below the $6.24 Wall Street had projected, according to Thomson Reuters."Google is pursuing absolutely the right strategy" with its aggressive investments in its core segments of search and display/video advertising as well as its new businesses, including Google Play and cloud computing, wrote Mark Mahaney, an analyst with RBC Capital Markets, in a research report.But he noted that continuing challenges for the company include rising commissions to its ad partners, or so-called traffic acquisition costs. TAC payments increased to $3.29 billion in Q2, up from $3.01 billion the prior quarter.Mahaney also wrote that Google is still struggling in its transition to mobile as cost-per-clicks continue to decline. Still, he maintained an outperform rating on Google stock.Google "remains our top large-cap pick," Colin Sebastian, an analyst with Baird Equity Research, said in a research note. "We believe Google will continue to benefit from multiple long-term growth opportunities (e.g., mobile, video, enterprise, local, wearables, etc.)."BMO Capital Markets boosted its price target to 600 from 525, keeping its buy rating. Topeka Capital Markets boosted its price target to 660 from 657. It also rates Google stock a buy.On Thursday, Mountain View, Calif.-based Google announced the departure of longtime Chief Business Officer Nikesh Arora. He's leaving to join Japan's SoftBank as CEO of its Internet and Media division and vice chairman.Omid Kordestani, who led the company's sales team for many years, will take over Arora's position for now. But Google declined to talk more about how it will replace Arora.RELATED:Google, Autodesk, HP, Apple Eye Consumer 3D Printer MarketGoogle, eBay Merger Suggested As Alternative to PayPal Spinoff.

Stocks got off to a subdued start Thursday, opening lower and quickly turning mixed.
The Nasdaq dropped 0.7%. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average erased a narrow early loss to gain a fraction, as IBM (IBM) and AT&T (T) pulled up 1% each.
Volume started higher, but quickly turned mixed on the stock market today. Trade was down 4% on the Nasdaq, up 5% on the NYSE.

The Labor Department's weekly jobless claims report was positive, aside from an upward revision to the prior week's numbers. Inflation inched up in March, with import prices rising 0.6%, above expectations for a 0.2% gain. Export prices improved 0.8%, better than February's 0.6% gain and above forecasts for a 0.3% increase. China's markets rallied, despite data showing slower imports and exports in March.

In stocks, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) rose 3% in powerful trade after announcing it had paid $108 million to settle a long-standing bribery suit brought by the U.S. Justice Department. The news counteracted a report released by Gartner saying PC industry shipments fell 1.7% in Q1. The gain put the computer-maker just below its April 2 high as it works on its fourth straight weekly gain.
Among leaders, about 80% of the IBD 50 stocks moved lower at the open.

Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) dropped more than 3% in heavy trade. The Internet security and online games provider rebounded in moderate trade Tuesday and Wednesday after finding support at its 200-day moving average.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) also dropped more than 3% in strong trade. The stock fashioned a possible bottom this week to a 20%-deep consolidation. While Rackspace Hosting (RAX) reportedly is mulling going private, many investors continue to hope for a buyout, according to an analyst.

Rackspace stock jumped 8% in midday trading Wednesday on a report early Wednesday from TechCrunch that Rackspace is considering going private after reviewing takeover bids from IBM (IBM) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).

TechCrunch reported that the HP bid was for $43 a share. Rackspace is trading near 36.50 in the stock market today, but was trading at 28.64 in midday before first an earnings beat then an announcement that it had hired Morgan Stanley to look at strategic options sent the stock rising 7%, and 18% in successive days, to 36.12.
Rackspace stock fell earlier this week when few buyers appeared interested.

The stock's surge on the going-private report shows that investors are still hoping for a buyout, perhaps spurred by the latest reports, says Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities who rates Rackspace stock underperform.

"I think that investors are hoping more for a (buyout) deal than for it to go private," Seyrafi told IBD. "But even if it goes private, it probably would be at a premium to the current share price, and that would also be a positive event near term.
"But I think investors are hoping for a (buyout), because arguably they can can get a higher price on the deal."
Rackspace is in a tough spot. The company's year-over-year revenue growth the past three quarters has been stuck at 16%, while its EPS growth has declined.
Competition among other cloud service providers, including Amazon.com (AMZN), Google (GOOG) and Microsoft (MSFT), is a main reason, Seyrafi says.

"Most investors know the story for Rackspace has become more challenging with increased competition from Amazon Web Services, Google with their compute engine and others, Microsoft Azure, for example," he said. "That competition is only increasing, and there is also increasing price cuts from AWS and others, so it does make sense for the company to try to see what is the best value they can garner in the marketplace."

Going private might not have much upside, Seyrafi said: "It's an option, but it doesn't solve a problem. They are still going to have the competition to worry about as a private company instead of a public company.

"It might make more sense for them to sell the company rather than go private."While Rackspace Hosting (RAX) reportedly is mulling going private, many investors continue to hope for a buyout, according to an analyst.Rackspace stock jumped 8% in midday trading Wednesday on a report early Wednesday from TechCrunch that Rackspace is considering going private after reviewing takeover bids from IBM (IBM) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).TechCrunch reported that the HP bid was for $43 a share.
